reviewText: I like Armello. I like it a lot. It looks fantastic, it's a beautifully-crafted world, it's got a great deal of variety both in aesthetic in characters. The world and its characters are fascinating; even with little character development, the animations alone are enough to convey each character's personality, and aspects like the Rot are mysterious enough to be captivating. I'd absolutely love to see this world explored further in other games or media - it's a world I want to spend more time in. However, I've put a good deal of time into the game, and while for the most part I've enjoyed myself, the game has two critical flaws that make me uncomfortable recommending it. So while this review is negative, please understand that in the context of it's great until you start taking it seriously."\n\nThe two major issues the game has are as follows: first

reviewText: This game is a real treat for those looking for something unique, visually attractive, and challenging. It is very well produced blend of strategy, role playing, and board gaming. The producers have comitted great attention to detail. Every element of the game; characters, story line, events, spells, equipment, flavor text, and even poetry, create a true sense that this is a fully imagined world that you have entered.\n\nBefore I go into the gameplay, a little bit on the game lore would be helpful: Armello is a kingdom of animal clans ruled by a lion (king). Unfortunately, the king has been infected by a creeping, evil disease called the Rot". It has driven him mad and slowly ebbes his health. Each night the Rot grows in him

reviewText:
After days of gathering Spirit Stones, my time had come to infiltrate the castle and cleanse the King of the Rot, at last bringing an end to the madness that had plagued Armello for so long. Twice I was thwarted, twice I lost precious time as the King fell deeper into his sickness, but on my third attempt to slip past the sinister curses, I made it beyond the palace walls. Soon we would be free!

But it was not to be. The other powers of the realm, drunk with lust for the throne, would force me out, limping, bloodied, back to my home. It became clear that I would never be able to save the King before the Rot claimed his life.

And so I began a swift campaign of political treachery. I schemed, I connived. I did things that whittled away at my soul. To my dismay, it was not long before a rival house entered the keep and slew our once great King. But they sacrificed their own life in the process. In the turmoil that followed, I slipped through the web of liars and conspirators to occupy the vaccuum of power left in the rivers of blood that now freckled our land.

I could not save the King, nor could I save my spirit. But by the gods, I would save Armello.

(Stories like this happen EVERY time I play. This game is PHENOMENAL.)

reviewText:
I bought this to play with my friends, problem is that there are no friends in Armello.
You will lie, steal, backstab and betray everyone you know and you'll have fun doing it. Best of all, you're all adorable innocent little forest creatures. Nobody ever expects the chubby squirrel.

Once you understand the game mechanics (and have patience, you'll learn all the nuances soon enough) you'll likely end up addicted and trying to coerce your friends into playing. If you're a completionist, some of the achievements are going to drive you bonkers, in a good way.

Even if you're not really into strategy games, check Armello out. I'm not big on strategy games either and I have lost so many hours to this game.

reviewText:
Armello is a skirmish boardgame-like computergame set in a relatively grim setting, featuring anthropomorphic (read: Furry, if so must!) characters. 4 players (and/or bots) are competitively trying to win the game within a set number of rounds, through one of multiple victory conditions.

More specifically, the goal of the game is to either defeat or cure 'the king' from his cursed state, before the rot that has afflicted him takes his life. Players will draw random cards every day/night as chosen from 3 types of decks, be it equipment, magic or trickery in order to increase their chance of succeeding in one of the multiple victory conditions - Meanwhile questing, fighting off corrupted beings or dealing with your other opponents trying to hinder your success.

The game delivers absolutely gorgeous  artwork and modeling, with every card containing animated artwork brought by a wide selection of skilled artists - I might personally be biased enjoying an anthropomorphic setting like this, but its undeniable that the designers spend a great deal of time focussing on the aeshethics of this game to grant us an immersive experience.


For me personally, a total recommendation - If there would be anything I would like to see changed in the feature, it would be a slightly more attractive balance between the multiple victory conditions, as I consider some of them to be drastically harder to achieve.

As for additions: This game needs more lemur!

reviewText:
My overall rating for Armello: 85/100

Armello brought us a board-game-like adventure-strategy  where four heroes are racing for the throne of Armello ruled by corrupted king. Strategy here is a key element, though luck factor is also important, as fights are being resolved with dice rolls, but a good player may ensure that odds will be on his or her side. Lets see this title in detail.

GAMEPLAY

+ Variety of heroes with unique abilities
+ Hex tile design
+ Day/Night cycle
+ Huge replayability
+ Four victory options
+ Interactive turn-based system
+ Cards
+ Story-driven prologue
o Fair multiplayer (host leave may crash the game)
o Luck and random number generator
- May be frustrating sometimes

Gameplay is cute and lovely. Heroes are moving on hex based tile, and trying to get prestige, magic, coins or even rot sometimes. With four modificable stats via quests - Fight, Body, Wits and Spirit - the amount of strategies is huge and also it adds more replayability to Armello.

There are basically four victory options. Firstly we have a Prestige victory - gaining prestige for quests, killing heroes and banes. Second one is a Spirit Stone victory, after gaining four stones through quests and stone circles, the king is banished after engaging him. Kingslayer and Rot victory are very simillar, you have to kill the king, survive, when trying for Rot, your Rot has to be higher than king's.

Day and night cycle also brings important aspect, as heroes have affinity to day parts and also other creatures too. During the day Guards move, during the night Banes are spawning and moving. It may be an advantage or disadvantage, heroes may also become corrupted, which changes their strategy.

Good strategy may bring the odds to player side, yet still luck plays an important factor here and after several unhappy rolls players may get frustrated. It is a risk, that needs to be taken. There are six kinds of cards - Items, Spells, Trickery, that may be drawn, Treasures, Followers, acquirable from dugneons or quests, and Palace cards, which player simply has to encounter. Questing is important, as it may deny the palace perils, which are really difficult and nasty.

Multiplayer is fair and it is up to the player, if they decide to team up or not, victory may belong to the best one. Also mechanics are good againts leavers or delaying players, though, when the host drops it might result to game crash.

Last addition to good points is a story-driven prologue, that is not just a simple tutorial, but the beginning of story in Armello. Also easy to understand and explain game mechanics.

CHARACTERS

+ Traits and affinities, variety of them

Player may choose so far from eight heroes and adjust the strategy accordingly.

Rabbit clan is represented by Amber, the Far Seeker, who is excellent in dungeons seeking, thus has a higher chance of get a reward. Another member is Barnaby, the Screwloose, who collects equipment and when changing equipped items, cards are not burned.

Bear Clan offers Sana, the Forest Sister, who uses Spirit instead of Fight, when dealing with corrupted creatures, and Bran, the Oakbreaker, who gains temporarily Fight after each successfully casted spell.

Rat Clan has Mercurio, the Grinning Blade, who steals gold from previous settlement owners and Zosha, the Whirlwind, who is alwasy stealthed at night and may ambush other creatures.

Finally, we have here the Wolf Clan. Thane, the Winter Wolf pierces burned cards with swords through enemy's defense, River, the Howling Arrow, shoots before fight, inflicting one hp injury to target.

King is always corrupted, whose healthe decrease and rot increase through the game. Banes get additional rot each night, guards are dealing with them, or with heroes, who have bounty on themselves.

New heroes are announced, review will be updated after release.

VISUAL

+ Nice art style
+ Animations
+ Dices
- Few graphic glitches

Art style is lovely and suits the nature of the game. Also combat animations with dice rolls are amazing (there are four different dice styles so far with animations), differing whether the dice explodes or not, also hit to the hero differs from a blocked attack. There were some graphic glitches, but very rare and not affecting gameplay.

SOUNDTRACK

+ Stylised
+ Lisa Gerrard performance
+ Changing accordingly to the atmosphere

Soundtrack is very well created and composed. Songs are underlining the dark-fantasy atmosphere and course of the game. Also Lisa Gerrard participated and her voice well known from Dead Can Dance or Gladiator suits melodies and game very well. I am glad that developers released soundtrack, that may be also purchased even by non-early-access players.

SUMMARY

To sum it up, Armello is well driven adventure-strategy game with dice rolls and a bit of luck, that resembles the style of board games. With a plenty of cards player may react to changing course of the game and adjust the strategy perfectly. This title alsom offers much to the people outside the genre, so for a reasonable price you may get a huge amount of fun.

I have been playing this game from 0.3.5 Pride's Fall" patch and game made a huge progress since.

Strongly recommended."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Armello is a turn-based strategy game similar Civilization V as it has a similar grid based layout and turn taking system. Your goal is simple, winning, but how you do it is up to you as there are multiple ways of winning a game of Armello. from what i've seen Armello provides an enjoyable single-player experience as well as an enjoyable multiplayer experience.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Pros:
Art style is very aesthetically pleasing and very nicely finished.
Gameplay is enjoyable.
Its a great game to play with you friends.
Its a relatively easy game to learn.

Cons:
Matches are a little short for my liking (I am too used to Civilization matches).
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Armello is an very enjoyable and promising game, I have been playing Armello since it was in alpha and i've seen the game grow and improve drastically and I am really excited to see what Armello has in store for us in the future.

I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys strategy games.

This game was reviewed using a code sent by the developer.
“Imagine Magic The Gathering meets Final Fantasy Tactics, and Game of Thrones meets Kung Fu Panda,
Armello is a turn based strategy game that was released in September 2015 on PC – being developed and published by League of Geeks.  The game was originally an iPad title that was released in mid-2012 before going through a successful Kickstarter project to get the game onto Steam.

The game play in Armello feels is almost like an actual board game. There are lots of different dice involved
date: and hex squares in which you can move your character. You take control of one of eight anthropomorphic animals and plot to oust the corrupt king from power. You can do this in many ways
recommended: either by becoming even more corrupt than the king
hoursPlayed: winning by coming the most prestigious character in the game by completing certain tasks
voteText: or killing the king yourself in battle. The game has a day/night cycle
helpfulPercent: you get two turns per day to carry out your actions. The game lasts for 10 nights usually. Each turn the king will lose one health but becomes more corrupt.   Your character has about 3 action points
votesHelpful: moving
votesTotal: attacking and casting spells all cost one point
votesFunny: meaning you can only do so much in one turn – planning your turn is key to this game.\n\nThe game has a card game element to it all be it a very small one. You have an unlimited deck of cards; the cards consist of equipment
commentsCount: spells and traps. Each turn you draw the amount of cards you used in the previous turn.\n\nOne way in which you will be able to win a game of Armello is to become the most prestigious character on the board. You earn prestige by killing other characters in combat
column16: killing corrupt “Banes” which the King summons
column17: or by completing various quests. Each character will have one active quest at any time; this will involve traveling across the map to a specific hex square. The quest will always be completed
column18: but you can take an extra risk by taking your chances on a dice role in order to get extra equipment or stats; failing this will mean you lose stats. I personally found the questing system in this game really fun – the flavour texts of each quest is a nice addition and the simple resolutions keep the game flowing.\n\nGraphically Armello is a really pretty looking game. All of the characters look like they have been drawn in a children’s story book

Although the game does have a fairly lengthy tutorial that does actually do a good job of explaining the rules of the game; it still took me probably two full games worth for me to just get the basics of the game down. Even now there are parts of the game that I don’t understand; it would be been nice to have a little bit of maybe a tooltip with a lot of the buttons and card effects for you to easily understand what is happening without throwing you in at the deep end and letting you click random stuff to see what happens.  The game can vary in difficulty; sometimes you can be completely screwed over by pure randomness of the cards you are dealt or the dice roles – such is life when you play board games. I think I have got about a 60% win rate at the moment which is fairly good I would imagine.

Like I said before

reviewText:
Once a time, there was a wolf, a rat, a bear and a hare…

And they all fought each other, as well as the bad lion king!

While being beautifully drawn and animated Armello is not necessarily a childs play.
Indeed it is beneath the beautiful exterior, quite a complex board game variant, which mixes board-game with card-game and rpg elements.

While you act as champion of your clan, liberate towns and followers and fulfilling quests as well as fight the other champions and the kings forces. Fitting to the scenario though, you also have different ways to win. For example you can even become corrupted by the dark forces.

On the negative side i would add though, that there sadly is not much of a story, besides the tutorial, so it really is more preferable to play this in multiplayer.

Conclusio: Armello is a beautiful board game, which is best experienced with friends. Would have loved a real single player campaign though.

Point Scale: 7/10
voteText: 82 of 112 people (73%) found this review helpful 5 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Rabbits, Rats, Wolves and Bears battling against each other to kill the King!!  Armello takes place in a beautiful fantasy setting with wonderful weather and lighting effects.  It truly is a wonder to behold.  I won’t mention so much about the graphics in this game as it is plain to see from videos and screenshots that only a fool would dispute how especially nice this game looks!

https://youtu.be/Pz5asaCPhY8

Armello is far from style over substance.  The games mechanics, whilst they may take some time to digest fully, are as beautiful as the game looks.  Don’t be fooled by the fairy-tale appearance, its gameplay is far more sinister!  Players will be poisoning, stabbing, stealing from, reaping revenge and a whole list of other mischievous acts upon their opponents.

The acts are carried out by the cards in a player’s hand, or they can be played to hexes on the board or you can just outright attack another player.  The Kings guard can also attack players if they upset the King and monsters (Banes) roam the land attacking nearby players.

As I mentioned before the objective is to kill the King and the first person to do this wins, if no one manages it before the King dies (I forgot to mention that he isn’t very well!) then the “prestige” leader wins.  Prestige is accumulated in a variety of ways including killing other players, the Banes, etc.

I’m not going to go in depth into the rules here.  The game offers a tutorial, which I found helped a little but going in blind I was quite confused by the end.  On the main menu there is also a “Game Guide” that is worth reading as well.  Hopefully after that things should be a bit clearer.  I gave up twice trying to learn the game due to not understanding the tutorial, then a friend played a game with me using VOIP and it all became clear!

I am so glad I persevered.  I must say that I haven’t met any example of a board game, either physical or digital that encapsulates so much.  If you have any interest at all in turn-based games or even better board games specifically, Armello could become your new obsession!  Heed that as a warning if anything!

Player numbers are pretty good, you can usually find an online four player game within a couple of minutes.  Sometimes it may take a little longer, which isn’t bad considering each match will take around 60-90 minutes.

The developers decided to not include in-game chat which I think is a bad decision.  Their reasoning behind this is because a few people will troll and insult others.  Yes, this is a sad fact of the world and especially the internet but that’s what mute buttons were invented for (well maybe not originally!).  The lack of chat means learning the intricacies of the game will take a bit longer and developing friendships with other Armello players may never happen from within the game.  Which I think is a shame.

Anyhow, that’s enough time away from Armello typing this review up!  I’m gonna go find myself another match and hope I can be the one to topple the king this time!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I work retail at a board games + gifts shop and Armello captivated me right from the get go. With redwall-esque anthropomorphic animals, deadly rot vultures called Banes, and a solid board game behind it to boot; this game was a no brainer for me. But is it for you?

Well, I've logged about 40+ hours in the first week of owning it and here is what to expect if you add it to your steam collection.

It's a bit much to dive into if you have no previous experience with board games, but if Puerto Rico, Settlers of Catan, Power Grid, and Lords of Waterdeep are names that are familiar to you, then you shouldn't have any problem. There are currently 4 characters (with extras for the folks who kickstarted it) each with unique starting stats. Players will balance things like fighting skill to be able to beat other players/banes, wits to increase hand size and solve challenges, health to survive longer on the game board between turns, and spirit which dictates how many spells you can cast.

You'll also be collecting gold, influence, and magic while also trying to limit the amount of rot or corruption you garner. Or will you...That's the best thing about Armello. The way to win in any given game isn't immediately obvious. In fact, there are 4 win conditions. There are turn cycles, day and night, and with each passing day the corrupted King at the center of the board grows weaker. So your options are 1: collect the most prestige points and hope he dies. 2: Collect 4 spirit stones and bring them to him to cure/exorcize the king 3: Fight him in battle and survive to claim the throne. 4: Purposely allow yourself to be corrupted by the Rot and obtain a Rot Victory. The last seems the hardest, but it gives each of the characters an interesting advantage over one another. Mercurio is great at scheming in the background stealing gold and settlements, but you can build him almost as bruisery as Thane, the wolf who is the pen ultimate of fighting.

Each game can have random stuff set you back or catapult you forwards into the lead. And sometimes that can be frustrating because it's not necessarily through any great strategy of your own, or even an opponent doing something annoying. Then again sometimes it is. So I feel like any board game it tries to balance luck and randomness with solid player strategies and tactics. The communication at present is done through emotes alone and it's hard to really convey much to the other players. It certainly isn't the same as chatting with your friends around the game table, but it's still so damn fun without the option to chat. And the art/videos/concept is simply amazing.

There is no single player campaign, so don't fool yourself into thinking this is anything but a board game. Now, it's still in early access and with the success of it who knows what they do next, but my assumption would be, more characters, new items, plot cards, perhaps new perils or monsters, eventually even new game boards or modes. But it's a board game in virtual form. Nothing more, nothing less. If that's your thing, then I hope to see you in a game soon. :)

reviewText:
Armello is an enchanting boardgame about taking down a mad king before any of the other players can.
The gameplay is pretty straightforward - go on quests, fight other players, avoid traps, and get to the king.

Admittedly the gameplay is a little too random for my tastes, but while frustrating, I still find myself having a fantastic time playing with friends. I would compare it to Catan meets Risk. You can plan for the future, but dice rolls will screw you over at some point or another.

Other than that the sound, art, and gameplay are very well polished and well executed. Definitely feeling like Redwall meets Game of Thrones in that essence.

Definitely a solid 4/5 stars.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is a must-have for anybody that loves board games.  Armello features a different board each playthrough and randomly spawning evil and good mobs to help terrorize your opponents; these things make every run a unique experience.

Due to the random nature of the game, I don't feel discouraged if I'm losing halfway through.  There are enough weapons, armor and followers to ensure my character at least has access to tools that'll turn a losing game into a winning one.

I'm a huge fan of Talisman and Elder Sign: Omens.  A game of Armello can be played in under an hour, and there aren't any characters that can just roll over other characters by default (such as the Assassin in Talisman).  Although dice rolling can be brutal, there are plenty of ways in Armello to fix" your dice results and improve your chances; the game rarely feels unfair (unlike Elder Sign
recommended: I did feel the price was a bit steep.  I'm glad to announce that I have no buyer's remorse; Armello is worth every penny."

reviewText:
Update 11/11/2015
Thought I'd refresh my review yet again.  1.1 is out, and while the Ranked mode was pushed to a later patch, there's been other great additions.  Connections between people in multiplayer are more resilient while pirates seem to have been booted from Steam's network.  More item cards were added, font size is bigger for better readability.

Single player mode is now lightning fast with fast-forward mode on: you can finish a game in 15-20 mins instead of 40.  The new house rules also let you tweak aspects like turn times, character max HP, or King's starting life.

Sharing of the Bandit characters is functioning, with their full release still planned for Early 2016.

Things the community is hoping to see in the near future:
Full reconnection to games when a player drops accidentally.
Cross Multiplayer between Steam, PS4, IOS, and DRM free.
More Houserules.
Ranked Mode.
Even More characters post Bandits.


Update added 8/2/2015

Addressing concerns found in negative reviews that are no longer accurate:

When this game first annouced early access, there was a controversy about a set of 4 characters being limited to only people who backed the Kickstarter.  This Bandit clan" has since been declared open for purchase as a paid DLC to be released a few months after the official release.  Those that were backers will get to play their "Beta" a bit before release

reviewText:
An Epic Video Board Game that will have you awe at it's beautiful graphics,sounds and art, make enemies, and fight for the crown!

Great array of characters for you to get comfortable with and learn their techniques and cards to discover for you to build your character to your wildest dreams with Equipment and buffs or put your opponents at a disadvantage or recruit handy followers to join you along in your party.

You'll spend absolute hours on mastering Armello and it'll never get old. Especially with fantastic multiplayer action & random map layouts every game.

Armello does in fact run incredibly well on my not so beefy PC so don't be afraid if the game doesn't run at all or too slow.

If you dig stuff like Redwall or games like Dokapon Kingdom and Mario Party. This may be up your alley and be sure to have some friends along too! Gets two thumbs up from me and it's incredibly easy to pick up and play!

Also Armello keeps evolving with more features and additions as time goes by. So look out!

reviewText:
Armello is a fun, addictive online board game for up to four players.  My friends and I have been playing it since it came out, pretty much non-stop.  And while we may scream in anguish after a particularly unlucky die roll, we always end up coming back for more.  An extremely tight and polished game.

Pros:
-Authentic Board Game Experience
-Incredibly addictive
-Beautiful Artistic Style
-Four paths to victory, giving options for each player to always have *some* chance of pulling out a win, even if it's from someone else failing at the last moment
-Multiple character types with unique traits and starting stats
-Three card types (Items, spells, tricks) that work very differently to achieve the same goals, allowing for more diverse strategies
-Dozens of unlockables with additional unique traits
-Easy-to-set-up multiplayer, especially with friends
-Relatively short but satisfying games (30-45 mins single player, 60-90 multiplayer)
-Excellent tutorial

Cons:
-A fair amount of luck involved, some of which can be significant enough to foil the most well-thought-out strategies
-Can get heated in multiplayer, when someone chooses to attack/interfere with another player unprovoked
-The random terrain might slant the game for/against certain people from the start
-A lot of (often random) events can provoke excess frustration, such as getting a teleport/bane from a ruin, having wandering guards/banes move into your path, being hurt by the daily declaration, etc.
-Getting across the map (usually to reach your quests) can feel painfully slow
-One victory path (Rot) significantly more difficult and luck-based than the others
-All followers and treasures (ie, the best gear) can only be attained through ruins and quest bonuses, and both of these are entirely luck based.  This can lead to gear disparity between players based on what are essentially coin flips.
-No way to get back in after a multiplayer disconnect (though an AI will take over for you)
-Some finicky, non-obvious rules are not covered by the tutorial, especially when it comes to gaining/losing influence and rot
-Like most board games, will eventually get repetitive

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has come quite a long way since I first got my hands on the Alpha build and has made great strides going to Beta and now Early access. Lot's of little improvements to the UI have been made to make keeping tabs on what goes on in-game much easier. Cards have been added and balanced as needed with the current total so far being 60 out of a planned number of over 100 cards. The game mechanics have been all put in their place to produce a decievingly deep strategy board game that can have you at certain victory only for someone or something to quickly dash your hopes and make you lose everything.

Armello overall is a game that involves a good mix of luck and skill to win. The luck aspect comes from what cards you draw, dice rolls, and dungeon exploration among other variables.  Skill on the other hand comes from knowing where to move, using the terrain to your advantage, and how to use those cards to give yourself an edge. Gameplay itself may last anywhere from about 40 minutes to an hour for multiplayer matches, depending on how long players take on their turns, and at about 30 minutes for matches against the AI. Currently there are a series of tutorial pop-ups present when you play your first game to help guide you through everything Armello has to offer since it can be a little daunting to first time players. Plenty of this game itself is seemingly done, but there's still plenty of polish to be added and feedback to be given. This in turn is where any prospective Early Access player will be able to help make this game even better by providing a fresh perspective on everything already in game plus new ideas for the future.

League of Geeks still has lots of work ahead of them, but I already know from what I've personally seen that they will get it done and do a damn fine job of it at that.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Armello presents a true personal experience each new time it's played. From personal experience I can say each new match is unique - the map has procedural generation (which plays for the reach of resources such as settlements to conquer and dungeons to loot), the player starts each new match with random cards in hand, and this adds to the opponents being placed in different base camp locations (for example, if opponent A was placed on northern base camp in a match, there is a chance you can find it placed on the eastern or western base camp on a next match) plus the strategy you're thinking about running.

As the game truly is a legitimate digital board game, there is the possibility a player's strategy may be entirely destroyed in only a single turn, or it can turn on this player's favor as well - and this is the true beauty of Armello. The playing of cards - at any time - adds an interesting dynamic to the experience, not to mention the rot, the quests mechanic, the rings and amulets chosen before the match that help the player on his/her strategy and more elements to list.

Additionally, the environment, the lore, the graphic design (character's and even the cards' illustrations), the sound effects of this game, they're all great.

As a more personal note, I'm reading the Redwall series and, as in my opinion making a proper Redwall game wouldn't have a good result, I must say that when I want to effectively play" Redwall
date: I go play Armello. This is really an amazing experience."

reviewText:
After being in both the early access and experiencing the first week of the ful release, I like to think I understand Armello a bit. It is fun, but feel somewhat poorly tuned. Lets start with the bad:

- There are four victory methods, but one seems entirely based on luck (Spirit Stones) and the other feels as if you are attempting to push a boulder up a mountain with a toothpick (Rot).

reviewText:
I am somewhat getting addicted to this game slowly. Out of all of the games i own, Armello is the only other game besides the Fallout series to get me to go in depth into it. The concept is very great, simple to grasp gameplay (learn how to play in roughly 5-20 mins) is awesome, every game you play is totally different than the one your friend will play. The list goes on for this game, but just like a lot of games they do have some drawbacks. For example there is no custom characters for yourself, though it be great to see it in the future to have a custom character that you can make (only one) and see him/her progress in the game.

Though the only other thing that i see as another downside is the map size. The map size never changes, it is great that it is like smallworld where the tiles changes every game, but there should be at least one or two different map sizes other than one. Because game map size is somewhat small for me, and at least they should offer a bigger mapsize too for people, like me, who like extra long games.

Thanks for reading my review, though all my reviews are not as detailed and pretty as some, i do try to give you all my own thoughts of the game to help your decision to buy a game or not. This game gets a 9/10 in my book, and i do highly recommend this game to anyone who like GOT (game of thrones), Table Top Games like Small world, or anything that is RPG related. To devlopers of this game, you guys did a very good job with this game and for that i am glad to play Armello.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(This was written while the game was still in Early Access)

Armello is a board-game RPG type of game with beautiful graphics, awesome mechanics and proper diversity: this is a game that really feels completely different every time you play it. Though some cards may appear more frequently, I've really had to adapt a different strategy every game I've played.

This is also because of one of the best parts of Armello: the victory conditions. There are 4 different ways to beat the game, and the four conditions are able to be reached by anyone in the game, provided they plan for them. This helps keep the game interesting for everyone: it's hard to have a completely hopeless game, you can always try to fulfill one of the different conditions, regardless of the other player's status.

The game takes a little to learn and understand, and (at the moment) some tooltips aren't always easily readable, but it isn't a particularly hard game to learn.

There is ONE big problem with the game at the moment: lack of local multiplayer. This is a boardgame kind of game and the lack of local multiplayer is a big oversight. The developers have said they may add it in the future, but at the current moment it is sorely lacking it. Keep this in mind, because this lacking feature and the somewhat high price tag compared to other board-games, makes it hard to fully recommend.

If you consider buying it, watch some gameplay videos first. Then, think about how you would want to play the game more: Do I like playing these games online with strangers? Can I wait for a local co-op that may not come? Do I have friends that play online and are willing to buy their own copy for $25?

Armello is an amazing game and should be given a try, but at the moment the multiplayer options have a few bothersome conditions.

reviewText:
Pros:
* Amazing visual style. Pretty much the strongest point of the game.
* Simple enough combat system
* Fairly good tutorial

Cons:
* Balance. Attack/defense balance is cranked all the way towards the former, which means that even if you can kill your opponent thrice over, they are likely to kill you too, throwing you back to square one.
* Way too much is left to chance. If RNG hates you, you can't do anything about it.
* Matches are too short - 20 turns, 24 at custom rules, and any attack that wounds the King cuts that further down.
* Next to no settings, specifically graphics, language (it always takes the setting from steam), ans such.

Overall, the game has great potential but it needs fixing. Right now it has little to boast aside from the good looks.

reviewText:
Frustration simulator 2015.

A beautifully designed and drawn bcomputer board game. Entirely charming, addictive, easily played through fairly quickly per session.

But Oh My God. It's so frustrating. It seems like every die roll is stacked heavily against you.

Need some money? Well explore a dungeon! From the icon wheel that spins up when you do, it appears more likely that you'll get a coin result, but no. Four dungeons in a row you'll spawn a bane. Not just that but despit there appearing to be only one bane icon on the wheel, you'll tick past it only to stop on another striaght afterwards.

Got 7 fight dice and great gear? Think you can beat that other character who has 4 fight dice and poor gear? You'd think so, but no, you wont. In fact you'll roll worse than him for all three actions of your turn and get the snot kicked out of you.

Got a handful of cards and want to deal with that peril? No I'm sorry, all the icons will be mismatches for your cards and you'll fail all the die rolls you couldn't cover with your cards.

Oh and do you have a quest with a 70% success chance? Well you'll succeed... As long as the reward isn't an item that you really want, because if so, your success chance is actually 0%.

I really don't know how they have coded chance into this game, but failure at almost everything is the norm.

I keep playing it, so I really have to recommend, but for the love of god, if you don't deal well with frustration, if you are prone to mouse or keyboard beating... Perhaps choose another game.

Every match can be played in a completely different way, with hundreds of cards, items, and followers to mix it up. reviewText: Beautiful animations, beautiful artwork, hypnotically immersive soundtrack, fluid game mechanics and overall gameplay that just oozes originality while also being ridiculously fun to boot. Armello is a turn-based RPG/Strategy Card game which is honestly more of a Virtual Board game than anything else. You pick a Hero, each possessing their own strengths/stats/abilities and proceed to compete against 3 other players while trying to win the game through 4 different methods (kill the king, gather 4 stones and confront the king etc etc). All the while, you have random events, dictations from the King (player-chosen events), and even an evil race of monsters (called Banes) that are trying to kill everything and everyone. Sometimes you will work together with other players but it's important to remember there can only be one winner, so backstabbing is friendship killing levels in this game. Final opinion? This game is a hell of a lot of fun and I highly recommend it even if it's just for the Aesthetic alone... Now excuse me, I'm going to go maul a few animals with my Spirit Bear.\nGameplay and Review:\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2qJlYJLmeQg

reviewText:
Great artwork but a disappointing board game.
Armello has some similarities to Talisman, in that a way to win is in the middle of the board, but you need to improve your character's stats and gather useful equipment before you have any chance at it.

However, killing or curing the king hardly ever happens as you have to be incredibly lucky for either to be feasible, so pretty much every time the game will run out of turns and the player who happens to have the highest prestige wins.

Winning or losing is almost entirely based on luck. Meaningful decisions don't really come up, each player will tend to do their own thing, clicking on the next 'quest' and hoping to randomly have the most prestige when the game ends.

Quests and encounters consist of a random die roll. Most of your time is spent waiting for the other players to take their turns, more so even than most other board games thanks to all of the neutral units taking their turns.

In general it is just rather shallow, dull and repetitive.

I love board games but there are many other board games, both physical and digital, that are better and cheaper than this one.

However the 2D artwork is gorgeous and the in-game graphics and animations are nice.

reviewText:
I really want to love this game. I got it in early access, and awaited eagerly as more elements were added. It has many elements that appeal to me. A tabletop feel, fantasy world, anthropomorphic characters. Throw in gorgeous graphics, especially on the animated cards, and a great soundtrack, and surely we're onto a winner.

Sadly, I have to say the full release has disappointed me. The game just feels empty. But unlike many early access games, which end up as buggy unfinished excuses to take your money off you, Armello feels like it had a lot of love and effort put into it, which makes what we are left with a let down indeed.

There are four ways to win in Armello, and only two of them seem worth pursuing unless you like a self imposed challenge. The 'prestige' and 'spirit stone' victories are fairly straightforward, but the 'kill the king' victory is an exercise in masochism, fail at it (which you will most likely, as the king is an absolute beast of a fighter) and you'll be too far behind to try for the other methods. The 'rot' victory is identical to the 'kill the king' victory, except you have to punish yourself even more to get it.

You can play many cards during an opponent's turn, but good luck finding them: the mouse scrolling gets stuck very easily, and if you zoom out to see the whole map, an inexplicable layer of cloud obscures the whole map! Compare this to a true tabletop card game, where you can play cards against your opponent sitting round a table. Imagine if you had to get out of your chair, chase them around and physically hit them with it before they played their hand. In Armello Seeing as you don't know a card has been played until it's effect kicks in, there is very little one can do to protect against it. Most of the time, you will never have enough resources to ever use that card that's been in your hand for the past 2 turns.

Once you've won a few games, repeat plays become a chore as you watch your 3 opponents slowly take their turns, then watch the king's guard take their turns, THEN watch the banes take theirs. Games become incredibly drawn out for all the wrong reasons. I think the developers could have added more settings to change gameplay rules, define what type of victory conditions are active and so on, give the player some customisation options to add longevity. Currently the only reason to replay is to unlock the many beautiful cards.

The game is beautiful, and fun for a little while. It's just a shame it leaves you wanting more so badly.

reviewText:
First off, it's totally bootyful. The art, animation, presentation, music, all of it, awesome.

The game is super easy to pick up and play, and it isn't all too deep. Matches last for 45 mins, maybe an hour, and each one can play out differently, with different win conditions that are better suited for different characters. A few account-level unlocks, but nothing too skewed toward power. So there's a fair bit of replay, but it's not infinite.

No local multiplayer, currently, but there is online. Single player probably won't keep you occupied for too long, and it is rather easy (difficulty levels would be much welcome) but multiplayer has some potential, especially when ranked play comes with a later patch. Still, grab three friends, sit around without pants on, make a drinking game out of getting rot, and you're probably have yourself a good time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's hard to describe a game like Armello.

At it's core it's a board game, but it's so much more than that. It's also a turn based strategy game, it's a card game, and it even has some RPG elements. More importantly, all these elements work well together.

There's currently 4 characters to choose from (in Early access, there will be more at full release), each of which belongs to their own clan, and each character has their own stats, abilities and starting items. They are all different enough that each game feels fresh.

When you first play Armello it might seem a bit complicated, but once you've played a match or two, you will know exactly what you're doing.

Even though the game is currently in Early Access it's fully playable.
voteText: 20 of 25 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Honor and courage. Trickery and deceit. Adventure and quests. Armello is a multiplayer strategy game that embraces several different styles of play and has a colorful cast of characters to choose from. With four different paths to victory, every game is challenging and requires you to pay close attention to your enemies each turn, and each game will be different. When I first read about the game, I thought it would be fun and interesting, but I didn't expect it to be so addictive! Reminds me a bit of Game of Thrones, but with anthropomorphised animals instead of Sean Bean. Whether you want to play versus the AI or with friends, Armello is worth the $20, and the community is friendly and helpful. I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys strategy board games. A+, 10/10.

reviewText:
A 4 player fantasy regicide board game.

Update v1.0 is a massive improvement on the beta build.

All the cards have been animated, annotated and even have sound effects. The card book got the same treatment, it also now highlights new cards so you can easily view them.

The world map now has much higher level of graphical detail with each clan getting its own unique starting location and rotten ruins reciving a sinister purple glow during night turns

As for the new heroes, the wolf ranger arrow offers safe first strike
Rabbit tinker can swap items cheaply allowing you to rapidly shift tactics as the turns unfolds.
Ninja rat is fragile but gains ambush advantage at night

But the second magic bear...wow.

He channels magic into smash-gic, every magic card used ups his attack. This synergises outrageously well with his clan signets and any spirit treasures/followers you pickup along the way.

The devs will respond to any bugs you report with the bug report tool ingame or on their forums and are a friendly bunch.

Games only last 18turns at the moment but id expect options for custom rules in a future build.

If you like board games and fancy something new, give this a shot.

It contains magic bears.

reviewText:
WHY DO I RECOMMEND IT?I recommend it based on principle:
Hard-working, focused developer;
Beautiful game with high production values;
Solid board game experience on the Internet.
IF I DID NOT, WHY WOULD I NOT RECOMMEND IT?I would not recommend it to other players with very specific tastes in game style:
Finicky multiplayer;
Long, slow matches that could get boring to wait through if you're not playing/hanging out with friends;
A little bit on the expensive side for an indie game.
SHOULD YOU/OTHER PEOPLE BUY IT?It depends on your answer to the following questions:
Do you like animal characters?
Do you like board games?
Do you have friends to play it with?
Do you believe in principles above entertainment?
If you answered YES to 2 or more questions above, I'd strongly recommend it to you. This game is a strong statement of shrewd, devoted developers and a sincere passion for their work. This, however, comes at the expense of being a game with limited audience, especially since animal characters tend to give the impression of a game aimed at children, plus a lot of people keep saying they'd prefer this to be a real" board game

reviewText:
Take the giant creatures from Black & White, the cards from Hearthstone, throw in some hexes with terrain from Civilization, some of the gameplay from Talisman, and the hellish RNG from Blood Bowl, and you have Armello.

While it looks lovely, don't let its looks fool you, underneath that beauty is a twisted evil (the other players), just when you think victory is within your grasp everything changes.

With several ways to win you can't simply focus on one thing and assume you have victory in the bag. And if it's all going horribly wrong, you there are ways for those who are falling behind to try to snatch victory from the jaws of defeat.

Cunning, and beautiful, worth every cent.

Playing Armello is the a new great way to make your friends hate you, its like Mario Party, but for PC. In this game you pick a character, right now there is 4 different, and you should always pick Thane. Then you proceed to find the best bling between rings and amulets. When all that is done, then you go around as a greatsword-wielding wolf and beat the sh*t out of magical birds of evil, and you friend that decided that a cute little bunny was the best character ever. After having played around for a bit, you will find yourself at a fight with the mighty king. Or once mighty, because he has grown weaker over time, and since you are pure, then his rot means nothing. In the end you claim victory, and even tho you failed on most of your quest, you find out that the sword is mightier than the pen, and you got the biggest sword in Armello.

10/10

Cant wait for new characters to rival Thane's unmatched strength, so my friends might want to play with me again

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off, I'm quite pleased for a game that breaks the archtypes of animals, meaning that a rat isn't necessarily a bad or evil character. Really, it seems that YOU are the one who determines the alignment of four characters, a Thane (wolf), Sana (bear), Amber (rabbit), and Mercurio (rat). Each character is trying to become the next lord of Armello, and it can be done with intrigue, murder, or muscle.

The game is a card/board/dice game so each play is different. Cards can be used to make your ascension easier, or more difficult on your rivals. And all the while Banes, something like a corruption elemental, are spawning and wreaking havoc on the land while dungeons are ripe for exploration. Declarations can be used to make thing easier on you, harder on others, or just a touch of randomness when nothing else is beneficial.

This is one of the most unique games I have played and I enjoyed it, it's easy ot learn and isn't a game that is all to lengthy in play. You can play alone with computer players, or you can get some friends together and compete for the throne in multiplayer.

reviewText: I backed this game's Kickstater from day one at the Bandit Tier. I even bought a copy for my wife, and a copy for my PS4.  As an avid fan of board games, video games, the world of Don Bluth, Disney, and Brian Jaques Redwall book series, I couldn't help but believe in it. I was not disappointed. It's a true marvel among games of it's type. Not only is it fun, but it's challenging too. Plus it takes a bit to master, but I assure you all of that goes out the window once you gather three of your friends to play the game. The art is rich with detail and warmth. So much charcter place in the little sprits. The abilities and cards are well thought out and give the game new dimensions. My only Con and it's such a small one is that they should add a chat box players can type what they want to the other players, even add a whisper function to allow strategic attack and defense. In the mean time, just load up Skype and talk to your friends through that while enjoying the game. League of Geeks did a great job with this one, I look forward to other ventures they have, whether it's in Armello or beyond.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been following this game's production for well over a year. Aside from the fact that I've wanted to do voice acting work in this game since the moment I saw it, the art style appealed to me greatly. Over the last year, as more and more assets have gone public (most notably the animated card art), my excitement for this title has only increased.

There is also the fact that the dev team pays extreme attention to the community members playing this game in early access; often playing against various members in weekly livestreams. They maintain an open dialog with the community and take our desires and interests to heart when bringing this world to life.

The singleplayer campaign has, thus far, been incredibly engaging. I find myself compelled to continue playing even when things have not been going my way and I'm getting frustrated. There is always something which makes me want to keep going.

Okay...I need to get to sleep. I've got work in a few hours. Buuuuuut.......maybe just one more game.""

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game has the essence of what I love from a good game of Civilization V with friends all boiled into an experience that is far less time consuming! The artwork is great, the soundtrack is immersive, and the gameplay always stays fresh! Although some may criticize the amount of chance in the game, a good player will know how to play circumstances to their favor. My favorite part of this game is that no game is ever set in stone. One player may be winning at first, but if they aren't careful another player can easily sweep in and steal their victory! When you are not playing with friends the game still allows you to play with bots that allow for a good challenge and a fun time, though, the game really does shine with friends where the amount of animosity it can create is glorious. I heartily recommend this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is definitely one of the best games, I've been playing, recently.

The game is easy to learn, and it's perfect for casual-gamers, as well as for people who like to spend weeks, playing one game and getting better, than anybody else!

I've played a few other Early-Access games, but none of them was this balanced. Most of them were quite unfinished, but this game can be played for hours and you probably won't come across any bugs or stuff that doesn't work, yet.

Over the last two days, I've played the game for almost ten hours and I quite enjoyed it. The only thing I don't like, about this game, is a detail in the multiplayer matches... When somebody disconnects from the game, the whole match will be ended, immediately. I've played a few multiplayer matches, but I've never finished any of those... this should definitely be changed, soon (maybe they'd turn the disconnected player into an AI), but it's just a small point.

If you're searching for a fun new strategy game, you'd definitely get Armello!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wow!
What can I say about this game that hasn't already been said? As a huge fan of real-life boardgames, there is often a bit lost in transition between the tabletop and the digital realm. Rarely has a game of Settlers of Catan or Magic the Gathering felt nearly as compelling online as it has in person.

However, Armello seems to meld just perfectly the best aspects of both real-world boardgaming and videogaming. The card art is gorgeous (and wonderfully animated), as is the world and the lore that is set up. Each character is unique, while still remaining viable and seemingly balanced. With four different possible paths to victory, players must adapt quickly and cobble together a winning strategy from whatever comes their way.

It must be said that no game has ever had the level of collaboration between developer and player that Armello has. As a successful Kickstarter, the game has grown past anyone's expectations thanks to the free exchange of ideas from the community. I can only hope that Armello, and the League of Geeks team, serve as models for what future videogames can accomplish!

reviewText:
The TL;DR version: It's Redwall Mixed with Game of Thrones in electronic boardgame format and is exactly as awesome as that sounds. Buy it!


The Proper version:

Armello is a strategy game that blends both strategic, tactical and luck based mechanics into a very well-polished package. Your typical game lasts about an hour (Longer for Multiplayer) and has you in a race for the crown. During each game you compete with both your opponents and AI controlled entites like Banes and Castle Guards to progress to one of four victory types.

The variety of characters (8 in total as of launch) ...each with their own unique starting stats and special abilities and the variety of victory types (4 in total) means that every game plays out differently, especially since the map is randomly generated every game. Even when playing the same character, you might find that the terrain and early game events might make one type of victory better than another.

The main victory in the game is a Prestige victory. This follows your standard victory point progression like other board games. The other three victory types are ways for players who are behind to Steal" the win from the prestige leader. This is good as even if you fall WAY behind
date: you are still able to claim victory
recommended: yet it isn't unfair to the prestige leader as the prestige victory is the lowest-risk victory
hoursPlayed: and players trying to 'steal' it from you must take a riskier and more difficult path. It also means that a game isn't won or lost until the final turn
voteText: so every player is still engaged even if someone takes a very early prestige lead.\n\nThe Single Player AI is competent

reviewText:
Armello is a board game... of sorts.
You play as heroes of 4 animal clans who fight to save their kingdom, or to destroy it. That is entirely up to you, the player. You have a choice of 8 characters (currectly, more are being added!). Each clan is represented by 2 heroes. They have a variety or special abilities which make them unique, and you need to adapt to their playstyle to win. Some character might be too weak but strong in battle, yet other might lack in battle but win with magic and amounts of health.
But as I said, Armello is a board game! It is not the best, but not the worst either. It has its flaws. For example the game relies too much on RNG. Which means you might get really good drop and on the other hand you will do so miserably and ask yourself: why? The gaming board represents the kingdom or Armello, its procedurally generated, so the game will always be different, although the shape of the board stays the same. The board is filled with villages, dungeons, enemy mobs, forests and mountains, and also with traps.
The goal of the game is to defeat the king, who has been taken by a Rot. (Rot is a special condition in a game that drains 1 health every 2 turns) The king is slowly loosing his health. You have many options how to win. Be a fighter, a diplomat, the one who purges the darkness away from the king or a corrupted hero who decides to rule with even darker hand than the king himself.
You can play alone with AI controlled players, join up online with friends or online against random players to have a chance to drop some sweet loot that can be sold on Steam market (really, free, no microtransactions!), or be kept for you to admire. (Seriously, a dice that sparkles... count me in!)

Although the game is really clinging on randomness and it sometimes feels like its more based on luck than actual skill (which might and might not be true. If you are really lucky you can win, but if you think about your moves, you can win just as much) its very fun, matches might take over 60 minutes sometimes, but with its randomly generated maps the games are never the same.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

All of you PC board games and ports out there, take notes. This is how it's done.

Although it's in early access, which does show a little bit in some small areas, Armello is already mind bogglingly better than the VAST majority of PC tabletop-style games out there. It plays great, it looks great, it sounds great, and it FEELS great.

The amazing music, gorgeous art, and the non-childish lore give the game a phenomenal atmosphere. The gameplay is simple enough, yet offers so many possibilities that it will take a looong time before two matches feel too similar. The developers listen and the kickstarter community is friendly to boot. I can honestly say, i am having a hard time finding things to complain about. What few issues i've come across, they've been ironing out with steady updates.

I may be a little biased, being an avid tabletop and PC gamer, as well as Armello's theme being right up my alley. But this game feels built from passion, which is extremely rare to come by nowadays. For that alone, i would recommend it.

reviewText:
Armello is a computer boardgame set in a fantasy kingdom of Armello, a world filled with antropomorphic animals of various kinds. Rot has corrupted the good king of the land, making him erratic and mad. This of course will not do and the clans of the kingdom set out to solve the problem, some of them harboring a solution more sinister than the other. It falls to the player's clan to either cure, kill or replace the king by being the hero of the people.

The game starts by the players picking their characters from a bunch of eight different heroes belonging into four different clans as well as the starting trinkets which the player can use to get and advantage in a specific situation on board and a statboost of their favourite stat. The board is then randomly generated with the King's palace in the middle. The map is made of a bunch of different tiles such as high mountains, dangerous swamps, periless dungeons, busy villages, lush forests etc. etc. Almost every tile has a special purpose, giving the player either a defence boost, health refill, invisibility, wound or something else. For example Dungeons give various rewards from money to magical items and Villages pile the heroe's purse with shiny, clinky, coin at dawn. The tiles can be further changed by various cards and events.

The goal of the game is to either kill the mad king and take his place. Cure the king with four magical stones or wait till the king dies by succumbing to the rot (or being slain by another hero with both the king and the hero dying) and claiming the throne as a prestigeful hero of the good people of Armello. By completing quests each hero increases their attributes and prestige.

The player heroes all have a handful of cards they can play any time they want. Even when it's not the player's turn to act provided the player hero has the money or magic and the proper conditions to use the card. These item cards range from beneficial items to magic to shady deals to spring traps and other evil things upon the unlucky contestants.

Attributes include Fight which determines how good your hero is in combat, Body that servers as your hero's hitpoints and health, Wits which lets you draw more cards to play later and Spirit which measures your magical prowess. Each of these stats are used in either combat, questing or when facing a peril. Naturally the higher the attribute the more chances your hero has winning the encounter.

Secondary attributes are Gold which is used to play various types of cards to enhance your own hero or make the life of other heroes more difficult. Magic which is the fuel for using magic cards for the same purposes as above. Prestige which helps you winning the game and Rot which... measures how much you rely on the dark evil. Prestige and Rot both require some attention here.

Prestige measures how famous your hero is. Having the highest prestige at dawn has the benefit of letting your hero give the mad lion king advice on which of the two new rules he's going to enforce for the coming day. This can be used to make the life more difficult for the other heroes but the choises aren't always beneficial for the prestige leader. When the king dies, either by succumbing to the rot or when killed by another hero unsuccesfully, the player whose hero has the highest prestige wins the game. Players can also lose prestige by killing the royal guard or by dying. Some events, such as certain quests when failed, also drain prestige. Player can increase their hero's prestige by killing opposing heroes the evil banes and by completing quests.

Rot is the dark influence heroes gain by dabbling into evil magic or being corrupted by rotten creatures. Having rot can make your hero stronger, but it comes at a cost. Each dawn a corrupted hero takes damage and if your hero is very badly corrupted, the normally beneficial healing shrines will kill the hero instantly. Having rot makes your hero more potent in combat, but only if you fight against other corrupted creatures. If the hero's rot value is bigger than the opponents, the player may add the opponents rot in dice to their dice pool during combat. Also each time a rot corrupted character slays somebody they refil their health by one point and is not hunted by banes. Having rot is a very aggressive strategy towards winning the game.

When a fight breaks out the player gets to roll their Fight dice. There are several items and abilities such as shields, armor, weapons and magic which add or reduces from your or your opponents dice pool. Players try to roll as many hits as they can as well as blocks to negate enemy hits. Fights can end in a several ways but dying doesn't punish the player too much. The defeated hero will respawn in their clan's starting ground and is back in the game as soon as the player's turn is up. The player can also burn the cards in their hand to get a guaranteed result on a single die.

The game has one nasty flaw though, if you can even count it as a flaw. The game is very random. By having a poor luck with the tiles near your starting zone or a bad starting hand of cards you may find your hero's chances of winning being very low from the get go. Bad card draws and unforgiving dice can also completely ruin your game, but that's given, considering the game is closer to a board game than a what you normally have on a computer. But besides that I find the game very enjoyable. The presentation is great. The game has some really fine artistic style, fitting music and it's just a joy to play. It's a bit boring alone, but with friends the game really shines. Armello is not for everyone but I believe anybody who's into board games will probably enjoy this one immensively.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My review for Armello as posted on: http://www.grabthegames.com/preview-armello.html

A digital board game like no other, it really feels like Game of Thrones but with animals.  The first aspect that I loved about this game is that is not a simple board game but it has a solid and interesting story that makes the game experience even better! Moreover, the game features beautiful graphics and a really captivating soundtrack and in game music as well. The game is also fast with a high replay value. The day and night cycle is a great addition to the game with both of these cycles affecting the game play. Everything is also so beautiful in this game from the animated cards that will be more than 100 in the game to the captivating board of the title. Furthermore, the game has a lot of heroes to choose from that each one represent a different clan. Each clan representative has different set of skills, advantages and weaknesses with more to come when the final version of the game will be out. The heroes are also highly customizable with rings and amulets with impressive attribute. The title also features a dynamic sandbox. This means that every game you play will not be the game as the previous one because the maps and the quests are randomly generated. However, there are some negative aspects that I should mention. The biggest one for me is it lacks a good tutorial; I found it hard to get used to the title but after two or three games you will be able to learn it easily.  To sum up, if you love gorgeous games and tabletop title this is the game you must pick up without second thought. Totally recommend it despite the negative aspect. It has a great feature and more content will be implemented in the near feature.

Verdict: 8.5/10

+graphics
+customization
+sandbox aspect
+day and night cycle
+100+ animated cards

-desperately needs a better tutorial

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The only strategic game I play on steam. As a Kickstarter backer, my opinion is somewhat beholden to the money I've given to the project. That being said, Armello had one of the fastest Kickstarter turnaround times I've ever seen. The proof is in the pudding: Armello is one of the most beautiful games available on Steam, with a strong sense of artistic self. Its parts create an ideal whole.

With over 100 cards and a total of 12 playable heroes (4 during the Beta, at least 4 more at launch Sept. 1st 2015, plus 4 additional ones for backers and eventually, late adopters) there is enough variety to keep you coming back for more, to see how each game plays out. Randomized gameboards and multiplayer support only further this. The additions of quests and storyline are icing on the cake, and I expect the full release to be even richer in terms of how the story is told. I've taken to playing the game just to unwind; the mix of beautiful art and serene, appropriate music is enough to please the senses for every moment you play.

In short, you owe it to yourself to experience the world of Armello, which in itself is so compelling that even without the exemplary game system it would serve as the basis for a series of best-selling fiction.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a great game--a combination of a traditional tabletop and board game, but two things that are crippling the game, or at the very least, are proving to be worrisome, are online play and DLC.

Currently, if one person even remotely disconnects during the game, it completely ends the match and returns you to the Menu Screen.   On several occasions, I played game nearly to their completion, only to have a player, whether intentional or not, disconnect, completely ruining the match and wasting whatever time you devoted.  Something as simple as a screen for the remaining players to decide whether to wait or continue with an AI would have sufficed, but as it is, there's nothing more furstrating than to figuratively have a player throw the game and table.

Second, between their Kickstarter page and their Wiki, there are currently 4 playable characters with 8 additional characters being released as DLC--four of which are slated to be paid DLC, and other four only available if you donated at least $45/$55 to their Kickstarter.  While I can appreciate something being special or exclusive, for what is supposed to be a casual stategy game, I can't help but feel a bit sleighted of being denied content simply because I happen to be late to the party or don't have a fat wallet.  Maybe if it was one or two characters, or even vanity items, but to devote a whole faction--literally a third of the currently planned playable characters, with a time and money requirement, I can't help but feel this game is pay-to-win even before leaving the gates.

reviewText: Oh, Armello!  Shall I compare thee to a summer's night of Munchkin?  No?  Risk, maybe?  Dungeons and Dragons?  Alright, perhaps that's pushing it too far.  It is an excellent party game for up to four friends online and with a somber atmosphere and interesting level of lore and immersion.  Even if you're on the losing side, every game feels fun and compelling--the tables are always ready to turn and even in the face of utter hopelessness, you can always take on the role of a vicious saboteur.  Some will say it is too dependent on chance, but I would argue otherwise.  It is a game about choosing a path and then leveraging your odds.  Every move matters and it's possible to turn even a game fraught with terrible luck into a last-minute victory.  Game length varies a bit; single player games last me around an hour, but it's about twice that with friends.\n\nThe King is corrupt and marching toward his death.  Take on the role of one of several heroes representing the clans of the kingdom, each with their own unique traits, tricks, and motivations for claiming his throne.  Will you play the pacifist and build rapport within the kingdom, elected to power when he inevitably succumbs to his sickness?  You could fight your way through the competition with guile and brawn to slay the monarch yourself, taking the castle by force, or perhaps the Rot has found a more powerful host in you and he is but your final meal before your dark ascension.  With so many paths to victory and the freedom to devise your own strategy, you're guaranteed to find plenty to explore within the world of Armello--especially when you adventure with friends.

reviewText:
If you love those interesting tabletop board games, then you'll enjoy this game.
Armello is an original digital media IP that has everything you'd expect from physical board games!

Bottom line: Do I enjoy this game? Do I think its mechanics work well?
Yes.
I've played all 4 of the prologue (tutorial) chapters, and also played 4 regular games. I enjoyed playing, and each game was a bit different since the map is semi randomized, each character has different strengths, there's various quests to choose from when you start or complete a quest, and there's several different win conditions.

The art in the game for the cards is very cool. Each of the cards has some little bit of animation like blinking/shifting eyes, or a forest whooshing by as a person runs through it, or a bit smoke moving. The art style of this game is wonderfull, but you can see that in the screenshots.

The rules/mechanics:
It has its own 6 sided die with symbols instead of numbers.
It has 8 different characters, each with a unique special passive ability and slightly different stats. This means each character will play a bit different as one might be better at battle, but another might be able to cast more spellcards or more expensive spells.

Each character has 4 main stats:
Fight- Determines # of die you roll during battle.
Body- Essentially is your max HP
Wits- Determines # of die you roll during Perils, a negative event card played on a space you entered. It also determines your maximum card hand size. You draw to this amount each turn.
Spirit- Essentially your max MP, you restore to this number each night
All 4 of these are also used in quest challenges where 1 stat point x10 = % chance to succeed.

You also gain/lose Gold used in equipping Item cards / hiring (equipping) follower cards or playing Trickery cards
There's Prestige that you gain/lose through certain actions like completing a quest, and some few Trickery cards will cost Prestige instead of Gold. There's a thing that is basically your current MP for the day. Finally there's Rot. If you are infected by this, you lose 1 HP per day and there's other mechanics surrounding this. The king is infected by this setting the turn limit for the game.

There's a card system as mentioned as well. There's Items (including equip-ables, one use, and followers), Spells which can be buffs / debuffs/ or even direct damage to other characters, and Trickery (You triggered my trap card, Yugi! Sorry I'm unoriginal). Trickery cards most of the time are played as traps that can be set on certain tiles and when anyone enters that marked space they must pass a challenge by rolling the # of die equal to their Wits.

There's a bit more to the game but that's basically it.
The king is dying and mad (crazy/evil) due to Rot infection. You must have the highest Prestige when he dies to win, or you can kill him yourself and become King/Queen, or you can gather 4 sacred stones and attempt to cure the king and the land of Rot.

reviewText:
This game deserves more attention from it's developers as the universe they created with this small game contains a lot of character. It's a fun universe to discover.

After my 30'th hour playing I still have more unlockable to achieve however I wish I could unlock more, including Skins / Characters / Cards and more.

The staleness of the game comes from the small maps and single game mode with single player and multiplayer options, leaving the desire for DLC game modes such as: Story Mode, Adventure, or even a co-op.

The Decks used in the game seem shuffled in the beginning however because the decks can include a vast varity of cards it makes playing what can loosely be called a 'class' is difficult as there is no ~build a deck~ mode.

I have been unsuccessful with contacting the developers directly in regards of the direction of the game or to leave feedback. I find this not normal for an indie developer.

Lastly performance: I play on an i5-4300 machine (Surface pro 3 - 4 gb ram)
The game is playable, manageable via touch inputs.
The performance is not, feeling always at a low 20's in fps on low setting at any resolution it feels like there is a lot of un-optimized code. Testing this game on my Desktop rig caused the temp’s to climb to the high 60’s in a machine that can render starcitizen in the high 50’s.
Overall 8/10

reviewText:
Armello did something for me that no other game has been able to do effectively. It made tabletop strategy seem accessible and fun for me.

The tutorial does its job well. The way it presents the various gameplay concepts, staggered through different characters to show different approaches to the game, really helped make the ideas stick. While Armello has some fairly complex aspects to it, I was never left feeling intimidated as I often am by other games in this genre.

The art style is gorgeous and I feel this is one of the most beautiful games I've played in a long time. Despite basically being pawns on a board, each hero has its own distinct personality, which I personally find necessary for a game to be engaging and to have any longevity.

Though I'm only a few games in and can't comment on it at length, I do like the inclusion of a progression system. Being able to unlock items for my characters that allow me to alter their play style gives me more incentive to keep coming back.

The pace of the game can be a bit slow at times, since you not only have to wait for other players' turns but also the king's guards as well as any banes that have emerged on the map, but I feel that's really a minor issue.

Overall, I'm really happy with Armello so far and look forward to trying out the upcoming multiplayer ladder.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Armello is a game that you can see the roots and passion for boardgames shine through. From the character traits to the perils you locate as you wander the 'board' you can feel the designers admiration and devotion to the tabletop genre.

The art is beautiful. The trees manage to bring forth the feeling of dark and deep adventure, the dungeons do the same. Honestly the amount of atmosphere created from such little space is truly extravagant.  The attention to the detail is something you'll be noticing with each game you play.

The only major drawback is that is falls short of enjoyment when wanting to play with strangers via the public games. There are very few people queued up to play and when you do play there is no way to communicate to each other. This means that the hilarity and competitive fun that you get when playing with friends is lost.

If you are looking for a game that blends the polish of many modern day games and the mechanics of old style tabletop boardgames where the dice play a huge part but your strategy and wits is what truly separates you from your competitors then I'd recommend Armello 9 times out of 10.

I would suggest inviting a few friends along for the fun though!
