reviewText:
This review was written on the day of the 1.3 patch

So I've had armello for a while, and not really played it much, and there's a pretty good reason for that.
Until patch 1.3, there was no real random lobby presence for multiplayer matches. With 1.3, you now get chests and keys to unlock... *drum roll* dice skins.
It's a little lackluster, but hey, some people are into it.

For the game it'self, it's a fun boardgame. The art design and style in general is amazing, the rules are pretty solid (if still being tweaked) and games tend to last 30 mins to an hour, which is pretty solid.

If you're thinking of buying it my advice would be to try and grab it on sale. Sorry LoG, but it's true.
This game is Ok on single player.
Pretty good on multiplayer (now wait times are down)
and I hear it's great if you have enough friends for a full game (R.I.P. the 4 pack T_T)

If you're still on the fence, LoG has been teasing more characters, and eventually iOS support along with even MORE characters (woo, bandit clan), so maybe wait for that.

But yeah, if you're into stuff like Talisman, but want a shorter game, pick up this cross between Wind in the Willows and Game of Thrones.
If you're more into Gears of war... what are you even doing here reading this? shoo!

reviewText:
I first noticed this game when it was up for a possible free PS+ game a number of months ago.  I voted for it without hesitation and have been telling myself to buck up and buy it ever since it didn't get the votes needed.    After purchasing the game and spending a few hours in it, I realized that I probably didn't know what everyone else knew when they didn't vote for it.

I want to talk about the positives first.

PROS:
-Great graphical style.  This game really is beautiful in an indie game sort of way.
-Brilliant setting.  I was immediately immersed in the setting and the world.  A pretty substantial feat for such a small game, with such little information.  I found myself wanting more and more setting and story information.
-A unique take on the classic Talisman" boardgame.
-Variety of intriguing characters to play.
-Variety of unlocks and gear to modify your characters

You'll notice that nowhere in the "PROS" section was there anything to do with actual gameplay.  Gameplay is atrocious.  The sheer amount of lack of control you have is absurd.  You will spend the majority of the game just watching random terrible things happen to your character
date: that you have no control over
recommended: which can very easily chain react and spiral out of control.  The game also punishes you at every opportunity.  You get to draw cards at the beginning of your turns
hoursPlayed: up to a hand limit
voteText: but most of the time those cards are useless for both their icons and abilities.  You are also not able to simply discard cards.  You have to either use them or burn them (trading a die roll for a guaranteed result depicted on the card).  Which means that you will end up losing multiple "Perils" or events just to get rid of cards that you don't want
helpfulPercent: hoping to draw new good cards
votesHelpful:
and then invariably drawing more bad cards.  That is just one aspect of the game.  Let's look a possible sequence of events.  And when I say "possible" I mean common.

-King presents two laws for the current leader to choose from (random)
-Draw cards at the beginning of your turn from three different piles
votesTotal:
of which none are useful to equip or burn (random)
-Encounter a Peril in which you roll dice to succeed at (random)
-Fail the Peril because it is a Wits challenge and you are a Fight character and don't roll well enough (random)
-Get warped to the farthest Dungeon away from that Peril
-Encounter the Peril on the Dungeon
votesFunny: in which you roll dice again (random)\n-Fail the peril and suffer the consequences\n-Encounter the Dungeon (which is essentially a die roll where you can get gold
commentsCount: treasure
column16: a spirit stone
column17: magic points
column18: a parasite (that takes control of your character and moves it)
column19: or a "Bane" which is a Rot-stricken enemy.  End up with a Bane
column20: from the die roll (random)\n-Get moved off the dungeon (possibly even further from where you were trying to go)
column21:
because you encountered a Bane.
-Bane attacks you and initiates Combat which is a bunch of dice rolls (random)
-Lose the combat to be killed and warped back to your starting location.

Seven of those steps heavily involve random draws or dice rolls
column22: and that doesn't even include the random Quest attempts
column23:
and those steps that did not involve a random element were simply suffering the consequences of the previous random step.

There are those who will defend this game saying that it is a board game and you can't do a board game without excessive random elements.  That's wholly and completely incorrect.  I am a boardgamer more than a videogamer with an absurd collection.  There are plenty of boardgames that reduce the amount of luck you have to endure in order to increase the amount of strategy you can use.

Instead of dropping money on Armello
column24: go take a handful of dice and throw them around your kitchen table for a while.  You will likely have more fun
column25: have less wasted time and money
column26: and can move onto something better."

reviewText:
I had backed Armello for $150 on kickstarter, and I had been playing it since beta.  I have, on record, 200+ hours meaning I am experienced in Armello (and I have won a fair amount of games.)  I have seen the changes made to Armello as it progressed from beta to early access to full release and now patches.  I had high hopes for Armello in the kickstarter, and I really wanted to enjoy it; but I feel Armello suffers from having too much RNG.   RNG is fine in video games, infact it's what makes a game.  The complaint is the AMOUNT of RNG this game has:  dice, cards, coin flips, percent chances.  It takes out the skill of anything that could be done.  There are some other key elements that also make it an even more unpleasurable experience:

•RNG
-Dice Rolls:  The dice roll chances come out to | 3/6 attack | 1/6 shield | 2/6 miss |  not exactly balanced
-Card Draws:  Adds to the RNG aspect with obtaining random spells/equipment
-Movement:  Dungeons can spawn banes (obstructing your path) or teleport (sets you back further but can help in very few situations)
-Quest Rewards:  Three sets of quest with rewards (spirit stone, random follower, or random treasure,) even a chance to fail the quest depending on your stats
•Community
-Griefing:  Partied up players like to gang up and bully the fourth player (LoG has took initiative to ban these players from what I've heard)
-Quiters:  Some players quit games due to their favorite characters being picked or leave because of unfortunate events in the game
-Aggression:  Uncalled-for aggression from other players, even unprovoked (On other negative reviews there seems to be die-hard fanboys defending the game blindly and aggressively)
-Unfriendly:  Some spiteful players tend to emote laughs and other emotes after being extremely hostile in-game
•Gameplay
-Battle:  Fights tend to end in a stalemate with both players dying due to 3/6 chance of rolling attack (unless luck is involved)
-PvP:  No allegences between players except between friends, everyone stabs you in the back eventually
-Strategy:  There's almost no strategy, everything's situational; and the game's too random for there to be any kind of set strategy (the only strategy is knowledge of cards and what the opponent could have/do)
-Crashes:  There are constant freezes and NMAs which seems to happen more frequently as the game updates
•Design
+Art:  I do love the designs of this game, but really that's the only positive thing I have to say about Armello
○Sound:  Nothing too impressive, but it's not necessarily bad

Even in private full lobby friend match there's no enjoyment to be had.  Everything feels like a matter of chance with no skill required.  There's no rewarding feeling you get when you win a match, because it's all luck-based.  After doing a good amount of private matches, we agreed to either playing a different game or just stopping all together.
Armello has plenty of potential to be a fun game, but with the randomness of everything it just kills any enjoyment.  Winning sessions comes down to luck (almost every game ends with being really lucky, or really unlucky.)  Armello could be more of a strategic game if the random elements were toned down.  For now, this will be a negative review, unless several mechanics of the game are revised.

reviewText:
UPDATE:

11/18 -  My feeling and opinion on the game itself have not really changed from what I wrote before. I still find the game to be underwhelming and the enjoyment of it disproportionate to the love I see it getting. However, the community on the whole here has been EXCELLENT. I mean I have been pretty adamant (though respectful) in stating my opinions and I have to say with one or two excepetions the reaction has been civil. That does not happen on the internet. Except for here apparently. So if you are okay with taking the community health into consideration I am actually gonna go ahead and say I would Recommend this and move up my rating to a...

5.1/10

I also have to take into consideration that my expectations for the tile may have been too high. More frustarting is that many other people that like simliar games seem to be completely satisfied with the experience and delivery. Its pretty unusual that I wind up an outlier in satisfaction when I am (or felt like I was) a part of the core demographic. Armello seems to be enjoyed by people like me. I barely enjoyed it for 5-6 hours before I found myself searching for reason to like it but I just can't quite figure it out. Anyway if your on the fence I say give it a shot.



11/9 Was pleased to see that with the new update the speed of the AI controlled players was adjustable. I would have to say that experience for singlplayer has been streamlined and improved dramatically. Sadly, I still did not enjoy the game. I only realized this after playing for another few games and realized I was searching for reasons to switch this game to a recommend.

In response to Kletian's comments to my review:

I agree that picking your deck can influence the outcome however there are just too many random variables that are outside of your control. Is this game strategically superior to chutes and ladders? Absolutely. Risk? Not even close. Monopoly? Probably the best comparison. The random or uncontrolled variables in this game include:

3 other players turns
1 King turn (King's Guards)
Banes Turn
Placement of Quest Markes
Card Draw (Mitigated by choice of card type but still random)
Dice Rolls
Board Configuration

That's alot of randomness to contend with. I am in no way opposed to RNG or believe that it should be a left out of any serious strategy game. However the way this game is structured leaves little room for interesting choices as the game evolves. The randomn elements seem to dictate the way you should be steering your strategy and trying to go in another direction is almost always going to put you in the losers bracket. Armello offers you choices in your strategy but the design of the game itself hamstrings you into playing one way or the other and its just a tough pill for me to swallow.

The game is still gorgeous and I agree with Kletian's comments that game is more similiar to Rouge-likes in progression type. However, I would argue that old-school rouge-likes rewarded you for measuring chances and taking risks which is something I found lacking in my time with Armello. The end result was that were often (not always) rewarded for taking those risks to gain advantages and overcome challenges. In Armello you are rewarded for understanding which path to victory is most likely to be successful and than gearing your startegy towards acheiving that goal. Abberations to this formula do exists but they seem far to infrequent and unintentional to be considered a part of the strategy.

For a game that involves startegy and measuring risk I would recommend Chaos Reborn.

I would take a pass on Armello unless you really love the art and animation (both are excellent).

5/10



OG REVIEW:

I have very mixed feelings for this game. I'll keep this review short and update it as I play for longer.

Current Playtime: 6-8 hours (5 games total on a friends account during early access)

Pros
- Original and creative concept for a game
- Ran Smooth on low spec computer with med graphics setting
- No bugs encountered
- Beautifully Crafted World (card art and animation are my personal highlights)
- Limited Game Modes at Launch (ranked coming soon per forum post)

AC/DC
-RNG Heavy from a double down effect of having card draws and dice rolls as random factors
-Universal Card Selection (no deckbuilding element if you are expecting a more typical CCG experience)

Cons
-Repetition of Game Board Means it all looks the same after awhile
-Some progression exists but a overall a little light on the RPG element promised
-Balance - Several ways to win a game but two of these are extremely difficult to achieve
-Long playtime for each game especially Multiplayer
-RNG + Balancing Issues + Long Playtimes = Frustrating Experience

Even shorter review:

3-5 hours: Sweet! An Online Digital Board Game with RPG progression.
5-8 hours: Slooow Moving Game (3 turns other than yours to contend with) and disappointed to find that a strategic approach is smaller element is secondary to dice rolls/card draws.

I will keep playing as I still love the premise and several of the issues I have with this title have been acknowledged and are being worked on by the developers. Priced out at $20 US dollars in its current state I am going to have to give it a thumbs down for the time being.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Been following this game's development for a while, and after getting my hands on the early access (finally) I can see that everything is as it should be.

I'm a huge board gamer, and this game's tabletop roots show through. But the developers went a step further here, and took advantage of the game engine to mediate things in ways no tabletop experience could replicate as smoothly. This not only takes all the boring round by round management, tracking, upkeep, and calculating out the experience, but allows for hidden movement, trap placement, and other subtle elements that would not be possible at a table.

Because of this, the developers made a REALLY smart move by allowing Armello to be played at a table with a single device, because at its heart, Armello is still a board game, and being able to play it face to face will enhance the experience tenfold. I cannot wait til September when the full version comes out, and I can sit down with my family and friends, a few beers, and have an evening of Redwall-styled treachery and high-adventure.

reviewText:
I have played a couple of single player games to learn the mechanics. and 15-20 multiplayer games.  Some of those have been with friends and some solo and all of them have been fun.

Pros:
-8 characters (more on the way?) with different skills and playstyles
-Multiple win conditions 3 fairly easy ones and 1 that is kinda difficult to set up if you want to give yourself a challenge
-If you can't win play the spoiler and just mess with others for fun.   Winning doesn't appear to give you anything other than some steam achievements so losing does feel bad just have fun playing.
-Fairly quick queues for a game only once have i had to wait more than 2 minutes
-Looks great graphically.

Cons:
-Disconnects and freezes have happened 4 out of 20ish games (couple times friends DC, once game just wouldn't roll dice, and once another player DC, then the other two DC and i had 3 AI in the game).  If the game gets stuck and doesn't progress you don't get the chest/key at the end.
-No ranked yet (hope its coming soon)
-Playing against a group of 3 in solo queue is fairly awkward when 3 work together. 1 person clearing out the castle and moving away so the player with the stones can just walk in and kill the king while the other 2 play bodyguard just isn't all that fun.   has happened a couple of times.


Overall the game is very good and certainly worth the pickup.  Reminds me of Talisman a bit and can see where the inspiration could have come from and thats not a bad thing.

reviewText:
I backed Armello on kickstarter (something I almost never do) based purely on the visuals, and boy am I glad I did. Aussie devs League of Geeks have done a exemplarary job - even the earliest build was a great deal better than most finished games, and they have continued to polish and refine the game, and built a thriving community of Armello enthusiasts that they have really listened to - this is kickstarter done RIGHT.

The final release reflects that polish, with love and attention to detail oozing from every pixel. It's unique mix of turn based strategy with RPG and card game elements is backed up by lush, Studio Ghibli inspired visuals, gorgeous music and inspired (and in multiplayer excceptionally devious) gameplay. There's a engaging story - a mad king, a kingdom under threat from the Rot, and now eight playable heroes attempting to either hold the kingdom together, take it over or destroy it. Each hero is unique, can equip different gear, and hold traps, hard won followers or spells for battle against the opposing players - some cards can not just snatch victory from defeat but change the nature of the game or the victory conditions if played well. Combat is via nicely animated dice rolls (themselves modifyable by the cards in hand) and often deadly - it's not uncommon for two heroes to kill each other in the same bout, there's the creeping horror of the Rot to fight (or allow it to possess you) and then there's the mad King with his strange edicts affecting all players who eventually will destroy the Kingdom if players allow it. Multiple victory conditions abound here, and the wily player may need to change their overall tactics multtiple times in a single play through.

The single player game against AI oponents in engaging enough, but it's in multiplayer that Armello truly shines. there are some utter ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ moves available to the canny player, and interplayer communication, while cleverly limited, is more than enough to form (and break at a opportune moment) alliances. New players are well catered for, with excellent tutorials, and Armello is one of those rare games that's relatively easy to pick up but difficult to master. Cross platform support (it's available on PC and PS4 at launch, with ios and android coming) means you'll never lack for oponents.

With it's sheer beauty, devious tactics and engaging gameplay Armello offers something different, and the incredible beauty of the game is made more astonishing by the fact it was created by such a small team - only 5 people who literally risked everything to bring the game to life. League of Geeks have to date offered unparalleled support, and knowing their devious minds I imagine ther'll be more than just tweaks and bug support in the future - the premise certainly lends itself to further expansion in the form of new heroes, extra cards snd perhaps bigger DLC.

If you're a fan of board games, story driven RPG or strategy it's a must purchase - even for those who are more into other genres should definitely give this a go. I really can't recommend this superb game highly enough.

reviewText:
Imagine the Game of Thrones taking place in the world of Zootopia. Lie, bribe, and plunder your way to claim the throne. In the world of Armello, the end justifies the means.

Pros: Armello provides you with 8 unique heroes, each with their own traits and playstyle, and 4 winning conditions. This makes the game balanced to each hero (provided you play your hero to their strength) while giving the game an excellent replayability value. Tutorial is decent, covering the basic gameplay without spoiling the gameplay too much.

Cons: Lack of story/singleplayer campaign might be appaling to those who play games for their storyline.

reviewText:
I enjoy Armello quite a bit, and I've had my great moments, my dismal moments, and my meh moments over the course of time that I've put into this gem of a game. The world is beautfiul and aethestically pleasing, the characters diverse and full of life in their designs and battle animations, unique movements for each one I must say. And for those who enjoy lore, one can find it in the form of cards, quests, or a certain follower known only as the Stranger. He adds an interesting depth to the game, but I'll won't elaborate on him. Armello is a simple enough game to understand, but it's very difficult to truly master.

Armello is a digital board game with hexagonal tiles that can favor those who have put a considerable amount of time into it, but it doesn't mean that said players, myself included, will win. I have been a part of many a game where someone with far less time won or ruined me, even though I was employing my knowledge of the game to try and win to the fullest. How did this happen you might ask? The answer is simple and is partly why I enjoy Armello so much. RNG. It will make or break your game depending on your dice rolls or on the cards you draw. Sometimes you get fantastic rolls or draws, others are terrible, and often they're a mix.

The beauty of this is that it makes players think strategically about their moves on the campaign map, and how they can utilize their hero skills and the cards they've been dealt to the best that they can in order to win. Furthermore, when one is in battle or facing a peril, then they can burn a card provided it has a matching symbol, though the question is should one save a certain card for later or not. In terms of combat, it makes the player think about the risk versus the reward for killing a player or a bane; in that said hero could die, come out victorious and gain a prestige, or both combatants could die depending on the die rolls. What this means is that you can seek out combat or avoid it to the best of your abilities, and know that there are cards in the game that can increase your chance at a succesful combat by taking away health or delay an enemy player if they're pursuit. Provided RNG gives you said cards.

Now, there are some factors that people claim are major issues with the game; one is the combat system attack die rolls, another is the comeback system after you die, and then there are those who claim some heros are more powerful than others.

In all my hours of Armello, I have seen many a die roll that either brought me victory or ended those hopes. Now, it is true that there are four sides of the die that favor attack, three in reality due to two of these sides being dependent on the time of day. And, yes, there is only one shield side, but that shouldn't get your hopes down. Rather, it causes you to think and plan how you'll play a round. Now, you can have a massive hand of say 13 dice and you only get three defence from them, or you can get 10 defense sides from them. It's all dependent on RNG. I've seen many a battle that netted a massive amout of attack, or defence, or even rot (Much to the benefit or detriment of the player depending upon their current status) and I can say that although attack is favored by the die, that doesn't mean you'll get attack die.

As I said, it's all dependent on RNG. Furthermore, if one is worried about defense, then there are plenty of defence item cards that grant automatic defense die without subtracting from your hand that can be aquired, provided you have the gold. Furthermore, you can burn cards with a defence symbol on them to boast your defense, though you must think tactically on the possible results and if they'll be better or worse.

Now, there are those who complain that the comeback system is detrimental to players, but I say it causes one to rethink their strategies and pursue either the same old goal, or develop a new one to win. If you can't get to a quest because other players keep killing you, then change your tactics and focus on something else, say a dungeon or spirit stones. One does not need the quests to win a round in Armello, they simply provide benefits that increase your chance to win or even fail. I have lost plenty of games to people who never completed their quests but focused on other aspects of the game that caused them to win, be it rot, prestige, spirit stone, or combat victories. What's more, one can use this system to land them closer to their quest, if it's by their clan grounds, and that causes other players to think about the benefits or negative of killing a character in that sure you'll get prestige if you succeed, but what if it turns put you simply put them next to their quest which resulted in them winner. Choices, choices, choices.

Some people say that some of the heros in Armello are overpowered, and that is only true if you let them be overpowered. Otherwise they're in a similar boat you, the player. If you know how a certain hero works, then you can utlize the cards in your hand to either deny of benefit said hero if they are an opposing player. What's more, there is a certain cost in regards to supposed overpowered hero abilites in that there are certain restrictions on them that can easily break someone's attempt to win.

Let's take Barnaby for example, his power allows him to add or remove item cards and not dispose of them as what happens to other heros. Problem is, the amount of cards Barnaby can hold is entirely dependent on his wit level, and the only way he can dispose of said cards, outside of two very early decrees, is either burning in a peril, or in battle. And that's not even counting if RNG grants him decent or good cards.

Mulitplayer wise, Armello can either be quiet or bositerous depending upon the time of day and on how many people are playing. Granted, this is a bit of annoying area if you don't have friends or have not yet discovered the Unofficial Offical Armello community where one can often find a game instead of waiting a time for a random match. I will state that the vast majority of people who play in the random mulitplayer matches stay through to the end of a game, I rarely see someone quite because they couldn't do what they wanted, and most people who do leave simply DCed is all. Multiplayer Armello is utter joy with friends in that you can test your friendships, watch salt meters build, or determine which player RNG does not favor that round. One of my friends is noted for chasing the rest of us down if we are too annoying to him even if it means he's risking his attempt to win.

One more little morsel of information for you to sample. The community of Armello is wonderful from what I have found and there is a place where you can meet fellow Aremllians for a possible game. What's more, you can have a chance to face the devs themselves in a game of Armello pretty much every Sunday at 6 PST/PDT depending upon the year. Perhaps we'll see some of you there, and if so, then good luck.

If you've read down this far, then have some Bubble Tea or Hot Rot Wine on the house and know that I wish you a good time. In the end, only you can decide if Armello is right for you by playing it, trusting the word of others only gets you so far and is open to possibly damaging interpretations of a game.

reviewText:
Flowery review:
I would have a hard time distilling what about armello makes it so great. There is the enchantingly crafted art style, the beautiful music, the fun varied strategies of differing hero's and victory types, it seems to really have it all. The only fault I find is that it is such a complete package and yet you are left simultaneously satisfied with the experience, and wanting more.
Nuts and bolts review:
Armello is a digital board game,  unlike most of its kind it seems distinctly aware that it is in fact digital and takes such advantage of its medium from the animated battles to the day/night cycle of turns, they really knew what they were doing with the tools afforded them. That said the game is not without fault mainly your problems will arise from sometimes excruciatingly long queue times to the fact that if a player disconnects for any reason there is no way to rejoin the game you were in. These slights are unfortunate and like many board games matches run for around an hour so you have to allot time to play a match and really hope you don't have any issues towards the end of a particular session or else you can lose all that time you spent. There is also an element of luck involved with winning in any particular match and some of the victory types are easier to achieve than others, however the variety they afford the games strategy overshadows the seeming unbalance of their ease.
Pros:
- music, art, and subjectively gameplay  are extraordinary
- masterful execution of a digital board game taking advantage with animations and even important functions like the day night cycle that just couldn't be replicated on a traditional tabletop.
- wonderful game to play with friends.
Cons:
- connection issues while not extremely common can really be a big bummer.
- there is a fair amount of luck involved in actually winning the game.
- speaking of winning some victories are far easier to achieve than others.
- queue times can be abysmal at times added to the fact that matches run long and it could take one and a half to two hours to get from queue to finishing a match.

ps. I don't normally write reviews more than a couple sentences long so I am aware this is a little disjointed and not the best but this game really deserves a longer explanation in my opinion let that serve as a recommendation in and of itself.

reviewText:
Armello, or Furry Chess, is a turn-based strategy game modeled on tabletop games of old. You'll find it whimsical and charming, I'm sure.

STUFF WOT I LIKED AN' THAT
Lots of fun, nice variation of characters, with four more planned when it's released
Plenty of replayability thanks to the characters, the unlockables and the new Custom Match option
GORGEOUS art style, I honetly can't stress enough how beautiful this game is
Nice integration of diceroll and card-based mechanics into the structure
Perfect in terms of complexity: This game has enough depth to be continuously interesting and challenging without being as beardy and convoluted as games such as Civilisation. It's very easy to understand the basics.
Tutorial is very well done, broken into four short, modified game sessions that introduce a character and a couple of key mechanics at a time. There's also a great guide to the gameplay available in game, even in the middle of a match. Sure beats having to pull up the wiki in a pinch.
Doesn't drag on too long - The nature of the game means the timer runs down, so matches won't run on for hours on end. This is perfect for more casual players who don't want to dedicate three hours to one single playthrough,  like me
NOT SO GUD M8
Bugs and the like - The recent update (as of 14/11/2015), the first post-release one, caused a lot of trouble for several users, including myself, rendering the game unplayable. This was, however, patched after only around three days.
Tiny Playerbase - I know two other people who play this game, and I had to bully both of them into playing it. If you plan to play this game you oughtta spread the word around, a lot
Public multiplayer is a bit of a ♥♥♥. Since there's such a tiny playerbase matchmaking can take a pretty long time sometimes. However, the devs were canny enough to pre-empt this, and you are able to play offline games while you queue
Early Access - Although Armello is super strong so far, there's a fair potential for change. Doesn't seem to be a likely worry, but it's always an important thing to bear in mind.
Overall, I'd say this game is definitely worth your time, whether you're a fan of strategy games or not. It would make a good gateway into the genre, with its excellent balance of depth and simplicity.

reviewText: Great casual game with a surprising amount of depth. Can be enjoyed from a surface level or by diving into the strategy element for more depth. don’t let the art-style / cute-animal-ness mislead you.

between the MAD king's malice pouring from his throne and your competitors, the game is built from the ground up with grim brutality, power grabs and betrayal in mind.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Man, I actually regret not backing this on Kickstarter now. I wanted to because the art style and unique Bedknobs and Broomsticks-esque fantasy setting is definitely of a high caliber, but watching the gameplay videos it just looked slow and honestly quite boring.

As soon as I began playing I immediately realized that was not the case. This smooth turn-based strategy game may be infinitely less complex than a lot of the bigtime 4X games, but I think that's actually to its benefit (and mine). The mechanics and four different victory conditions centered around the King are particularly interesting.

I'd like to see some diversity added to the Banes (AI minions that spawn on the map) and I'm generally not a fan of anything being dictated by dice rolls, but overall this is already a very solid and polished game.

I'll have to play more before the cracks start to show through, but the quality of the game as is and the dev team seem to indicate any major issues will be addressed over the course of the six month Early Access.

reviewText: If you enjoy board games, you should take a look at Armello -- it's a computer game that plays just like a board game.  It certainly can use a bit of tweaking of the AI.  Although there is some truth to the fact that the game is set up to favor a prestige or combat victory, that's not a huge issue.  And with some tweaking by the devs, that can certainly be adjusted.  It's not a big issue, but it's one that others have mentioned.  The only actual bug that I've encountered since release was one related to an achievement, and the devs were able to fix that issue.  It's fun, and light-hearted, and I definitely recommend it.  Check out any of the Let's Play videos on You Tube, to settle any doubts.

Gameplay video + Impressions below

This game is a new addiction for me. The game has a surprising amount of layers to it's mechanics.
Games last roughly up to 1 hour so it's a nice short table top feel. 4 possible victory conditions which you need to try and acheive while also hindering others as best you can. Combat is dealt with via dice but you can swing it in your own favour more by clever use of terrain, stealth, followers, equipment, spells and traps. The animations during combat are pretty damn beautiful. 8 characters currently in game (hopefully more in future) each with a special power you can make use of to help you find success. Love this game to bits worth every penny and highly recommended.

reviewText:
tl;dr -> After losing friends while playing physical Catan at someone's house, you can boot up Armello and ruin friendships even more from the comfort of your own homes. 11/10 would load Tabletop Simulator to flip digital tables again.

I received a review copy of this game and was very excited to try it because I have a deep love for tabletop games, and this one seemed to blend many different archetypes of the genre like dice-rolling, card mechanics, and map tiles. After playing both the singleplayer and multiplayer game modes, I was extremely pleased with my gameplay experience. Be advised, however, that the game truly shines when played together with friends; singleplayer may get dull after a few playthroughs.

If you enjoy playing tabletop games – especially ones with dice-rolling, cards, and map tiles; managing only one character, and playing against other people, then you will really enjoy this game.

The aesthetics are good – the amount of detail in the character models, terrain tiles, and everything else is high and very well-done. The dice-rolling looks and sounds like actual dice, and the cartoon-style battle animations are fluid. The map can eventually become repetitive because the only change between each playthrough is the randomization of the tile placements. The sounds and music are great and create a nice fantasy atmosphere.

Controls are simple and easy to familiarize yourself with. There are a number of tutorial missions that help you learn the gameplay mechanics and how each clan works. The learning curve is mostly minimal to moderate depending on your experience with tabletop games. Although the AI can be fairly challenging, the game is meant to be enjoyed with friends, so do not base the difficulty solely on the singleplayer experience.

Gameplay revolves around beating your opponents in a variety of ways, with a rapidly dying Lion King as your turn timer. After every player has completed their turns, the King will take one damage (starting the game with 10 health points) and issue a royal decree. The royal decree will change an element of gameplay until the next round – for example, one type of decree will force all players to pay 5 gold, and any unable to do so must give a piece of equipment. The player with the most valour points chooses which decree will pass. Valour points are obtained in numerous ways, such as completing quests, defeating monsters/players, et cetera.

During your turn, you are given a number of action cards (categorized as magic, equipment, and guile) based on your character’s wit, which also determines your maximum hand capacity (high wit = more cards). Equipment cards may give you bonuses like extra health or dice. Magic and guile cards can benefit you (similar to equipment) or harm opponents (ex: damage someone within range). To play cards, you need gold or mana (if you are using a magic card). Cards played on opponents usually require you to be within a certain range of tiles.

You are allowed 2-3 moves, however, moving onto a mountain tile will cost 2 moves (but also provide a bonus to defence). Swamp tiles will damage you for one hp, ruins will give you a random event (yielding cards, damage, quests, etc), and town tiles will be captured and generate gold per turn.

Quests can be selected when you begin, and completing them will grant you an item, bonuses, and valour points. To finish a quest, you will usually have to travel to a specific tile and can either risk a full (there is always a % of success/failure shown) or standard completion (higher chance of success).

The King sends out castle guards, and monsters spawn during the night- these can be fought for valour, however, attacking a guard will put a bounty on you (that other players an claim).

During combat, your attack rating determines how many dice you get to roll; endurance determines how many dice you get when on the defensive. Cards/equipment can boost your dice count, and “selling” cards allows you to lock in a particular dice roll (for example, selling an axe card guarantees an attack roll, removing one die from your total pool). Your attack rolls are subtracted from the opponent’s defence rolls, and any excess do direct damage. It is possible for you and an opponent to kill each other. In the event of a death, you respawn on your next turn in your specific corner of the map, losing a number of valour points.

To win, you may do a number of things. If the King dies from his ailment (he is inflicted with chaos), the player with the highest valour wins. Killing the King, collecting all the spirit eggs from ruins and entering the castle, or attacking the King when you have more chaos points than him (you get chaos points from killing monsters/players) will also allow you to secure victory.

Overall, the gameplay is fleshed out very well, allowing for smooth, fun experiences. The singleplayer can be a bit lacking due to repetitiveness (without the human element). There is a lot of replayability because you can unlock different starting items and abilities for your characters (usually by winning with them). Anyone interested in digital tabletop games should definitely give this title a try.

Recommend!

Cheers,
DJSF @DJSF's Rogue Reviews

My Website[theroguereviews.com]

reviewText:
Pretty disappointing.

I'm a big fan of board games, and was recommended this by a video reviewer I put good faith in.

The game is gorgeous, and has a lot of charm, however the gameplay just doesn't hold up.

Maybe it's because I listen to a lot of podcasts on game design, but this game was a fail. There's way too much luck involved, and most strategy you can conjure up hardly matters. The first two games I played I just happened to win because I was doing quests and playing cards when I could.

A good game boils down to making interesting decisions, but when playing this game there's very few to be had. Most of it doesn't even matter. Do I pick the quest that gives me a 30% chance to get a Spirit stone and a spirit that I won't use, or do I pick the quest that gives me a not useful companion that gives the health I'll probably need?

Do I win by killing the king because I happened to get some rot cards and died to the birds? Or do I kill the king because I got lucky enough to get two spirit stones from the dungeons and it was super easy to get the rest? It's just horribly dull.

Gameplay boils down to. Pick a character
date: use amulets/rings to give them small advantages." This gives you the illusion that there's strategies to explore
recommended: but in actuality it ends up more like this:\n\nGo to quest. Hopefully get something good out of it
hoursPlayed: or don't 'risk' it. (But good luck having any sort of a chance if you don't.) Explore dungeons
voteText: get random stuff
helpfulPercent: or don't. Get into fights. Win/Lose them depending on what equipment you happened to get and how lucky you were on your rolls. Someone on the board gets enough Rot/Spirit Stones/OP equips to kill king. Very little you can do to stop them. They fight the king and usually win. Sometimes they'll die in the process and someone else who did nothing all game will win instead. Game's over.\n\nI hope more people explore the interesting design space there is in a digital board game in the future

votesFunny: look elsewhere.\n\n2.5/5"

reviewText:
Armello is a beautiful but relatively simple board game.

Armello excels in aesthetics and music but for some gamers (even tabletop gamers) the gameplay can be a bit lacking. How and if you win the game are heavily dependent on RNG. This can be very frustrating to players who want a more strategy based game.
RNG determines the outcome of dice rolls, dice rolls determine the outcome of battles, battles determine the outcome of the overall game. To be fair, dice rolls can be manipulated by cards in your hand and by your equipped cards. However, what cards you get is up to RNG and you may end up with poor equipped items or a lack of the card type you desire for any particular battle. Also, the amount of cards you can hold is determined by your wit stat, which always seems to be lacking unless you are a rat (at which point you have very little of any other stat).
Aside from RNG, my one qualm with this game is the speed. Waiting for turns to go through can be excruciating. While I recommend watching the characters (as you may find ways to trump them), there are times when all the characters are in stealth... So you will sit there, listening to them rummage around for a bit, waiting for your turn while almost nothing happens visually. I HIGHLY recommend turning on 'Quick AI Encounters' after your first game. This will speed up the turns quite a bit.

There are 4 victories you are capable of attaining: prestige, kingslayer, spirit stone, and rot. By far, the easiest victory to attain is the prestige victory; it depends more on strategy than any other victory. Rot is the hardest victory to attain; it is highly reliant on RNG. If you are a completionist, or even just want to attain all the victory achievements, you will be kept busy for quite a while. However, if you are fine playing it once through, it will maybe keep you occupied an hour or two.

I recommend the game if you like to fight against the odds and have decent luck with RNG.
I do not recommend the game if you hate RNG dependent mechanics (for which there are many).

Overall

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In this 4-player competetive board game you take the role of one of four heroes from the great animal clans (wolf, bear, rabbit and rat) each having their own strenghts and weaknesses.

I could use a lot of words describing the game mechanics , but then again, just watch this video from Pinstar: https://youtu.be/bYm87khL55w

Pros:
Play online in public games, against friends in private games, or offline against AI opponents.
Four different win-conditions allows for various strategies.
Gorgeous graphics style and sound.
Very well thought out card and dice system.
Playing time is approximately an hour, so you can easily squeeze in a match in your busy schedule.
Cons:
Although strategy is involved, so is a lot of luck.
No hot-seat mode (the game mechanics won't allow this, because cards are hidden from other players and it's possible to perform actions when it's not your turn).
No LAN- or dedicated server-mode, which is really a shame. Dependency on a central server is never a good thing. Hopefully the devs will fix this.

reviewText:
I've played quite a lot while this game was in early-acces and finally decided to create a review since it's just fully released. So here's my quick review :D

Pros:
- A lot of strategy: There is a time limit of around 1.5 minute online per turn. You really need this time to complete your turn properly. Every move is a decision.
- Great artwork: The game just looks absolutely amazing. Especially the cartoonish artwork in the 'fight scenes'.
- RNG: The game works with random cards you get in your hand, this makes every match a different experience. The fight system works with dices, so you can get lucky or very unlucky, but overall, the player with the best odds wins most of the battles.

The RNG part is something you may or may not like. I personally liked the RNG part, because the winner of the match is still mostly decided by skill, not RNG.

Cons:
- Slow: In an online game you are waiting most of the time. This isn't that much of a problem since you can still play cards while it's not your turn, but still, one game takes about one hour.
- Matchmaking: Getting into an online match can take some time.

Overall this game is worth your money if you like Strategy games and can enjoy the RNG parts.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Armello is a beautifully crafted game with easy to learn rules/controls, gorgeous and vibrant art and a soundtrack that could calm the nerves of raging bull. There are still a few minor bugs with the gameplay BUT this is easily forgivable since it is still an Early Access game.

Speaking as someone that does not play many tile based and turn based games, I was a little hesitant when jumping in for the first time. The game, however, is very charming, not overloading you with books of dialogue about the characters or the kingdom. It feels more like an emergent narrative that allows the player to decide there own fate during the game play. It's very replayable as there are many unlockable items that can change your strategy when in game. There are also more characters confirmed for later release which looks very exciting.

The Art, as mentioned, is amazing and consistent all the way through. One thing that I do love is that they have 3D animations for tile game play and traditional 2D animations for combat. Any fan of 'Redwall' or 'Mice and Mystics' will be able to jump into this with no problems.

Definitely worth a look for anyone that enjoys tabletop and roleplay games!

reviewText:
A visually stunning and impressive game. The game is a sort of adventure game of intrigue, combat, and politics. 8 characters across 4 clans of animals are playable in a game to either kill, or cleanse the king.

Each clan has their own ring set to expand upon their playstyles to alter how you play. Amulets allow you to give a bonus stat at the start or a head start on some of the winning conditions in the game.

Gameplay follows a lot of your adventure board game stylings such as super dungeon adventure. The map is essentially a big diamond with various tiles for different effects. Each player has a quest to start with from 3 pickable ones. If you get to the tile you can either risk a roll for a bonus item but if you fail you will lose things such as health, magic, prestige, etc. This is all the while fighting off banes brought from void dungeons, other players, and occasionally the kings own guards. Each day has two turn cycles of day and night. Each day the king loses 1 of his 9 health until he dies on his own and at night his rot level grows by one. This means there are 18 turns in total until he dies.

In that time you have 4 ways to win the game. The first is that you have the highest prestige when the king dies on his own or by someone killing the king who dies by the kings hand in that same fight. The second is that you kill the king without dying to him. The third is to kill the king with more rot than him (Rot victory). Lastly is the cleansing victory which has you gathering 4 spirit stones found across the map occasionally or by finding one in the dungeon tiles.

Combat in the game is an interesting concept as well. Each character has 4 stats to work with, Fight increases the number of dice you can use in combat/defending, Body determines your characters health points, wits increase card carrying capacity and peril dice, and spirit determines how much magic points you get at night to use on spell cards. Upon entering combat you roll dice equivolent to your fight stat against your targets fight dice. Any bonuses from equipment are considered as well. rolls determine your attack and defense numbers and are compared against your targets. Fights can end in double KO's.

Each turn you can draw cards up to your wits number. Cards come in 3 flavors: Items come in the form of equipment, or useable one time items that require gold to equip or use. Magic cards allow you cast the spell on them for it's magic cost. The last card set is trickery, they allow you to alter events or cause trouble for a gold cost.

The soundtrack enhances the mood of the game quite well. It suits the fantasy medieval setting very well.

Now there are some gripes with the game in some aspects. For the most part each character has a unique playstyle that doesn't have a glaring detriment. However there are two characters who's specific abilities aren't all that helpful to you in progressing towards a win condition. The first is the rat mercurio, whose ability of taking a gold from a settlement owner when he takes it himself starts becoming useless in the later parts of the game. The second is the bear Sana, her ability is that she can use her spirit stat as her fight stat when she fights anything that's corrupted. This is a big loss for her in the early game as the only thing that's corrupted early are banes (rot birds that spawn from dungeons), so unless someones going for a rot victory or you are going to try and fight the king, her ability is practically useless until the very late game.

A second issue i have with the game is that you have a visual range of about 8 tiles of the board for clear visability. If you zoom out, the game gives a kind of through the clouds look which blurs your vision a bit. For a game that's supposed to be board game like, it would be nice to have an option to view the entire board clearly (outside of stealthed enemies). It is mitigated by quick keys to jump to certain sections of the board, but it would have been something nice to have.

The last one i have is that the online is a little to be desired. As a whole it functions, but you can't host an online match until you get a friend in your game nor is there a list of available games. Your options are look for randoms which with the low player count can take some time, or invite a friend then you can have others join you or fill with AI.

I would recommend the game for anyone who enjoys adventure like board games but don't want to spend the 70-150 dollars it costs to buy them. The average game length is about 50 minutes to an hour and no suspend feature for online so make sure to have some time to play through to the end.

reviewText: From the totally unique aesthetics to the wonderfully original gameplay, Armello has it all. The moment the opening cutscene began, I knew I had bought something special. A one-of-a-kind boardgame/rpg experience. The lore and core story are epic as the best medieval stories (Armello TV series please, League of Geeks) and the quests are all entertaining and have a great Dungeons and Dragons flair about them. And let me just praise the tutorial segment of the game. It's done EXACTLY how a tutorial should be. It eases the players into the (seemingly) complicated mechanics, but in an organic, story-driven way that is entertaining and informative. By the end of it, I had a firm grasp of how to play, was ready to dive right into my own game, but I also was so excited to learn more, find all the secret quests and fill up my card collection. A true gem of a gaming experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Armello is a digital board game set in a medieval fantasy world inhabited by animals.
The king is afflicted with a dark curse that slowly drives him insane and eventually will kill him. The 4 clans (Wolves, Rats, Rabbits and Bears) now try to gain the upper hand (or paw) and fight each other for the throne of Armello.

You play as one of the clans' heroes, like Thane the wolf warrior or Sana the bear druid. (4 heroes available right now, 4 additional heroes + 4 Kickstarter backer-exclusive heroes already confirmed)
Traveling over the board in a turn-based system, you draw cards (items, spells, trickeries/traps, followers...), conquer villages and explore dungeons for gold (to play your cards) and treasures, complete quests related to your hero's backstory, fight monsters and other heroes for gold and prestige in a dice-based battle system and try to raise your stats (like number of dice, life points, etc).
In the end, you can face the king in battle. Or banish him with magical spirit stones. Or just collect the most prestige and wait for him to die. There are many different ways to win the game.

A special feature of Armello is the rot. Your hero can become affected by the same curse as the king, completely changing the course of battles. If both you and your enemy are affected by rot, the hero with more rot gains the other hero's amount of rot as bonus dice. If your rot is high enough, it makes battles against other heroes or even the king way easier (when you suddenly roll 5 more dice than your enemy). On the other hand, you lose health every turn and can't use the healing stone circles anymore. Managing your rot  is an important part of the game.

There is no best hero or best way to win the game. Some lucky dice rolls, bad card draws or finding a good follower in a dungeon can and will make you adapt your strategy.
Maybe you were the prestige leader the whole game and lose everything by accidently attacking a King's Guard. But then, a quest and some dark magic increase your rot and you suddenly have more than the king. Now all you need is more fighting power. With a bit of luck, you'll find enough gold in that dungeon over there to equip the expensive battleaxe you found two turns ago. Or wait until next turn and try to draw a card that lets you steal the rabbit's morning star...
No game is the same as the last.

The game has come a long way since the beginning of the Backer-Alpha and lots of things have been improved during the Backer-Beta (like a complete rework of the rot system). Now, with some of the things added and changed in the latest build, this Early Access version definitely is the best version of this game so far. If everyone keeps submitting bug reports and suggestion to make the game better and the developers at League of Geeks keep up their great work (and I'm sure they will), this game can become one of the best digital board games in years.

------

Pros:
Great artstyle
Likeable characters
Beautiful animated cards
Easy to learn
Surprising strategic depth
Interesting dice battle system
Great 4 player Online-Multiplayer (maybe still a bit unstable, but steadily improving)

Cons:
Bad luck can make you lose in a single turn
AI sometimes too easy to beat/no difficulty settings
Some heroes/strategies actually ARE stronger than others right now, but with more cards and balance changes, I'm sure this will be fixed after Early Access

If you like board games, fantasy settings or animals, or you're just looking for a relaxing game, I can definitely recommend Armello!
voteText: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is what Dragon Commander tried to be and failed miserably at. Few games do the 'living board game' genre justice, where you take the core of what makes a fun board game, and a fun video game, and then mash them together. Armello has harnessed that magic masterfully and I can but recommend them and bow to their prowess.

If you like video games, will you like this? I dunno. I guess it depends on what sorts of video games you like, but if you're anything like me (or Ron Gilbert, who's apparently also like me) then you have the capacity to enjoy a slower paced game. It wouldn't be fair to compare it to strategy games, though, that's not its jam. It is very much the living board game that everyone has been trying forever to make. If you like board games, will you like this? Definitely. This is a form of dark magic that brings a board game to life to be played in a way no other has.

Not only that, but this game has a remarkable amount of lore behind it. How far did they go? There are audio books (!!) for it, which are beautifully done and excellently voice acted. I'd genuinely recommend grabbing those, too, as they make Armello such a complete experience. Armello is a place, a world, on a desk for you to interact with.

Give it a try. It's like nothing else you've ever played.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this - it's gorgeous, generally well-polished, and I really like the idea of a strategy game where you only have one character (avoiding the usual problem with something like Civilization, where turns get longer until the game isn't fun).

Unfortunately, the strategic depth just isn't there.  The game has harsh coin-flippy rewards and a terrible snowballing potential, meaning your result on the first challenge (where it is most like a coin flip) determines the course of the rest of the game.  This, and some of the supporting systems, lead to the best strategy being to simply stack your highest stat as high as possible.  Three of the four stats eventually lead to a massive pile of prestige, which lets you win by default a few turns before any of the other victory conditions are possible (without extreme luck).  Better balance between the victory conditions would help, but ultimately the problem is that the game's randomness can only be steared when you're ahead.

There are other problems with the game - cards are samey, lots of useful information is animated away before it can be read, and the UI has some serious rough edges (burning cards has a pile of issues, in particular).  But the core problems with the strategy are what kill it.

reviewText:
This is absolutely a board game.
It has a tiny 9x9 hexagon map. Single player games generally last an hour for ~16 turns. It does a few things you couldn't do in a physical board game, like hide player units when they're in stealth and change the writing on cards.

I was somewhat disappointed at first since I prefer my turn based strategy/RPG hybrids to be sprawling fantasy 4x empire builders. This is so good I'm very happy it isn't.

The game mechanics are really fun and well balanced, while the artwork and character design is absolute top notch excellent.

One of the things I didn't notice in videos for this game is the card artwork. It's by far my favorite part. The cards are all animated. The animations are short, but they give a lot of life to the cards. Check out teleport, it's one of my favorites. Can you find the frog?

I haven't tried multiplayer yet, though I hear it works well. Singleplayer has a lot of longevity though, since there are so many neat steam achievements to get. One thing that could be improved is the single player AI. There's nothing obviously wrong with it, it seems competent. but the simple fact is I end up winning the vast majority of games played against it, even though I'm usually just achievement hunting without much care to weather I win or lose. It would be nice if it got a tuneup.

reviewText:
An honest review after playing only short time, it's not possible to do so more cause of annoying bug of half the sounds being static.

It's a fun boardgame with a few elements beyond capabilities of reality boardgames that make game even bigger of a charm.
The art style is purely awesome. The illustrations of cards, menu, characters and fights are simply awesome and even though the game is not big on 3D work, it's good too. The system is explained and even though seems complex at start, it is easily explained multiple times it's not hard to memorise.
The 'fights' and also interactions have a massive downside of being RNG-based as of rolling the dice and has nothing to do with skill as of for most of the game too, but also at the same time giving the 'surprise' charm you get when playing a real game.
Story isn't very special, usual magic adventure with a rather interesting character roster filling up for that. Not much to say.
Overall, well-worked out game. Not sure if curent price is worth but i got it as a gift and it also has Multiplayer. Definetely fun to play with other people so probably mostly worth only if others play it too.

reviewText:
A rich and rewarding creation from an independent studio that combines classic, dark intrigue with a setting not unlike Disney's Robin Hood.

I backed this game from it's kickstarted inception and played a role in helping play-test and shape it and the rapid turnover for changes and fixes showed that the creators took it seriously.

Even now, the game continues to be given improvemnts post-release.

The artwork is vibrant, rich and beautiful, the character designs are diverse and interesting and the gameplay itself brings a fusion of RPG, cards and strategy that will always remain fresh thanks to a proceduraly generated board.

It's easy to learn, fun to play and depending on your play style, you may find some characters more to your taste than others, but I highly recommend you play as all of the different characters!

I recommend this game to anyone, be they hardcore sorts or casual, as it has something for everyone.

reviewText:
Armello is one of those games that's likely to always be here on my hard drive. The game is fun, and is one of the very, very few games that don't give the feeling that the AI is cheating.

The only reason i MIGHT have taken points off is the small scale, and the fact that it makes me want to play a full, open world RPG version of it... but neither of those wants is enough for me to be able to bring myself to count it down for them.

They're right: tabletop game, with digital magic.

reviewText:
Having watched this game through Early Access iterations and release, I can say that the game is fun and also that the devs care that it is in a good state.

HARDWARE
GTX 970, Phenom II X6 @ 3.2ghz, 16gb RAM, SSD
Mouse and Keyboard
Steam Controller - Works great, see below.

Performance - The game never drops below 60FPS and looks great 98% of the time.  Minor texture flickering may occur and occasional audio performance issues from using the newly released Steam Controlled and Big Picture mode it seems.  The game is being constantly updated.  I have experienced NMA (no more action) bugs only twice or so in my 74 hours of gameplay, some other minor bugs after its release from early access as well but the release is solid and you should not experience any real issues either.  Netplay seems to work very reliably and has Steam integration for playing with friends.

Gameplay - Armello is more or less a tabletop board game where you control one of several semi-customizable heroes in your quest to be the new king.  This is achieved by acruing the most prestige when the king dies of a magical corruption (or failed regicide), killing the king and surviving, or by collecting four artefacts required to cure him.   You have several decks of cards with themes of equipment, magic, and subterfuge, which you can draw and play towards your goal.  There's choices on how to progress your character, risks to weigh against rewards, and plenty of tussles to be had with the other players as you fight each other along the way.  The thematics in this game are all wonderful, and the art, music, and visuals all contribute to the great presentation.  The duration of a full-length online game is about 45-90 minutes depending on how long people take on their turns, and it can be less if a player achieves one of the other victory conditions,

But is it fun?  I think so.  The game has a strong element of RNG.  Random board terrain, cards drawn, AI character movement, fickle dice rolls, and other players strangely unpredictable behavior all contribute towards making the game seem a crapshoot.  One of the more prevalent complaints I have seen is how RNG heavy the game can be.   But strategy does exist and a large part of it is being adaptive to the state of the game and trying to sway the odds in your favor.   Knowing what decks to draw out of to try get the right cards you need, knowing what your objective should be for that phase of the game, and knowing what victory condition you should be working towards (and not just wandering the board aimlessly), these are all important and more.  True, this isn't always going to work, but the game would probably be a lot more boring if every player was able to run consistent strategies, or only a few consistent strategies existed.  The randomness of the game gives you more unpredictable 'oh-my-god that just happened' moments.   It wont require any sort of grand strategy game knowledge to enjoy yourself either, so if you like to just play by the seat of your pants you can do that too.  I think most importantly, if you can be a bit laid pack and not get upset over the outcome of a dice roll going completely wrong and maybe even losing you the game every now and then, you will have a good time.

All in all, its a great game.  I've played 75 hours and loved them all, and I hope to play many more.  There's been a lot of balance changes from Early Access up til now a few months after release and the devs do have an ear to the community for the most part.  There's some more content on the way in the form of new characters as well, and maybe even some more content DLC down the line (I hope!).  Its a good one.  I'd recommend it.

-STEAM CONTROLLER-
Game works great with the Steam Controller!  I would recommend my custom setup I have uploaded to the community profiles section, or you can read my suggested binding here.  This arrangement lets you easily and quickly view player positions and keep an eye on the action.  I put left click on the left side (unlike the default for steam controller) because it felt more intuitive to grab cards located on the left side of the screen that way.

I'm Not Sue's Armello KB Bindings
LEFT BUMPER assigned to Right Click
LEFT TRIGGER assigned to Left Click
RIGHT BUMPER assigned to Hero Shelf (H)
RIGHT TRIGGER assigned to Inventory (I)
STICK assigned to w,a,s,d respectively.
RIGHT PAD is set as mouse.  Customize sensitivity to your preference.  No click action.
LEFT PAD is set as Directional Pad. Assign buttons to Focus Player (1-4), keyboard 1, 2, 3, 4, and click action to Focus Quest (Q) Q.  Require Click is off.
Assign mode switch for the LEFT PAD to LEFT GRIP.  Scroll clockwise and counterclockwise to Camera Zoom In and Camera Zoom Out (mousewheel up / mousewheel down).
RIGHT GRIP is assigned to Focus Active Player (Spacebar)
LEFT GRIP is unassigned.
Y BUTTON is Roll Dice (R)
A BUTTON is Left Click
B, X BUTTONS are unassigned.
< BUTTON is Show Scoreboard (Tab)
> BUTTON is Menu (Esc)

reviewText:
I Love It!

Dont be dissuaded by the (few) negative reviews, this game is very much a dice and card based tabletop boardgame, and it does that quite well. There are multiple ways to win, and certain animals have a slight advantage depending on the way you plan to win, not that you are AT ALL limited in choices due to the creature you chose as your avatar.

Dying is a part of the game. You WILL DIE. But depending on the strategy youre using to win, you may find that an occasional death is helpful. There is a lot of strategy involved, and as other people have mentioned, one roll of the dice may see you needing to completely revamp your strategy... but as a tabletop gamer, I'm used to that, and find it to be part of the challenge.

Single and multiplayer modes available, and I find the AI on single player to be challenging and enjoyable... you can invite friends to multiplayer games or just queue up for a pick-up.
I got it for 25% off ($14.99), but it is definitely worth the $19.99 full price.

As I write this, I have 18.0 hrs of play time, and that is in two days... so yeah, I kind of like it.

If Settlers of Catan, Risk and Hayao Miyazaki had a baby, this would be it; and it is adorable!

reviewText:
If you're a board gamer, or have sunk hours into Dokapon/100% Orange Juice - this is probably going to scratch your itch. The rules were easy enough to pick up after one game, and any other questions we had were quickly answered by the game manual (which is hidden in the escape menu). The characters seem relatively balanced, and thankfully, not pandering to furries.

The game has solid depth, and I could see myself replaying it for the forseeable future before it gets stale (I'm estimating about 60 games). Playing around with different characters and pushing yourself for the more difficult victory conditions is a riot while everyone scampers around the map jumping on each other to prevent everyone from doing the same. While there's a healthy element of randomness to it all, much of the luck can be mitigated by smart plays, so generally the more skilled players win. That said, the card element is a little tricky to control, and I do wish there was a way of influencing your draws other than by card type.

Just note: this is a short game that's meant to be replayed. There is only one 'map', and the game lasts around 40 minutes; even though the trailer would seem to have you believe that it's some kind of sprawling epic. The map itself is relatively small, but that serves to keep everyone running into each other consistently, which is point.

Make sure you have a friend along for the ride, because the amount of banter you're about to get up to on Skype is worth the price of admission alone.

reviewText:
I backed it on Kickstarter and it was the right thing to do. Armello is a great mixture between card, strategy and board game. The graphics and animations are amazing and so is the soundtrack. I haven't played the MP yet, but the Singleplayer gives you a good choice between different heros and especially during the first few hours you will always find new cards which can change the game. Replaying will always give you a slightly different map, different AI players and quests. So it's definitely worth the money.

You can take your time to find the best strategy but you will also get a game for in-between, because one playthrough takes roughly an hour.

10/10 would kill the King again with honor, prestige and Soul Stones.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Armello is one of those titles for slow tactical gamers that like to enjoy a Challange of the Mind and Patience... Only those who  know how to conceal their intent will stay out of the crossfire to win any given game...
This game is all about the multiplayer so dont bother with the AI...

Play the tutorial and jump in, thats it.

The smarter player will always win. Choose your way to win and see yourself either trying to protect or kill the King in the Centre of the map. Recognizing the wintype your enemy is going for will almost always lead to easier victories.
As a noob id go for prestiege wins first..

As for now nobody really knows how to play so prepare for easy wins and ragequits..

All in all the game is good. I just hope it becomes more popular and people learn how to not ♥♥♥♥ up and ragequit -.-

reviewText:
EDIT2: I finally got to playing some mp games and I must say wasn't very impressed so far. Firstly, I barely managed to play them because every time I found other 3 players and we started up the game it would disconnect. I verified several times that the problem is not on my end.

- After finally connecting to a game it turned out to last veeery long because players don't have immediate actions like AI (and even AI seems slow after several games).
- players can leave the game when they like without any consequence and then AI replaces them
- there is a huuuuge amount of luck involved in the game (a bit too much for my liking)

- I still recommend this game because it needs more players to get better and it has quite a bit of room to be better, especially because these are some very nice foundations, but I wouldn't call it a final product because it kinda lacks content.




I kinda bought this game on a whim not knowing what it's all about. I just like board games.
This will be a limited review based on just my first few hours and I didn't even play the multiplayer yet.

I was only disappointed in one aspect -  there is no real campaign mode or something similar, but I should've expected that since this is, primarily, a multiplayer game.

Tutorial was really nice and I think single player serves only the purpose of teaching you the game so you can get into multiplayer. That purpose is served well.

The setting, art, gampleay are all very nicely made and as I said, this will be a limited review since I didn't yet play the biggest aspect of the game.

EDIT1: I thought cards had to be collected for mp, but I was corrected by Goon for Hire (thanks). This makes it even better since you are immediately ready for mp.

reviewText: This game is very much worth the money. It's an extremely fun turn-based board game with a lot of interesting mechanics. Being a digital board game it does employ some mechanics that would otherwise be impossible in a real-world counterpart. The aesthetic is absolutely wonderful, the animations are great, and the music is great too. If you've got 20 bucks laying around, I cannot recommend this game enough.
