reviewText:
Having watched this game through Early Access iterations and release, I can say that the game is fun and also that the devs care that it is in a good state.

HARDWARE
GTX 970, Phenom II X6 @ 3.2ghz, 16gb RAM, SSD
Mouse and Keyboard
Steam Controller - Works great, see below.

Performance - The game never drops below 60FPS and looks great 98% of the time.  Minor texture flickering may occur and occasional audio performance issues from using the newly released Steam Controlled and Big Picture mode it seems.  The game is being constantly updated.  I have experienced NMA (no more action) bugs only twice or so in my 74 hours of gameplay, some other minor bugs after its release from early access as well but the release is solid and you should not experience any real issues either.  Netplay seems to work very reliably and has Steam integration for playing with friends.

Gameplay - Armello is more or less a tabletop board game where you control one of several semi-customizable heroes in your quest to be the new king.  This is achieved by acruing the most prestige when the king dies of a magical corruption (or failed regicide), killing the king and surviving, or by collecting four artefacts required to cure him.   You have several decks of cards with themes of equipment, magic, and subterfuge, which you can draw and play towards your goal.  There's choices on how to progress your character, risks to weigh against rewards, and plenty of tussles to be had with the other players as you fight each other along the way.  The thematics in this game are all wonderful, and the art, music, and visuals all contribute to the great presentation.  The duration of a full-length online game is about 45-90 minutes depending on how long people take on their turns, and it can be less if a player achieves one of the other victory conditions,

But is it fun?  I think so.  The game has a strong element of RNG.  Random board terrain, cards drawn, AI character movement, fickle dice rolls, and other players strangely unpredictable behavior all contribute towards making the game seem a crapshoot.  One of the more prevalent complaints I have seen is how RNG heavy the game can be.   But strategy does exist and a large part of it is being adaptive to the state of the game and trying to sway the odds in your favor.   Knowing what decks to draw out of to try get the right cards you need, knowing what your objective should be for that phase of the game, and knowing what victory condition you should be working towards (and not just wandering the board aimlessly), these are all important and more.  True, this isn't always going to work, but the game would probably be a lot more boring if every player was able to run consistent strategies, or only a few consistent strategies existed.  The randomness of the game gives you more unpredictable 'oh-my-god that just happened' moments.   It wont require any sort of grand strategy game knowledge to enjoy yourself either, so if you like to just play by the seat of your pants you can do that too.  I think most importantly, if you can be a bit laid pack and not get upset over the outcome of a dice roll going completely wrong and maybe even losing you the game every now and then, you will have a good time.

All in all, its a great game.  I've played 75 hours and loved them all, and I hope to play many more.  There's been a lot of balance changes from Early Access up til now a few months after release and the devs do have an ear to the community for the most part.  There's some more content on the way in the form of new characters as well, and maybe even some more content DLC down the line (I hope!).  Its a good one.  I'd recommend it.

-STEAM CONTROLLER-
Game works great with the Steam Controller!  I would recommend my custom setup I have uploaded to the community profiles section, or you can read my suggested binding here.  This arrangement lets you easily and quickly view player positions and keep an eye on the action.  I put left click on the left side (unlike the default for steam controller) because it felt more intuitive to grab cards located on the left side of the screen that way.

I'm Not Sue's Armello KB Bindings
LEFT BUMPER assigned to Right Click
LEFT TRIGGER assigned to Left Click
RIGHT BUMPER assigned to Hero Shelf (H)
RIGHT TRIGGER assigned to Inventory (I)
STICK assigned to w,a,s,d respectively.
RIGHT PAD is set as mouse.  Customize sensitivity to your preference.  No click action.
LEFT PAD is set as Directional Pad. Assign buttons to Focus Player (1-4), keyboard 1, 2, 3, 4, and click action to Focus Quest (Q) Q.  Require Click is off.
Assign mode switch for the LEFT PAD to LEFT GRIP.  Scroll clockwise and counterclockwise to Camera Zoom In and Camera Zoom Out (mousewheel up / mousewheel down).
RIGHT GRIP is assigned to Focus Active Player (Spacebar)
LEFT GRIP is unassigned.
Y BUTTON is Roll Dice (R)
A BUTTON is Left Click
B, X BUTTONS are unassigned.
< BUTTON is Show Scoreboard (Tab)
> BUTTON is Menu (Esc)

reviewText:
I Love It!

Dont be dissuaded by the (few) negative reviews, this game is very much a dice and card based tabletop boardgame, and it does that quite well. There are multiple ways to win, and certain animals have a slight advantage depending on the way you plan to win, not that you are AT ALL limited in choices due to the creature you chose as your avatar.

Dying is a part of the game. You WILL DIE. But depending on the strategy youre using to win, you may find that an occasional death is helpful. There is a lot of strategy involved, and as other people have mentioned, one roll of the dice may see you needing to completely revamp your strategy... but as a tabletop gamer, I'm used to that, and find it to be part of the challenge.

Single and multiplayer modes available, and I find the AI on single player to be challenging and enjoyable... you can invite friends to multiplayer games or just queue up for a pick-up.
I got it for 25% off ($14.99), but it is definitely worth the $19.99 full price.

As I write this, I have 18.0 hrs of play time, and that is in two days... so yeah, I kind of like it.

If Settlers of Catan, Risk and Hayao Miyazaki had a baby, this would be it; and it is adorable!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Aloha Steam-ers and Stream-ers,

Warning: The following will be presented first by a short blurb about my thoughts on the game, followed by a very dense reflection on the aspects of the game and all the nuances I have come to find during this Early Access Period. If you just want the short and sweet Review, Look only to the first paragraph. If you want the Essay...continue ^_^

--Blurb--
Currently Early Access: Not all features unlocked, not everything is in final game form, soul of the game and it's potential is immediately apparent. Play with a friend or by yourself.

Game of Thrones meets Redwall for an epic ride through the lands of Armello in the format of Settlers of Catan...without all the trading

This turn based strategy desktop gaming with a furry overtone will have you forming secret coalitions, laying deadly traps, braving forgotten dungeons, hunting deadly creatures, and praying to the RNG gods for their blessing. With multiple methods to achieve victory and only having 16 turns for you to accomplish one of those conditions, this mad dash for the crown will leave everyone scrambling till the last second.

Goal of the game: Become King....sounds easy right?
How to reach that goal:
Kill the King and take the throne by force
Banish the King with magic of the Wyld
Win the loyalty and support of the people
Embrace the Rot and become the new Dark Lord

Pros (imo)
-Achievement System: Good long term investment if you wish to discover different strategies of play
-Card and Dice combat: Good Planning is countered by Good Luck and vice-versa, makes sure everyone has a chance
-Questing System: RPG style of character building along multiple routes to aid you in your victory path
-PVP and PVE Adventuring: Fight other players or monsters to enhance your chances of winning
-Graphics: Beautiful art with minimal animations subtly draws you into the game as you play
-Not a Winner's Game": you've played them before. Everyone who spends 15 turns to attempt to achieve victory has a chance to achieve victory. Lovely aspect of the luck based combat system.

Cons (imo)
-Combat Log: When first learning the game
date: you'll be swamped by a feeling of "what just happened" a lot. The combat log is small and hard to keep track of since every turn is packed with so much information.\n-Early Acces Bugs: Not completed yet
recommended: so if you're looking for a finished and polished game
hoursPlayed: you will not be getting that right off the bat. Community and Developers are working to iron them out and plan on improving the game throughout it's life span\n-Hidden Information: Lots of things about this game I don't know about. I don't know what the goal is
voteText: payment plans
helpfulPercent: development schedules
votesHelpful: etc. Putting a lot of trust into the developers. However
votesTotal: considering how much they've done with the game already
votesFunny:
I don't think that trust is misplaced.
-Addicting: This is just me.....I put it as a con cause you may have a life....I love being addicted to this game.

Overall Impression: Love the game
commentsCount: can't wait to see what else they do with it. More characters

etc. So much more is planned for this game and I am enjoying seeing what comes down the pipe.

--End of Blurb-- (Yeah...THAT was the short stuff ^_^)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nArmello is a board game and  the premier game from League of Geeks featuring fuzzy characters, some RPG-like elements, and cards to help get a leg up on your opponents. This to me this is a great example of how early access should be used. The amount of love, attention, and focus to detail is shown. The devs are regualrly fixing major problems that crop up or fixing balancing issues. Speaking of bugs and problems there arent a ton in the first place that really cripple the game. It has its quirks from time to time sure, here's lookin at you dead bug-eyed bear. They are currently working on ironing out the first bit of content then we can expect to see more content. I can say if you are looking for a change of pace in gaming or if you are into in depth board games this one is for you.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI fully recommend this game to anyone that is a huge fan of board games and card games or table top games in general. This game is simply beautiful, the music is phenomenal and sets a wonderful mood while you are playing the game. The art style adds a wonderful look and feel to the game with out taxing your system to the limits but also at the same time the game looks amazing and has a beautiful high definition look. The game mechanics are easy to learn and easy to play but with a deep level of strategy in the game. As far as early access games go this game is fully playable and feels like a complete game. The length of a match is perfect for board game fans and  players who want a quick satisfying game with out dedicating hours of play. During a match you never feel like you don’t have something to do which is nice in keeping players intrigued. Playing this game single player is a bit on the easy side but it is a good way to master the various victory conditions and try out new things before you take them online. The rpg element add a nice feel to the game and allow for each character to feel unique and diverse with a different play style. Simply a rare gem on the early access market that you don’t see very often.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hello!

Armello really is a great game; people have likened it to Settlers of Catan, Magic the Gathering, Endless Legend, etc. It definitely has the feel of a board game, but in a semi-fast paced, strategy, top-down rpg added in. The art style is beautiful, and most of the mechanics are thoroughly ironed out for an Early Access Game. I admit, some things need balancing and it is lacking just a tiny bit more stuff. (i.e. Stealth really doesn’t work well, and AI needs to be buffed/has to have an easy-medium-hard slider.) But the game is already very complex and complete, with 4 characters to work with (4 more coming when it is fully released), several rings/amulets to choose from, and 4 ways to win. That’s not including the dozens of items, spells, and treasure you collect from wandering the smallish map and battling opponents.

The price I feel could drop 5 dollars where the game is at currently, but it is still early access, and with the implementation of 4 more characters + the Ranked Mode, I would say it is a fair, balanced price at 25 dollars.

A great recommendation from me!

~Wolfy

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the best early access games out there. The game is wholly playable, including multiplayer. It takes a moderate amount of time to finish, but it never feels too long or too short. Like Hearthstone turned real cards into a fun, digital game, Armello does the same with a turn-based board game.

I do have some gripes about it, which is kinda expected from a game in early access. The AI difficulty is laughable and more often than not they manage to get themselves killed. I have yet to see an AI actually win a game. Having to play lots of games to unlock some of the content is frustrating, but thankfully the system isn't DLC and you don't have to actually win to unlock stuff.

In its current state, I would say it has a 7/10 rating. Just needs polish around the corners to make it a must-buy.

If you enjoy board games, this is for you!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Mercurio weighted the Spirit Stone, smiling to himself. This was the last one. He had everything he needed to break the curse that had nearly devoured his king. And it was just in time - the king's mind faded with each day, and before long he would be beyond saving.
On his way to the castle, Amber, the infamous gold-digger crossed his path - the ignorant fool! Couldn't she see that his task was infinitely more important than quarreling over riches? Mercurio felt little regret as he pierced her heart.
To make things worse, Thane, the lord steward, fell to the curse, too, and driven mad with the rot, he was battling his way through the king's guardsmen.
Unfavorable circumstances forced his hand; Mercurio had quite the way with words, and a fat purse to emphasize his arguments. He claimed the title of lord steward just in time to sign a decree that rallied additional warriors into the castle.
The king was safe - for the time being. All that remained was to overcome another valley, another forest; and the ever-present Banes.

It was a rough journey, but Mercurio did not come so far to fail now; battered and bleeding, he stood before the palace gates at long last... imagine his surprise when the very guards he rallied to ensure the king's safety approached him, weapons at ready!
While he was busy battling the Banes, Thane, the corrupted madman, had put a bounty on his head!
This was the moment of truth. Mercurio played all his cards, pulled all the strings; accompanied by a group of mercenaries, he cut his way through the royal guard and into the throne room, hastily applying the Spirit Stones -
despite the circumstances, HE DID SAVE THE KING AND ENSURE PEACE AND ORDER THROUGHOUT THE REALM!

---

The point: this game is absolutely charming and magical, and the people behind it clearly love what they're doing and care for Armello.
Worth every penny <3

reviewText:
After my sixth game, I think I have a basic understanding for how the game works. It is definitely worth the full asking price, and I can see myself playing this game for another 20+ hours despite the repetition.

I'm by no means an expert, but I think I have a grasp on what are the game's sources of improvement (as well as misunderstood expectations from negative reviews). Hopefully these insights will be of use if you're undecided.

It's Like Civ But Not Like Civ
Everyone I've seen describing this game has used at least one of the three comparisons:

Redwall Series (anthropmorphic grim fairytale with some realism) + Game of Thrones + Civilization 5 = Armello

While I would probably use the same base description, some aspects might mislead fans of Civiliation 5 by accident. Here is the simple answer to the question, How is it like Civ?"

LIKE CIV:
It has a hex-based grid system that generates maps for every game.
You get that "Just One More Turn/Game..." feeling in a good game.
There are political and warfaring tactics
date: along with other means (in this game magic)
recommended: to improve your odds.\nYou make a small amount of moves per turn
hoursPlayed: each cultivating in the always potential victory or defeat through your own choices.\nGrinding certain units for rewards
voteText: i.e. the Barbarians. (In this game
helpfulPercent:
the Banes and Knights.)
Each character caters to a specific playstyle and has some personality.
You can start the game with small bonuses to stats. (Unlockable things here.)
UNLIKE CIV:
It's not a 4X game.
Each game (for singleplayer with AI bots) lasts 45 mins to an hour and a half.
You control only a hero
votesHelpful: not a settlement and armies.\nInstead of hundreds of turns
votesTotal:
the game works with nine days (a round for day and night; 18 turns total).
Character animations cannot be disabled (and there's a gameplay reason).
The goal of the game is to take the throne in one of four victories. (GoT comparison).
Although some characters might be better for one playstyle over another
votesFunny: you can win with any victory condition.\nRNG elements are in plenty.\nThat last aspect is the most important one. Although Civ has probabilities
commentsCount: you still had a lot of control over your actions; in this game it's pretty much the opposite. But you can always better your odds.\n\nFor example
column16: ALL of the win conditions (whether for avoiding traps
column17: fighting
column18: or even achieving a victory) is based on some luck. You can influence your chances by improving your Wits abilities at the start for traps. You can accomplish  quests (goals to get improved stats
column19: cards or loot) to improve your character. Or you can use cards you get every turn to better your luck or help you in the game.\n\nLike old RPGs/tabletops
column20:
the challenge is working probabilities in your favor for success.

The Balacing Act
The game has an interesting gameplay element: The King. Everyone is out to kill/banish him and retake the throne from his madness
column21: which is essentially the basic storyline. Each day the King loses one-heart
column22: which he can only regain from killing a corrupted player. You spend one turn to breach the walls
column23: trying to break the trap; the next one to finish the King.\n\nRegardless of your choices
column24: the King will die at the end
column25:
and the victor is the one who suceeds him.

There are one of four victory conditions:
Prestige Victory (the normal victory) is when the player who has earned the most fame/goodwill with the King takes his place when the King dies.
Kingslayer Victory is when the player kills the King in battle AND lives to earn the throne.
Rot Victory is where a corrupted player
column26: higher Rot level than the King
column27: kills the King AND lives to earn the throne.\nBanish Victory is where a player collects four banish stones and gets to use them on the King
column28: ridding Armello of the Rot.\nOut of the four
column29: the Prestige Victory is going to be the main outcome. (4 out of 6 games I won with that outcome; the other two I lost due to the same reason.)\n\nTwo of the victory conditions require you to live from the battle
column30: which both players can kill each other in combat. So if you kill the King and die
column31: the Prestige Leader wins. (And if you attack the King
column32: you lose your Prestige). The "good" option takes some time to gather the stones and you also have to get lucky to banish the King.\n\nMy take on this system is that there is a reasonable risk/reward system for going for the King. Because the odds are against the player living from the battle
column33: it keeps players from bumrushing  on his last heart
column34: while at the same time rewarding the player who does live to take the throne. (Many times I play the Hyena route; get on the King's goodside before becoming a cutthroat).\n\nThere are plenty of means to take away Prestige from the highest player--bounties
column35: special cards
column36: King decrees
column37: constant deaths
column38: etc.--all of which are due to chance. But they are plentiful to never seem like a game is hopeless. The King Decrees are an option for the Prestige Leader to choose that may benefit him or hurt everyone--you only get two bad options that display the King's madness of power.\n\nThe Rot system
column39: while benefiting the most corrupt in battle with extra dice
column40: takes away one heart every dawn. The magic system recharges at every dawn too to some minimum stat. Burning cards only gives you one assured stat for Perils (traps) and battles.\n\nThe rest of the game is centered on luck
column42: as you can put on equipment or followers for extra bonuses and play other cards for temporary buffs or set traps. (For better or worse
column43: you can play these cards when it's not your turn
column44: which is helpful when an enemy gets too close or you set a pre-ambush. This is why the game won't skip animations when it's not your turn.)\n\nHonestly
column45:
the luck system doesn't bother me because I still feel like I have lots of input in my outcomes. And every decision I make feels all the more impactful when it cultimates in a victory of my own doing... But not always of my own efforts.

Needs Some Tweaks
For starters
column46: having the King's health-bar be customizable might extend gameplay without ruining the balancing act. As well as having more variety in maps other than locations of settlements
column50: randomized and given a different seasonal change.\n\nI think nine hearts system is fine since I like the compact Civ feel. The maps
column52: are way too compact. I hate having to quickly backtrack to recapture a settlement because some player recaptured it after respawning at home. Again
column53: player customizable options would be nice.\n\nAlthough the characters do not determine your playstyle
column54: some characters feel pressured into one or two routes without a lot of bonuses in the game. More character classes too would be great. (Currently there are 8; two from each clan.)\n\nFor example
column55: Zorro the Rat cannot take damage
column57: and he's good for sneaking up on players (disabiling their card-burns) and getting bounties.The only way I can see him killing the king is for going for a Rot Victory to get more dice. But he'll need a lot more health to not die in three turns.\n\nI think these limitations will give seasoned players some edge in spoting tactics with the characters tropes.The typical
column58: "Foxes are doing something cunning; pigs are being piggish; weasels are weaselly"kind of cliche for anthropomorphic characters. (Am I the only one who hates that?) I do like that tropes are a potential mechanic.\n\nAlso
column59:
being stuck with a crap set of cards is annoying if you can't burn them often. A discard option outside of perils or battles would be nice for those nothing turns.

Try Your Luck
I really wanted to talk about the gameplay storytelling
column60: but I think the balancing and misguided expectations were more important to address. This is a pleasant

Early Access Review

As an avid collector of regular table top board games Armello immediatly caught my attention. A single game can last 20-60 minutes (depending on the luck of cards/dice) but at any moment you may have to rethink your strategy depending on what someone else is doing (or if something is done to you). Since I have played enough games to unlock all of the characters selectable abilities I can say it is fairly balanced right now. The only improvement I am waiting on is the implementing of new cards there is about 20-30 cards I haven't seen out of the 40+ games I have played.

I recommend you support this game if you are an avid player of board games and if you see any bugs please report them to make it even better.

reviewText:
This is my first review on steam, so I'm going to be somewhat soft.

First off, I think the game looks very well done and playing is enjoyable. The graphics looks great, the map textures are awesome, and I like the 3D models for the characters on the board. I like the animated battle scenes. they look great to me and change the pace a bit.  If there is one or two things I would change, it's the battle system and a story mode for the single player. Sure some strategy is used to place yourself in a favorable position, but it comes down to luck when it comes to getting cards and the die rolls. Can't tell you how frustrating it is to lose to someone who has lower health but get an awful roll. I've played a few time, losses on my part, and I still go back to play more. Adding in a story mode will give more depth into the lore of the Armello world and maybe even discover a thing or two about the characters.

Overall, the game is enjoyable, this is a game where you'll learn from your mistakes and try to get that win that you always want through prep before game start. Yeah the battle system can be tweeked a bit, and maybe add in some sort of story play for the single player.

reviewText:
I love this game already. I've played many great graphical games but few have given me the kinda of thrill I had tonight on this virtual board game. As Thane (the wolf) I was locked into this epic duel with the king as we both constantly kept endlessly drawing each other other in attack versus defense with him down to one HP and me down to 2 WHILE fighting off rivals THREE times all in two turns! It was amazingly epic.
This game is really addicting but every game has its cons sadly. But there's really only 3 i can mention, so I will just name 3 of each of my biggest cons and pros.

Cons:
-Short gameplay. Even Epic" setting isn't long. I don't like that the king auto dies after a period of time. At least let him retain one HP or have an option to turn rot off on King or something.

-Map can feel small. It has some random generation but 4 heroes + 2 - 5 kings guards and banes (or even more) all at once can make it feel congested. That means lots of battles
date: which can be hard on people trying to be more stealthy. It might be just my lack of experience so far
recommended: but it seems flat out battling with decent equipment is the way to go. Did a round as the Wolf and never died once with a defensive build while managing to kill off most people by sacrificing saved up cards for +damage rolls when I felt needed to.\n\n-Lack of customization. I don't think there really needs to be one but it would be nice if we could

voteText: create a custom with our own name of choosing

implemented or not I enjoy the current characters a lot.

Pros:
-Creativity. Man does creativity come into play or you could find yourself surrounded by enemies. It's not a bad idea to draw some spell cards or trickery cards to lower someones HP or find a way to make a quick getaway.

-Battles can get intensive and the world change instantly. You can go from peaceful to people surrounded by banes and guards going after player bounties. I love the complete randomness of it! Even quests are never a promised reward.

-Freedom and Politics. Politics can change the flow of the game. And I love going from being the prestigious kings right hand man to stabbing him in the throat the next turn for fun.

In the end

reviewText:
This game is chocolate-covered bacon. A flashy video game with the heart of a solid board game. A sweet coating of eye candy with dark undertones. The gravity of Game of Thrones blended with the charm of Redwall.

Given a casual glance, this may appear to be a strategy game or RPG, but make no mistake... this is truly a multiplayer board game experience in digital form. Expect much card-drawing and dice-rolling. All players take turns in succession. Complete games are fairly short, about an hour or less.

It's very tightly designed, trading unnecesary complexity for satisfying depth. Each playable character has its own unique strength. While waiting for your turn, you are able to choose quests and play cards, so the thumb-twiddling common in many board games is minimized. Breaking from strict physical game tropes, there is a modest amount of progression in the form of unlockable amulets and rings that grant bonuses.

On top of all this, it's very pretty, the character designs are delightful, and the animated artwork on the cards is just wonderful.

It is not without its faults, though. Randomness plays a very large role, especially since conflicts are resolved with dice rolls. However, you can stack the deck" in your favor with equipment and followers

voteText: so I cannot comment on the general experience there.\n\nOverall
helpfulPercent: Armello is easy to recommend if you love board games with dice and cards

votesTotal: this is still worth a look for its uniqueness and fun multiplayer."

reviewText:
Armello is an engaging game that I really liked. It has it's basis in board and dice games, and I found the learning curve pretty easy. The graphics and music are beautiful.

It has single player as well as online multiplayer. Each game takes roughly half an hour. There are 4 different ways to win suiting different play styles, fight (fight and kill the king, and live), Spirit stone (Gather 4 spirit stones. You don't have to fight anyone if you don't want to), Prestigue (have the most renown from completing tasks/killing banes or other heroes when the king dies) and Rot (one of the hardest victories for me.)

I would definately recommend this game.

reviewText:
From the moment I first laid eyes on the trailer for Armello, I was captivated by the enchanting 2D animations. Armello offers a superb table top game experience easily accessible from your computer. But is that all it has to offer?

However, due to the character limit for Steam reviews, please read our full review here.[gamereviewsau.com]

Quick Gist Of Our Opinion
Armello is one of the most charming games I’ve ever played and has such a unique play-style that you’ll probably not find anywhere else.

The graphics are superb, the story is incredibly well written (and leaves you wanting more, more, MORE) and there are so many ways to win a game that you’ll be engaging your inner strategist just enough to keep your brain trained.

My one qualm with Armello is that the Prologue is so short. I really want to see more story! But apart from that, I feel Armello is an absolute must play for strategy game fans or just gamers in general.

You’d better start downloading it now or else… *shakes fist*

reviewText:
Armello: Haphazard Regicide

Ever wanted to kill a king? No? Oh… Well, ugh, this is significantly more awkward, isn’t’ it? I guess– er, you know, forget I said anything.

So…Do you like anthropomorphic animals? Yes? Cool! Well… Remember that murder thing I mentioned…?

Armello is a pretty rad indie game that simulates a stellar board game experience. One that mixes elements from Table-Top, Pen and Paper RPGs, and a bit of MtG to make for a very unique experience. Armello is pretty simple to play once you get the hang of the game’s systems. But it’s fairly complex to explain… Despite a bit of a learning curve, this game is definitely worth the initial hump of “What the hell am I doing?”.
Before we get into the nitty gritty, the main goal of Armello is to become the new Monarch. The current King has been stricken with an evil disease called ‘The Rot’. And as you would expect, he’s not doing so hot. Every night his condition worsens, and every day he inches closer to death. The Rot also affects his mind, sending him into madness. I feel bad for the guy.

Now, how does this relate to the player? Well, every win condition involves usurping him, either by waiting for him to die and taking his place. Or taking the throne through force. Heck, even the condition that involves purifying the King of his Rot kills him. So you need to get comfortable with the idea of regicide. Despite it’s appearance, Armello is a pretty dark and rough game.

The death of the King is the impetus, and the final goal, of your actions. Almost everything you do will revolve around this end goal. But the King is more of a passive piece on the board. He looms over the game, and carries out evil machinations, but never poses an immediate threat. What you have to look out for is the three other people all actively scheming, and advancing their own plots. You’ll be put in situations very regularly that involve you prolonging the King’s life in order to ensure you’re the one to end it. The enemy of my enemy and all that.

There are a lot of moving pieces in Armello. Four players all working towards a similar goal. With alliances and rivalries beginning and ending on a turn by turn bases. What might appear like help from another player is really just them protecting themselves. I’ll help you this turn to back stab you next turn.

Everything might be going exceptionally well on turn three, but by turn four the entire board state has changed and you must re-assess. It pays to think ahead, and have a plan, but it is invaluable to be able to adapt. There were many occasions where I was one turn away from winning, only to have it slip away from me when the AI pulled a total dark horse victory out of thin air.

How is this possible? Well, every player has a wide array of abilities that can, when used creatively, be applied to completely ruin another player’s day. There are pieces of equipment that increase your prowess in battle– making it easier to kill the King… or anything else. There are magic spells that give nasty status effects, such as: ending your turn prematurely, move you across the board, or possibly even killing you. And my personal favorite, traps. These can be anything from poison, killing companions, stealing their cards or gold, negating their equipment.. the list goes on. If you think through your actions, and use everything at your disposal, you can send someone in the lead into last place with one turn.

The order you do things in, and how long you wait to do it are incredibly important. On your turn you, usually, have three action points that allow you to do the various things at your disposal. Some take more than others… Simply moving three spaces can wreck havoc on another player. Scattered around the game’s map are little villages. If you move your character through them they will pay tribute to you in the form of gold. Without gold you can’t perform certain actions. Having three turns worth of set up be ruined because you’re short one gold is incredibly disheartening.

The swings in Armello are fast and hard. I’ve gone from first to last and back more than once over the course of a game. It’s never dull, and never boring. The pressure is almost always on. And the games are fast enough that you can play one over a lunch break.

Aside from killing the other players, there are also quests you can embark on that give various rewards. Sometimes the rewards can be game winning. Other times they can be a massive disappointment. But you’ll always walk away with some kind of a bonus, like an increase in your stats and Prestige. If the King dies of his Rot, the player with the highest prestige is the winner by default.

Armello really requires you to think, and demands a good bit a strategy. The games go by quick so your plans need to come to fruition sooner, rather than later. I find myself planning for the end game on turn one. “I want to win via killing the king”. And adapting my play towards whatever will actively further that goal.

It’s a good mix of long term and short term planning at the exact same moment. If you realize that things aren’t going your way, you need to adjust your strategy or risk losing. By the time you realize “things are bad” it’s almost too late. It’s as much about furthering your own ends, as it is interfering with everyone else’s. Because everyone’s position is so precarious, just a small bit of interference is enough to make someone target you the rest of the game…

“If I can kill the bear this turn, I’ll lower their prestige enough that when the king dies two turns from now I can win.”  Or even better “Well… If I can’t win, you’re definitely not winning either.”

Armello is a very mentally stimulating experience… And I’ve only played with the AI. So I can’t speak for playing with humans. I have to imagine it’s a hundred times better. But, that’s one of the best parts of Armello. The AI is actually very good! Now, once I got really acquainted with the game I was able to out play the AI fairly easily. But they’re still definitely capable of einschrauben mich über, hardcore.

And on top of everything else I’ve mentioned here. The game has some seriously great artwork. It has a great storybook style to it that is simultaneously both lighthearted, and very dark.
Watching a cute little rat solemnly hand over money to the king’s guards as they terrorize the townsfolk hits way harder than you’d expect. He’s not happy about it… but it has to be done.

Armello is awesome. It’s worth every penny. Seriously, support the Devs. If you like strategy, check it out. If you have friends, and want something to play together that doesn’t require a large time investment– Armello’s your game.

Buy it. I highly doubt you’ll regret it.

If you liked this review, check out 100HourSave.com for more.

The art direction is fantastic. The whole game idea is just so good. This is one of the best tabletop to video-game" takes that I've had the joy to play.

There are a few things that I would like to see get added to the game though.

date: I would love it if there was another game mode. This is obviously something that would take a ton of effort to produce. However

reviewText: A four player board game with great artwork, music and animations. The gameplay is addictive and each game takes around 40-70 minutes.\nThere's plenty of smart mechanics which makes it run much more smothe than other turn based mp games. reviewText:
Guess I should have reviewed long ago but I am quite new to steam apparently.

Overall, it's a boardgame made digital. It's intrigue. I've always wanted to get the feel of a board game, with dungeon master and so on. And this game sort of digitalized the real paper table game, and creamed with beautiful graphics, highly detailed environment and cute looking fluffy characters. For what it is, looking at the real board game now is less appealing anymore because they are all flat papers, decolorized statues, packed cards, tokens and have to calculate the maths yourself. And there's no special effects (unless the dungeon master got creative) like clouds, snow, day and night cycle. And since its automated, everything is running based on strategic skill and luck (rolling the dice). And I imagined having this feature sort of reduced the chance of players going against the dungeon master for fairness".

In the game players can either choose to go against each other or form an alliance (sometimes temporary). The main goal is to win the game in the end. And there's only one victor. Though most of the time I would just go in

reviewText:
Board Game style strategy gameplay.
Games generally run 40mins to an 1hr .
Rarely just sit on your hands when it's not your turn: there are always battles to watch or cards to play.
Developers are continuing to add content post-launch, so far all free with planned dlcs.
Enough variety at time of writing to where Every game I've played has felt different, much more to be added  later.
Restricted Comment system during online play, keeps the trolls quiet.
House rules galore for playing with friends.
Competent AI for Single Player or the very occasional DC by other players.
Occasional bugs, but open lines of communication to report them anf get them squashed.
All in all a must buy for those who like board games.

reviewText:
Armello, where do I begin. The moment I saw the trailer of the game I was hooked, in 1:30 it managed to get me excited for the game. I'm not going to talk graphics and such as each game that's being released nowadays looks great, and so does this one. As for sound, after playing a couple of rounds I grew bored with it, turned it off and putt on some Youtube. Not to say it was bad, but you know, you can only listen to the same song and jingles that many times.

Controls! Oh boy, I have a couple of gripes here. One being the cards being to close to your dice in combat and perils. Sometimes you roll dice when you meant to grab the last card to burn it, it's annoying. This is pretty much the biggest one, but there are numerous others. Camera resetting to a zoomed in position while you zoomed out, your camera being jerked everywhere when something happens, I think you get the idea, I'd say it's annoying, not game breaking.

Bugs! This game is great when you play it casually. When you're trying to get the achievements, not so much. I had it happen numerous times that I was going for an achievement and the game just froze, in the menu, between turns, rolling dice, for no reason at all. This gets really frustrating at times and makes me want to punch the screen.

Multiplayer. There is one, but I'm not going to try it because of the above reason. And also because there are exclusive characters you could only get when the game was being kickstarterted. I'm not playing against characters I know nothing about, it's an unfair advantage and these characters should be DLC at some point, be it with in a different skin, or some other model, I'm sure there is some solution.

Should you buy it? Well, the game is worth the money, I'm at 44 hours now and have yet to get all the achievements, and some of the other unlockables. If the devs first work out the bugs, tighten the UI, and level the playing field multiplayer wise it's a solid title worthy of your collection.

reviewText:
SummaryA gorgeous game that seems simple at first but has a surprising amount of well-balanced depth.

ReviewArmello is essentially a board game.  Actually, it’s a very complex board game that could only exist in any practical sense on a computer.  When developer League of Geeks created a physical prototype during development to hash out the gameplay, the result required two dungeon masters to keep track of all the rules and calculations, which I imagine made it a chore to play.  The computer, on the other hand, is an extremely capable dungeon master and is able to make the numerous calculations in a split second, so Armello matches are always fast-paced and fun.

The King has come down with a sickness called “rot”.  Every morning he loses one point of health, and every evening he gains one point of rot.  This serves as a ticking clock because the King’s days are explicitly numbered - eight, to be precise - so games can’t drag on forever.  A menagerie of armored and weaponed bears, rabbits, wolves, and rats make up the four heroes vying for the throne, and whoever has the most prestige points when the King expires wins the game.  Of course you can be more proactive and seek to claim the throne by killing the King yourself before he succumbs, or you can collect four soul stones and cleanse him of his affliction.  There is a fourth victory type which requires you to become corrupted with rot and then kill the King, but this is generally the most difficult victory to attain and therefore the rarest.  You know, now that I describe the premise, it strikes me as rather brutal, but this isn’t immediately obvious when the main players are adorable woodland creatures.

Players take turns moving their characters across a small hexagonal landscape and playing whatever cards they happen to be holding.  You acquire prestige by completing quests, killing banes (bird-like monsters from the underworld), and killing other heroes who then lose one point of prestige and are resurrected at their starting point.  Whoever has the most prestige at any given point in a match has the King’s ear and can choose which of the King's edicts to enforce each morning. This gives the prestige leader a small advantage, but it's mitigated by the fact that the edicts apply equally to all players, including the prestige leader.  During a player's turn, they can explore dungeon tiles which use a coin toss to decide if players are rewarded with treasure or if they awaken a deadly bane, claim towns which give gold, encounter a variety of perils that use dice rolls to determine if you succeed or fail, set traps for other players with trickery cards, hunt down soul stones which periodically appear in the mysterious stone circles, and pursue player-specific quests to improve your character stats. While you might be tempted to sit back and simply watch other players make their moves, it's important to realize that you can still play cards to the board even when it's not your turn. In fact, off-turn play is an important strategy.

When you first play Armello, you may think that a prestige victory is the surest and least risky, and this might seem unbalanced.  After all, you just have to keep your prestige total higher than your opponents’ and wait until the King expires.  But by its nature, this is the victory that also takes the longest to achieve which leaves a big opening for more aggressive players to storm the castle at the center of the board and go mano a mano with the king or cure him with soul stones.  The prestige leader also has a big target on his back and will be under constant threat of direct attacks and treachery.  It’s not unusual to see the “Prestige Leader” title change hands several times during a game, so a prestige victory is never a sure thing.  It's often best to pursue one of the other victory types while keeping a prestige win as Plan B.

One of the more curious aspects of Armello’s design is how the developers have gone out of their way to conceal information.  It’s impossible to zoom out far enough to see the entire board, and once you get a small distance away, your view becomes obscured by clouds and haze.  Basically, the developers allow you to get an overview of your immediate surroundings, but they actively discourage you from playing that way.  If you want to get information about your opponents, you can open a panel that covers most of the screen and then page through each hero’s status sheet one at a time which can be a little tedious.  League of Geeks has said they do this deliberately to discourage “metagaming” because they want Armello to feel more like an adventure than a board game.  Basically, you’re either doing recon on your opponents, or you’re watching events unfold on the game board, but you can’t do both at the same time.  I will simply say that I don’t entirely understand or agree with the developers’ reasoning here, but it’s not a deal-breaker.

One thing I can say without reservation is that Amerllo’s presentation is outstanding.  This is a low-priced “indie” title, but it looks like it came from a AAA studio.  The heroes are well animated and full of detail and personality, and the game board is a lush palette of gorgeous terrain and a lovely day/night cycle.  Then there's the various cards which feature beautifully hand drawn and subtly animated illustrations which put even Blizzard's Hearthstone decks to shame.  In short, this is one fantastic looking game.

One of the more unique aspects of Armello is the dice system.  Dice rolls are used to determine whether you succeed or fail a peril, or how you fare in battle.  And when I say “dice rolls”, I don’t mean an under-the-hood random number generator but physically simulated three-dimensional dice that bounce around your screen.  Depending on the situation, there could be as many as a dozen dice in play which can be quite entertaining to watch.

Most importantly, Armello is fun.  Matches against the capable AI can be as short as 20-minutes if you enable fast AI turns, so there's always time for a game, or you can dive into multiplayer if you want a real challenge. I've seen people complain that victory or defeat depends on random luck, from coin tosses to dice rolls to which cards you draw from the deck, but isn't that the case with every board game, real or digital?  This is, of course, where player skill comes in, and there are various strategies for dealing with runs of bad luck.  It’s the skillful player and not the lucky player who will win.

I think this is a good start for League of Geeks, and I could easily see Armello’s rich tapestry expanded into adventure games, RPGs, and even the 4X strategy genre.

reviewText: There’s a lot of strategy involved in playing Armello and it’ll take a lot more time to explain every nuance and trick you can do. Suffice it to say that if you’re a fan of card games or board games you’ll love playing this game. It’s deceptively simple but still full of strategic depth that anyone of any skill level should be able to pick it up relatively quickly and find something to enjoy. I’ve only played a handful of games but each one was different from the last. You don’t always get the same cards and each character has their own unique abilities that make certain strategies easier or harder. I had to stop myself from saying “Just one more game” even to write this review. It’s that addicting.\n\nhttp://cliqist.com/2015/10/13/armello-addictive-boardcard-game/

reviewText:
Gaming culture has undergone a bit of a...well, a regression for lack of a better word. I don't think video games are becoming any less popular as a medium of entertainment, but the last couple years have seen an incredible surge in the popularity of board games. Remember board games? Those things you were forced to play with your parents once a week while they tried to coax out more details about your life in some poor attempt at family cohesiveness? Yeah, those.

But at the same time, not those. Maybe I just wasn't exposed to the geekiest possible board games when I was young, but I remember playing Monopoly and Scrabble and Life. Simple games with simple rules. But those games are nothing like what we've seen come out of the board game renaissance in the last few years. Games like Risk and Settlers of Catan (ok, arguably Chess was very much this type of game as well) set the stage for incredibly complex games like Arkham Horror, Dead of Winter and Legends of Andor, games so complex that many of them could be played cooperatively against the board rather than against each other, which is still a novel idea to this day.

Much in the same way that Hearthstone before it married card games and video games in a way that simply couldn't have been done in any other medium, Armello is very much a child of these two genres and it works very well...for the most part.

Thematically Armello acts as a sort of combination of the Redwall books - which, for the uninitiated, feature tribes of anthropomorphic animals living together in a fantasy setting - and a very watered-down Game of Thrones. The basic premise is that you are a member of one of four clans - the wolves, the rats, the rabbits and the bears - and the ruler of Armello (a lion, natch) has been taken by the rot, a sort of corruption that threatens to drive him to madness before it, eventually, claims his life. Your goal, then, is to put yourself in the best position to take the throne from him and ensure your tribe's ascent to power.

Gameplay wise, Armello is very much a board game at its core. You have a set number of moves every turn and you negotiate the map for resources including gold (to buy things, duh) and cards to empower yourself or snare up your opponents. You must win before the withering lion king's last heart of health wastes away. If no one has claimed victory before then, the person-er, animal with the most influence over the throne (measured in prestige) at the time of the king's death wins.

Combat and other conflicts - like fighting your way through one of the game's many peril" cards placed by other players or even the king to hamper your progress - is played out through rolls of the dice (many
date: many dice in some cases) in which you try to match symbols for successes - in combat
recommended: swords and shields for hits and blocks and in "perils
hoursPlayed: trying to match different symbols.\n\nIn these ways Armello is fun but not especially innovative. It doesn't so much bend the board game" genre like Hearthstone
voteText: in many ways
helpfulPercent: did with the card game genre
votesHelpful: doing things that games like Magic: The Gathering
votesTotal: in its physical medium simply couldn't. But it does it competently and with a nice veneer of paint that wouldn't have been possible on a drab board with cardboard cutouts. And keeping track of all the numbers of modifiers and cards would be a much bigger hassle in a physical medium anyways.\n\nThe one thing that Armello does that
votesFunny: while not impossible
commentsCount: would at least be difficult and unwieldy in a physical product is the implimentation of the king's "neutral" forces and the universally-hostile "banes
column16:
creatures of the rots. While clearly an antagonist, the king is more mad than hostile and while he can be turned on players for various reasons, he and his Labrador guardsmen are more obstacles and nuisances than outright enemies. He can even be manipulated into helping you in various ways. The banes, meanwhile, are a constant, AI-controlled threat that add some spice to an otherwise standard experience.

Individual games of Armello are fairly short and it would be nice if there was some level of customization to mix things up more, adding health to the constantly deteriorating king to lengthen the game perhaps even additional map sizes to mix things up a bit. But overall, they are enjoyable and nicely paced to be played in a single sitting. Unfortunately, multiple game sessions tend to feel very similar with the only variation being how you choose to attain victory, which mixes things up a bit but I predict not enough to give Armello permanently-lasting appeal.

Finally, the game can be played single-player or multiplayer. I haven't had a chance to play it with my friend yet, but I predict that multiplayer is the way to go. It can be nice to get a feel for the game in single-player mode, but the AI is easily delayed and duped. In the few games I've played so far, I've won primarily by letting time tick away and maxing out my prestige. The AI makes a bit of a clumsy attempt to claim victory but nowhere near the concerted effort a human opponent would. It almost seems to stumble around until the game is almost over and then say, oh right
column17: I actually have to try and win" before trying for the only victory criteria it can accomplish...one in which it has done very little to prepare for. The promised addition of a ranked mode is interesting but I'm not yet convinced about the competitive promise the game might have.\n\nAll in all

column20: you could do much worse."

reviewText:
*This Review is for the launch version of Armello v 1.1, 2 days after release.*

Armello, the digital board game" that combines fantasy adventure and storytelling with strategy and more than a little "friendly" backstabbing!

Set in the fantasy kingdom of Armello
date: the game follows four heroes - nobles of the four houses of Armello
recommended: each alike in dignity (apart from Brun
hoursPlayed: who smells like a swamp) - who have decided to take the throne for their house after the current king is afflicted by madness and sickness stemming from a curse called The Rot. Each day
voteText: the King slips deeper into madness
helpfulPercent: issuing edcits that become increasingly unhinged to inconvenience the players as they quest across Armello
votesHelpful: and each night The Rot twists him deeper into darkness
votesTotal: causing monstrous Banes to spawn from dungeons and roam the land murdering and pillaging as they go.\n\nThere are four victory types in Armello: heroes can win with Prestige by questing across Armello
votesFunny: slaying monsters - and each other - to win the favour of the people and be named the king's sucessor when he dies from The Rot. They can get a Wyld victory by finding the four Spirit Stones and using them to purge The Rot from the king
commentsCount: saving the kingdom from darkness. Or perhaps their motives are more sinister... they can storm the palace and slay the king for a Coup victory
column16: seizing power by force - or they can embrace The Rot themselves
column17: becoming horrifying monsters weilding dark magics
column18:
killing the king and devouring his soul to win a Rot victory and plunge Armello into darkness...

THE GOOD:
* 8 Playable characters - 2 from each House - each with their own unique
column19: game-changing ability
column20: with more to come\n* Amazingly atmospheric sound design and music to help immerse yourself in the setting
column21: with music that changes to react to what's going on.\n* Adaptive
column22: atmospheric map - at night as stones are gathered fog rolls in over the moors
column23:
the sun rises and sets creating shadows and bathing the map in amber light before giving away to night in the Day/Night mechanic
* 4 Story-driven Prologue missions to teach you game mechanics without cramming it down your throat - take about half an hour to 45 minuites to complete and leave you multiplayer ready
* Dedicated multiplayer matchmaking system that quickly finds players - rarley have to wait longer than 5 minuites or so.
* Preset messages to communicate with other players to keep things civil - each character has a unique "phrasebook" you can use to send comments to other players
* Procedurally generated maps randomises the layout of Armello each game. Two tilesets - winter and summer - keep things varied
* "Digital Board Game" mechanics are new and interesting
column24: utilising the digital setting without just being a dry port of a board game - card art is animated
column25: and the digital medium lets the game use things like stealth mechanics or asymmetrical information to give each player a different view. Dice rolling gives players a clear view of how a mechanic reached a decision without being overwhelming\n* In-game quest system to let players improve their characters over the course of a game
column26: gain items and learn more about Armello.\n* Completing games as characters and in certain ways unlocks new "rings and amulets" that change how your character plays in future game - nothing broken
column27:
just different.

THE BAD:

reviewText:
As a digital board game Armello’s goal is clear. It tries to be casual enough to allow the players to get into the game with ease, but tries to be complex enough not to let its mechanics become boring after a short period of time. The game tries to reach for a wider audience and as a competitive game it deserves one, despite some of the more annoying problems that the multiplayer has to offer.
As a newly born world and lore, Armello only teases the players with its potential leaving them wanting more. The story options are limitless and I can’t stop myself what a positive influence a story mode could have on this game.
Armello has the enchanting atmosphere of a fairy tale with the brutal gameplay of a deathmatch and the tactical decision making of a strategy, but with its fate trapped in the cage that comes with small budget indie development.


Pros:
+ Charming world
+ Awesome heroes
+ Lovely 2D animations, art style and UI design
+ Great music
+ Easy to learn
+ Good enough mechanics to stay interesting for a while


Cons:
- A small map with no configurations available
- Victory conditions aren’t properly balanced
- Slow multiplayer
- No chat
- The game is crying for a story mode

Read the full review at:
http://thegameslashers.blogspot.ro/2015/09/armello-review.html
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I bought Armello upon release, something I don't usually do (wait for patches/sales/etc), but I don't regret it.
Basically, it feels like a great board game ported to videogame world.

Pros:
- Overall great game mechanics: balanced enough so skill/experience matters, random enough to make it interesting and not pre-defined
- Dice-based combat
- You have a lot of options and strategies to pursue during your turn
- Good art (especially cards) and lore
- Flawless Linux version (single player)

Cons:
- Problems in multiplayer (see below)
- Minor flaws in the interface

OK, not for the hard part. So multiplayer clearly has some issues, and while some of them (network problems and game-stalling bugs) can be expected to be fixed in the near future, others are more tricky.

The average multiplayer game lasts 1 to 1.5 hours, and you don't have much to do during your opponents turns and game events (King's Guards and Banes) - that is, 70 to 80% of the time.
It would be perfectly ok for a BOARD game, where you can chat with your friends/fool around/do some diplomacy, but it i NOT a board game (although feels a lot like one).
You even don't have an in-game chat, only pre-defined emotes.

Some options to overcome this:
- play with friends and chat in Skype/whatever
- read Twitter/what you prefer during other players' turns
- have a beer in hand (always helps)

That being said, I still enjoyed multiplayer to a certain point, and single player is completely OK (although can get boring after 10-15 hrs).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Board game + Card abilities + RPG and Strategy elements

This may sound like a weird combination, and perhaps this game is the first of its kind... but it actually works well!
It is based on a board game of the same name. However, it seems the developers are so passionate about their project that they added some abilities and mechanics that were not present in the original board game.
Even though the game is perfectly playable and enjoyable in the current early access, they are still releasing regular updates nearly every 2 weeks. Some of these updates introduce new mechanics and remake old ones, but the overall effect is an ongoing IMPROVEMENT.

Graphics: Simple 3D graphics on the main map + animated cartoon characters. The animal characters remind me of the Disney version of Robin Hood... but even MORE charming. Don't be fooled by the cartoonish characters >> this game is suitable for all ages and has enough depth and variety that older gamers will definitely find it worth playing.

Sound: Once again, simple and elegant. The music complements the graphics and atmosphere perfectly. If you play this game, you will wish that they make a movie from it. I'm not kidding. The immersion is that solid. The main downsides here are a lack of narration and voice-acting. Some music tracks can get a little repetitive. Adding 2 or 3 more tracks would be great.

Gameplay: The game has a perfect balance of complexity and accessibility. It is easy to learn but also requires your constant attention if you want to win. You currently play against 3 other players in both single and multiplayer (4 players only). There are 4 victory conditions, all of which are related to the King's inevitable death. (as you may have heard, it's like a Disney version of Game of Thrones... except it is way better than the current Disney stuff)

In Early Access you start with 4 playable characters. Another 8 will be available in full release (according to the forums). They all feel unique and each is more suited to certain victory conditions than the others. And you can still choose your starting bonuses with amulets and rings, so there are plenty of combinations for you to experiment with. Replayability is very high and rewards you with unlocking a variety of starting bonuses.

In terms of strategy, the game is mostly about making the best out of what you have and holding on to your advantages. It is currently difficult to aim for a specific victory condition without getting lucky (especially Rot and Spirit victory). So ultimately, the Prestige victory is the most likely end-scenario, especially versus AI (who is not the smartest). Nevertheless, they recently made new additions to the Spirit victory (and added cards that will help you achieve it). So the end-game scenario is gradually being improved. I anticipate a well-balanced game at full release.

Overall, this casual yet engaging experience is recommended for anyone who enjoys Strategy/RPG and wants something more relaxing than Civ 5 every now and then. This is also a great game for families. If you want to introduce your kids to Strategy gaming and play with them, Armello is perfect for the job even in Early Access.

Early Access rating: 7/10 - worth the price

For more details, check out my Let's Play below! (NOTE: my Let's Play is from BEFORE the At Wyld's Will" update. The Spirit Victory has been changed after that update. Keep that in mind.)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MTNtWWK1m9k&list=PLP90♥♥♥lxXzg5NX8zdhXRvjRA2ysLazzf"

Definitely a fun board game with lighthearted elements and gorgeous animations.

reviewText:
Gaming culture has undergone a bit of a...well, a regression for lack of a better word. I don't think video games are becoming any less popular as a medium of entertainment, but the last couple years have seen an incredible surge in the popularity of board games. Remember board games? Those things you were forced to play with your parents once a week while they tried to coax out more details about your life in some poor attempt at family cohesiveness? Yeah, those.

But at the same time, not those. Maybe I just wasn't exposed to the geekiest possible board games when I was young, but I remember playing Monopoly and Scrabble and Life. Simple games with simple rules. But those games are nothing like what we've seen come out of the board game renaissance in the last few years. Games like Risk and Settlers of Catan (ok, arguably Chess was very much this type of game as well) set the stage for incredibly complex games like Arkham Horror, Dead of Winter and Legends of Andor, games so complex that many of them could be played cooperatively against the board rather than against each other, which is still a novel idea to this day.

Much in the same way that Hearthstone before it married card games and video games in a way that simply couldn't have been done in any other medium, Armello is very much a child of these two genres and it works very well...for the most part.

Thematically Armello acts as a sort of combination of the Redwall books - which, for the uninitiated, feature tribes of anthropomorphic animals living together in a fantasy setting - and a very watered-down Game of Thrones. The basic premise is that you are a member of one of four clans - the wolves, the rats, the rabbits and the bears - and the ruler of Armello (a lion, natch) has been taken by the rot, a sort of corruption that threatens to drive him to madness before it, eventually, claims his life. Your goal, then, is to put yourself in the best position to take the throne from him and ensure your tribe's ascent to power.

Gameplay wise, Armello is very much a board game at its core. You have a set number of moves every turn and you negotiate the map for resources including gold (to buy things, duh) and cards to empower yourself or snare up your opponents. You must win before the withering lion king's last heart of health wastes away. If no one has claimed victory before then, the person-er, animal with the most influence over the throne (measured in prestige) at the time of the king's death wins.

Combat and other conflicts - like fighting your way through one of the game's many peril" cards placed by other players or even the king to hamper your progress - is played out through rolls of the dice (many
date: many dice in some cases) in which you try to match symbols for successes - in combat
recommended: swords and shields for hits and blocks and in "perils
hoursPlayed: trying to match different symbols.\n\nIn these ways Armello is fun but not especially innovative. It doesn't so much bend the board game" genre like Hearthstone
voteText: in many ways
helpfulPercent: did with the card game genre
votesHelpful: doing things that games like Magic: The Gathering
votesTotal: in its physical medium simply couldn't. But it does it competently and with a nice veneer of paint that wouldn't have been possible on a drab board with cardboard cutouts. And keeping track of all the numbers of modifiers and cards would be a much bigger hassle in a physical medium anyways.\n\nThe one thing that Armello does that
votesFunny: while not impossible
commentsCount: would at least be difficult and unwieldy in a physical product is the implimentation of the king's "neutral" forces and the universally-hostile "banes
column16:
creatures of the rots. While clearly an antagonist, the king is more mad than hostile and while he can be turned on players for various reasons, he and his Labrador guardsmen are more obstacles and nuisances than outright enemies. He can even be manipulated into helping you in various ways. The banes, meanwhile, are a constant, AI-controlled threat that add some spice to an otherwise standard experience.

Individual games of Armello are fairly short and it would be nice if there was some level of customization to mix things up more, adding health to the constantly deteriorating king to lengthen the game perhaps even additional map sizes to mix things up a bit. But overall, they are enjoyable and nicely paced to be played in a single sitting. Unfortunately, multiple game sessions tend to feel very similar with the only variation being how you choose to attain victory, which mixes things up a bit but I predict not enough to give Armello permanently-lasting appeal.

Finally, the game can be played single-player or multiplayer. I haven't had a chance to play it with my friend yet, but I predict that multiplayer is the way to go. It can be nice to get a feel for the game in single-player mode, but the AI is easily delayed and duped. In the few games I've played so far, I've won primarily by letting time tick away and maxing out my prestige. The AI makes a bit of a clumsy attempt to claim victory but nowhere near the concerted effort a human opponent would. It almost seems to stumble around until the game is almost over and then say, oh right
column17: I actually have to try and win" before trying for the only victory criteria it can accomplish...one in which it has done very little to prepare for. The promised addition of a ranked mode is interesting but I'm not yet convinced about the competitive promise the game might have.\n\nAll in all

reviewText:
An addicting and amazing boardgame with a relatively steep learning curve.
The game has an amazing vibe, good compelling dynamics and is beautifully, masterfully crafted in order to make RNG not only competitive but not that frustrating!!

So to explain how they did that (or why I believe they did) I must first say that, I bought this game as a boardgame designer, to understand some really interesting peculiarities.
It is imbedded in RNG and as far as transparency goes, this game is not an example. So is it bad? No...

As a strong believer in pre-production and heavy design in order to combat rng and give space to balance and skill, this game showed me new possibilities for luck and uses it in a way that hasnt really been seen in Boardgames before.

Most decisions in the game, involve luck ( % ), however, it is post luck, as in, first macro decisions (where you go, what you do and so on) then micro decisions that will have luck mechanic. To illustrate: you gear your character, move him on the map and decide whether you want to engage in luck events or not. IF you do, then your gear, character info (relative to race, buffs, etc) shall weigh the outcome of the event, may it be a battle or some other encounter.

So luck serves as a weight to your moves in order to make the game more competitive and dense Strategically wise.

Furthermore, the game uses really amazing Aesthetics to brush off unecessary intensity and soothe your experience, as a hot soup blow. So when rng does get on your nerves, you will barely notice it over the amazing music, illustrations and whole experience.

The only con to the game, is the amount of info you must attend to simultaneously. Meaning that, while it does have a good UI, it uses the fact it is a digital boardgame, to incert more information than anyone could possibly process. PLus, the learning curve is indeed steep and although tutorial process is connected storywise, it is still a dull process....

All in all, this game is really really good and worth cutting through the tough leathery learning membrane.

Online games are really intense but still manage to maintain the shoothing game's vibe. 8/10

reviewText:
I have enjoyed this game, the art style, gameplay and over all idea if pretty fun. I would give it a 7/10 though, few reason which I'll give below.

Pros:
-Lovely Art Style
-Interesting play style of the old hexagon rpg table tops
-Animations are well done and fluid
-Concept of the game is imagnitive
-Multiplayer works well and tests your friendships (Who will help you or end you)
-Interesting Game mechanics, from complete dice modification, to in game affect through choices.
-Loveable and cute characters: I mean look a Barneby, He's so damn eager to bonk them.


Cons:
-No game customization (You can't alter your map experience, each map is rerolled at a set size. Ways to fix this would be allow an option of multiple map sizes, with other game alterations)
-Winning is single minded: You win by having the highest prestige, whether or not you have slayed the king or not. (Ways to fix this, Make prestige victory a draw breaker [both player and king die or king dies without a killing blow being dealt] I beleive the game could have alternative ways to win as well, fix the king, remove the rot from him, corrupt him fully, etc)
-Restricted Character: The block on the additional bandit clan almost made me not buy this, and some of my friends refunded because of this. This is a good way to hurt player base when you have a purchasable game with locked characters, if the game was FTP then it would be understandable, or if they were purchasable from a DLC (Which would be a good idea for future clans as well, or adding them in as free updates)
-Short: This game is short, if you don't love it, you'll get bored quickly.The map is as big as a small continent from Sid meiser's Civ games. Quests only go to about 5 or 6 (haven't counted persoanlly) before you get end game quest.

reviewText:
The only bad thing I could ever say, even after playing this game for several hours now, and enjoying the liveing bejesus out of it, is that I didnt know about it's kickstarter. I would have been dumping money into this.
Aside from 'shut up and take my money', I suppose I shoulld give some actual details on the game.
Its a board game, where the premis is simple. Become king/queen. Your competeing with three other heros and the current king himself at times, to do just that. The way you go about playing is all up to you. Do you build up your character before walking right up to the king and kill him man to man? Or do you politicaly bide your time, gaining the king's favor and eventualy when he dies, the crown.
The board on wich you play is new every time. This coupled with the fact that there are eight characters currently (supposivly more in the future) means that each game can be entirely diffrent. I look forward to seeing what they do with this game.
A note to the devs if only for the giggles, a playable vulpine character of any sort. Seriously, I will chuck money at that if I have to. I'm already bummed I missed the chance to support your kickstarter.
