reviewText:
Early Access Review

Board game + Card abilities + RPG and Strategy elements

This may sound like a weird combination, and perhaps this game is the first of its kind... but it actually works well!
It is based on a board game of the same name. However, it seems the developers are so passionate about their project that they added some abilities and mechanics that were not present in the original board game.
Even though the game is perfectly playable and enjoyable in the current early access, they are still releasing regular updates nearly every 2 weeks. Some of these updates introduce new mechanics and remake old ones, but the overall effect is an ongoing IMPROVEMENT.

Graphics: Simple 3D graphics on the main map + animated cartoon characters. The animal characters remind me of the Disney version of Robin Hood... but even MORE charming. Don't be fooled by the cartoonish characters >> this game is suitable for all ages and has enough depth and variety that older gamers will definitely find it worth playing.

Sound: Once again, simple and elegant. The music complements the graphics and atmosphere perfectly. If you play this game, you will wish that they make a movie from it. I'm not kidding. The immersion is that solid. The main downsides here are a lack of narration and voice-acting. Some music tracks can get a little repetitive. Adding 2 or 3 more tracks would be great.

Gameplay: The game has a perfect balance of complexity and accessibility. It is easy to learn but also requires your constant attention if you want to win. You currently play against 3 other players in both single and multiplayer (4 players only). There are 4 victory conditions, all of which are related to the King's inevitable death. (as you may have heard, it's like a Disney version of Game of Thrones... except it is way better than the current Disney stuff)

In Early Access you start with 4 playable characters. Another 8 will be available in full release (according to the forums). They all feel unique and each is more suited to certain victory conditions than the others. And you can still choose your starting bonuses with amulets and rings, so there are plenty of combinations for you to experiment with. Replayability is very high and rewards you with unlocking a variety of starting bonuses.

In terms of strategy, the game is mostly about making the best out of what you have and holding on to your advantages. It is currently difficult to aim for a specific victory condition without getting lucky (especially Rot and Spirit victory). So ultimately, the Prestige victory is the most likely end-scenario, especially versus AI (who is not the smartest). Nevertheless, they recently made new additions to the Spirit victory (and added cards that will help you achieve it). So the end-game scenario is gradually being improved. I anticipate a well-balanced game at full release.

Overall, this casual yet engaging experience is recommended for anyone who enjoys Strategy/RPG and wants something more relaxing than Civ 5 every now and then. This is also a great game for families. If you want to introduce your kids to Strategy gaming and play with them, Armello is perfect for the job even in Early Access.

Early Access rating: 7/10 - worth the price

For more details, check out my Let's Play below! (NOTE: my Let's Play is from BEFORE the At Wyld's Will" update. The Spirit Victory has been changed after that update. Keep that in mind.)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MTNtWWK1m9k&list=PLP90♥♥♥lxXzg5NX8zdhXRvjRA2ysLazzf"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW

As an avid play of board games, tabletop RPGs, and computer games, Armello was an obvious choice to try. A very beautiful game with a lot of care and craft put into it so far, but not without its problems.

PROS:

- The artwork is amazing, making even the humdrum activities like running into perils (traps set by other players or npcs) or picking out items sublime. This alone is worth the purchase IMO.

- The blend between board game and computer game is carried out well. While on the surface Armello may appear to be an adaptation of a board game for computers, what with the map, the dice, the cards, etc., the automation of the game format allows complex rules and events to be streamlined in a way no board game could reproduce smoothly. It manages to be both casual and relaxed while still involving the players and suspending disbelief.

- The graphics are not only serviceable but quite nice to look at. The aesthetic is strong visually, and there's very little clutter. The models for the characters and npcs are very faithful to the art.

- The sound, while not spectacular, is pleasant and fits the thematic elements of the game nicely. After hearing the music over the dozen or so games I've played I can still say that it's not grating.

CONS:

- The price point of $25 is a bit steep if you ask me. Perhaps it's just because it's still early access that I feel this way, but for those of us on a tight budget it's a shame to have to hold off on purchasing such a beautiful game for want of funds.

- Understanding that this is still early access, I can't help but feel that, after 18 hours of playing this game, it's starting to wear a tad thin. They do release updates fairly regularly, adding new cards and quests, but it is starting to feel repetitive.

There's only one game mode and right now only four characters. This means that every game of Armello will run pretty much the same way, with some variations. Apparently four more characters are coming with the full release (in fall maybe), but I'm not sure that even that will be enough to get me to invest another 18 hours. Generally the game follows one of three possible outcomes (prestige victory, spirit stone victory, or killing the king), with the same time limit every game based on the king's deteriorating health. Personal quests vary the game quite a bit, but often you can only get one or two done before the game's conclusion.

I would like to see the introduction of optional modifiers. Perhaps options to extend the game, or perhaps team-based play could help the repetition. Or maybe different ending objectives, such as we see in Talisman, could improve replay value. Something like a bane-rush mode, where Banes spawn more rapidly, or where players work cooperatively to repel them.

CONCLUSION:

This game has its problems, but I don't hesitate to recommend it. Quite possibly the most beautiful game I've ever played. It plays to the strength of the board-game style while keeping things smooth and exciting with the speed of a computer game. However, don't expect to get it on sale before full release; the devs have specifically stated that they do not intend to put the game on sale any time soon.

Early Access Review

Armello is worth buying if you're looking for a game that you don't always have to pay attention to and don't mind the fact that there's a lot of luck involved. On the other hand, you probably won't like the game if you're looking for something to test your skill in since even if you play to the best of your abilities, the player that did the worst the whole game can still come out as the winner.

Each match lasts about 30-45 minutes.

reviewText: This is my first review on steam. I have played about 80 hours on the game and have probably unlocked all the rings, each game taking about an hour or so. I bought this game out of curiosity since the graphics were just amazing to look at. The sound impressed me as well. What I like about it is that it is a friendly game that doesn't have in game chat. It kind of hinders the social experience of the game but keeps it civil, instead having the built in text to choose from. This game has an interesting concept of having four ways to win which is rot victory, highest prestige, 4 spirit stones, and defeating the king. It's really fun how there are lots of ways to win and kill your opponents. There is a lot of strategy going on, such as skill cards, magic cards, and trap cards. You must go on with your quest while defeating your enemies and winning by one of the four victories. There is a lot going on in this game. The dice is also an excellent touch, since it allows you to click on it randomly which allows it to be fair aND challenging. Beware that although I do recommend this game, there are still more developments that should be made. Such as when the Internet connection is loss, you are automatically kicked out and cannot join the same game. Penalties for leaving games should be longer since it destroys the overall game play of having to play with AL players. Ranked matches are also not availible yet. Overall I recommend this game despite its ongoing developments because it is visually satisfying and fun.

reviewText:
You don't just need Armello now, this game was needed ten years ago. Armello brings me back to a simpler time when gaming felt like an excursion in to another realm. And here, with the help of the other Armellians and even some multiplayer companions, I can escape into that realm.

The music is so intensely beautiful that I sought out the soundtrack via Armello.com.
The visuals harken to Redwall with a color pallette that looks like a fairy tale of paint and bloom.
The gameplay is so quick to grab onto and satisfying that you'll lose hours to it as you perfect strategies.

I could say so many things and I've reviewed this game once already online but I will say that this game deserves the meager price in which it's offered and don't let the Early Access scare you away -- this game is as polished as you could expect from a full release and is being updated regularly.

Not enough love can be expressed for Armello. It deserves evangelizing.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I have trouble finding the words to do Armello justice. It is a wonderfully thought up board game, but developed to be played in a digital format, as a result it can do things that tabletop boardgames just can't. Players using stealth vanish from the board, there are neutral 'characters' who have their own agendas in game, the game itself is very carefully crafted and cleverly put together to be interesting and gets very challenging if you go online.

But all of this is secondary to the one thing that League of Gamers utterly nailed, and that is the theme. The aesthetic of Armello is a joy to behold, from the serene looking map and hauntingly simple but evocative background tunes to the cheery character designs and battle animations and card art that will make you want to stop and take the time to appreciate it from time to time.

Okay, sure, the AI players are a little easy and finding a game online can be a little difficult depending on your time zone and when you're looking, but there is still development going on and content being added, with the Bandit clan DLC on it's way and recent 'the stranger' update shaking up the ruleset a little, it seems hopeful that we'll see some more expansions and further improvements to an already wonderful game.

Highly recommended to any lovers of board games.

reviewText:
I'm over 100 hours into Armello now, mostly in multi-player.  The game is a real hidden gem; it's fun, it's cheap to buy, and it's still getting cool new stuff added to it.

I enjoy the competition and wild unpredictability of multi player mode the most, but be warned: it's a turn-based game, and sometimes you get a player or two that is reeeeeeally slooooow at taking their turns, which really ruins the game flow.

I think as time goes on, you'll be seeing mostly players who are pretty quick at taking their turns though. It's the noobs who tend to agonize and overthink their turns, somehow not noticing that the biggest factor is simply your dice rolls.  And once the current sale is over, I think we'll be seeing a lot less noobs.

For sheer fun, and cartoon animal silliness, Armello is a definite 10/10. And if slow turns get you down, there's always single player, which plays VERY fast. Almost too fast, because AI opponents love to try to kill the king and end the game ASAP. Make sure you're always #1 in Prestige ranking when you do single-player, cuz often the AI opponents aren't even close to being geared enough to kill the king and survive, so the winner ends up being the player with the highest Prestige.

reviewText:
First: Game is exceptional and worth every dollary, so I have to recommend.

Howver: There are some frustrations. Perhaps I'm not understanding everything yet, but success or lack of failure rather, seems to boil down to minimizing attrition, because unless you have substantial gear/followers,  you are very suseptable to to being killed in one encounter.  This is due to the variability of dice/cards and the numerous modifiers within the game.  Even at full health, with some good cards, your not safe. This makes early game survival critical as heroes are going be getting sent home frequently.  Making matters worse is the variability of the cards and drawing a hand full of cards you cant use.  Sure, you can burn uneeded cards and lock rolls, but I seem to need to do that far more frequently than I'd expect.  Its easy to get discouraged when, no matter what you do, no matter what options you choose, there is little chance of success, and no real option other than restarting.  This makes the prospect of online match-made games pretty grim, as players will quit in the first few turns as soon as someone has a clear advantage.  Perhaps I just suck and don't get it yet, but before they dumped money into the beautifull, triple-A assets,  they should have playtested the crap out of the game in a physical version to expose what feel like game ballance issues.  On the otherhand, I'm going to continue playing, becuase it's presentation is so slick, I'm optimisitic the frustrations I have so far are just because I'm no good.

reviewText:
Armello, where League of Geeks truly brought tabletop adventures to life.

This is a game that I've been waiting for so long as a Kickstarter backer, and now that I got to experience it I can say with all the confidence in the world that it was definitely worth the wait.

Beautiful aesthetics and a very very simple playstyle that even the youngest of the family can sit down and enjoy with ease.

While RNG plays a huge role in this game it never feels like it's out of control. (Excluding some wyld die explosions)

The game is quite versatile, it has 4 different victory conditions, a robust cast of characters and each also has further customization options with rings and amulets that makes each one of the very vast number of possible combinations feel unique and it changes the playstyle quite a lot, making each game feel (and play) differently.

There are a few parts to touch on however, even if the game has a huge amount of character customization it lacks settings for the game itself, unable of setting a longer or shorter duration of the game (by modifying the initial health of the King) or even changing the size of the map.

The single player game while it's (very) fun you won't find any difficulty modifiers, so if you're looking for a challenge I'd suggest you to play with friends who have experience with the game instead. The AI controlled units are decent, after a few games you can start predicting their patterns if you pay attention to their moves, also sometimes they make some very questionable (or well... just plain dumb) decisions so there's that.

With all this said, right now it's early on the game's life and so far I'm amazed by every aspect of it. Can't wait to see what else LoG will do with this gem.

I hope this review is helpful to you.

I give this game 8/10 in its current state, seriously consider buying and playing it with some friends.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Besides the fact that this is a digital depiction of the original Armello board game, it's quite a great mash-up of Board Game / CCG Card Game / RPG and story / quest driven entertainment. Constantly adding new features, cards, characters, unlockables and quests. I won't say much more because, I don't want to spoil ANY of the features and game play. I, myself, own a low-end laptop PC and the game, before starting all the animations and itself, alered itself to operate optimally outside it's available graphics settings, in order for me to be able to play (SUBJECT TO CHANGE due to developments; I can no longer run this fantasic game now, but do not let that detour you from purchasing this game at all, still a very fantastic title; make sure you meet ALL the minimum system requirements before purchasing this [edit added:8/12/15]). LoG definately is immersing us ALL into this title to make it a community favorite and keep us happy. I foresee this game becoming a Cult Classic" in the future.
~11/10 Burns~"

reviewText:
Armello is a thematic combination of Game of Thrones and Redwall and as a digital board game its very hard to not enjoy each of your turns as there's almost always something you can do. It is a very polished and enjoyable game. That said I do have some things that bother me about it.

It becomes slightly tedious watching each other players' turns at the same speed as you take yours and the veiw limitations of the game board seem strange when veiwing through a large monitor. This essentially means you are spending 3/4 of your time playing the game watching your opponents (if you can see them). While it is valuable that you pay attention to what your opponents do, sometimes it becomes a chore. The other issue is how the board will not allow you to zoom out and see more of it, and when you try it becomes blurry and unfocused. This gives me a sort of magnifying glass feeling when trying to look at the board as a whole.

I am eagerly looking forward to any DLC or changes that they make to this game to improve on these faults and polish this gem of a game. If the Developers are reading this, I humbly suggest adding more characters/clans and customization to the player.

reviewText:
Pros:
+ Fun
+ Strategy and planning
+ Different characters with different skills
+ Unique board game style
+ 4 ways of winning the game (more fun)
+ Short tutorial (easy to understand)
+ Can overturn game in a move

Cons:
- Lacked of players (hard to find games for multiplayer)
- If a player leaves in multiplayer, need to wait for timer to go off before skipping him/her
- Ranked game not yet implemented (maybe cause of lacking players)

Overall:
Good game whether with friends or single player. Able to pass time.

Rate:
8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

**Edit since the new update**

** Edit** I really love the new updates that they've given to the game -- the quests now lead you right up to the castle to defeat the king -- giving you at least a chance to be able to confront him or not. New cards have been added. And after a few playthroughs, the cards have become quite strategic in countering your rivals or enhancing yourself. A subtle thing that I love is the day descending into night and vice versa. As your turn begins, it is the very break of day and as each player takes their turn, it gets darker and darker until actual evening. I really like that. My love of the actual game is starting to lean towards actual fun and recommendation. :) If they keep enhancing it more, I can see Armello being something truly special. ** Edit **

I don't think I can mask my disappointment with Armello. I seen the previews, I love anything with animals and love RPG's and card games. I guess, in my excitement for something new, that I glossed over the board game" aspect of it. That's what Armello is -- a digital board game.

The story is very intrigueing and I love it. I love anything new and different. But
date: with just a digital board game aspect

hoursPlayed: gain more rot than the king and battle him

votesHelpful: performing either acts of good deeds or not. You are given three choices to make and each choice will get you a different result. Perhaps this was the rpg aspect they were advertising. Or maybe it's the table top aspect that was completely lost on me.\n\nThe card game aspect feels like an add on. Again

reviewText:
A non-biased quick look @ the game:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Zg6OSK09vUU

If Walt Disney was in charge of making a Game of Thrones style Might and Magic game, this would be it. Armello is a grand swashbuckling adventure that combines three styles of play; The deep tactics of card games with the rich strategy of table top board games, combined with a character role-playing system.

As a hero from one of the clans of Armello, you'll quest, scheme, hire agents, explore, vanquish monsters, cast spells and face off against other players, with one ultimate end goal in mind — storming the palace and becoming King or Queen of Armello. The Kingdom of Armello is as dangerous as it is beautiful, perils, banes and bandits hide around every corner and a spreading corruption known as the rot is leaving no creature untouched.

Armello is League of Geeks’ attempt to revolutionise digital board and card games, whilst providing players a rich world within which they can craft their own stories of epic adventure. The aim was to create a rich game full of backstabbing, close shaves, shattered alliances, ruses and empty promises - a perfect game to play with your friends. - Highly Recommended!

reviewText:
This is somewhat of a hard review for me to write. Do I recommend this game? In some ways, yes! I love the game. I love it too much. I've been involved with it from Day 1 back on Kickstarter. I love the art and the premise and I feel like playing it every day.

However, here are the reasons that I have uninstalled this game with a heavy heart:

I've played several games of Armello, some multiplayer and some single player (Note: more than what Steam quotes, as I have a different version from Kickstarter). The major flaws at this point are evident. One, in every single game I have been able to finish, the game has been won by the Prestige Leader. Every other victory condition is unbelievably hard to attain and I have never seen it done. As noted in a previous review, getting stuck in an endless cycle of dying and restarting is rampant and extremely difficult to break out of, which leads to the game timing out before anyone can achieve anything. In literally every game I have played, I have set out with the intention of winning with Spirit Stones, and while I have no problem getting enough of them, getting to the king is impossible with this endless cycle of dying.

Now, onto more clerical problems. In each game I have played (literally every one), something or a lot of things have gone wrong with the running of the game. In two or three, my Gold counter has gotten stuck at a certain number and I have no idea how much I have to work with. I don't know if it is logging my newly acquired Gold, but when I try to use a card, it will always tell me I cannot afford it, despite sometimes saying I have 12 Gold even. I have run into a couple of games where it will freeze so to speak and the characters are just in a constant loop of fighting
date: but the game does not progress. This has been documented by two of my Steam friends as well. Two or three times, I have had friends kicked off the server and the game has been restarted automatically. The gameplay and music/sound effects often lag (like, almost always) and are choppy (even with turning down the resolution, shutting down all other processes on my computer, and changing to a more powerful computer). I have had a couple instances when playing multiplayer that a countdown clock will never appear on the player screen, or we will be stuck in an all-ready" screen with nothing happening.\n\nWhile attempting to play with my friends
recommended: they are asking: "Is this game in early access!?" Unfortunately
hoursPlayed: it kind of feels that way. The minute a patch is released to fix these gameplay issues
voteText: I will be re-installing this game
helpfulPercent: because it is honestly my love right now. My recommendation is that you will want this game. Hard. But right now
votesHelpful: maybe it needs a pass for a little while."
votesTotal: April 9

reviewText:
I want to love this game, I really do. It's just that it's held back by absurdly clunky UI, lack of graphical options, and the fact that stat-boosting items are progression locked for some inexplicable reason. While the game's atmosphere and its core mechanics are interesting, it's just bogged down by its appalling execution. There is a strange lack of borderless windowed in the video options and there is no way to turn off the clouds above the game board if you try to zoom out. There isn't even a way to look at the whole board, nor does the in-game UI give any at-a-glance information. Instead, you are stuck clicking in and out of menus just trying to keep track of each player's information.

The gameplay itself is incredibly boring, even by board gaming standards. Eighty percent of the time is spent waiting for things to happen, only interspersed with several seconds of dice rolling, reformulating strategy, or watching the AI take its turn. Even the amount of RNG in the game is exceptionally high. While granted, there are several ways to reduce the RNG required, the sheer number of times it comes up-- spawning enemies, loot tables, King's choices, perils, dungeons-- puts it way over the top. The card decks are heavily watered down with seemingly no copies of cards, meaning that the chance of drawing specific cards in order to avoid RNG or simply be useful are slim. The only way to remove useless cards from your hand is to blindly charge into perils or combat in order to 'burn' them.

If you want a strategy game, look elsewhere. If you're into dice-rolling and short trips to your local Taco Bell but can't afford to play Warhammer 40k, then this is the game for you.

reviewText:
Let me start by saying the game is not bad but I cannot recommend it until they balance out the victory conditions.

As it is only one victory type is viable although there are 3 or 4? possible. This destroys the game's replayability. The game has limited turns and all the mechanics for a non-prestige victory take you too long and are really hard compared with the faceroll of the prestige victory.

It looks beautiful, it is a great concept but it failed the playtesting for balance IMO.

Buy on discount or wait until you hear victory conditions have been balanced.

reviewText:
Beautiful game with an interesting cast of characters to choose from. The game reminds me somewhat of a game of Risk but while having it's own set of rules, gameplay elements and identity.

I am not a huge fan of these type of games but playing Armello in short bites ( 1 or 2 games depending on how long the matches are ) really makes want to comeback the next day and play another match or 2.

All of the designs are lovely and feels alive with the little animations on the cards and in combat. Music is fantastic as well.

With the devs actively looking for feed back and with more content on the way, i can safely say that Armello is a game worth to be explored.

reviewText:
I read a lot of Red Wall when I was a kid because I wasn't really too interested in Harry Potter or all that nonsense. Uh. Not sure how that's -exactly- relevant? But it is. Armello's been an amazing experience that I'm trying to currently push on my friends. To note: This -is- basically an videogame boardgame, but it's super fun, and the animation is smooth. The tactics are varied and interesting, and there's a lot of room for risky play. Anyways, I'm probably more coherent when I hate a game. It's hard to praise a game as much as I have, so I'll get to the cons:
-There's only one game board.
-There's a pretty small character selection.

That's uh, about it. That and turns can take a little long, but that's okay when you're doing singleplayer anyways, because you can just turn on quickturns. I'd really love it if the developer considered DLC addons for maps and characters. I would definitely buy both. I'd be happy to support a developer that's made a wonderful game like this, anyways.

reviewText: I love the art and music and the general feel of the game but I agree with the other posters that the game mechanic is definitely broken. There are supposed to be four different ways to win the game but the way it is today, the game usually ends in ~20 turns when the king dies and that is not enough turns to win by any other means except by a prestige victory. So, after you've played it a few times you realize there isn't enough depth to keep playing.\n\nToo bad, because otherwise it's a really good game.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
The artwork is beautiful, the gameplay is easy to learn (but not easy to master by any stretch of the imagination) and the dice mechanic is more fun than just rolling regular numbers.

4 different ways to win: Collect 4 Spirit Stones, kill the King, kill the king while your Rot is higher than his, or have the highest prestige.

8 characters: Two rats (a manipulator and an assassin), two rabbits (a tinker and explorer), two bears (a warrior and a druid) and two wolves (one melee, one ranged) with multiple playstyles depending on which amulets you pick at the start of the game.

The only downside is no chat function other than the preprogrammed phrases. Not going to be either, according to the devs (they don't want to have to moderate, etc). It's also a -little- slow paced, but that's good if you like a relaxing strategy game for a couple of hours a game.

reviewText: Armello is better than most boardgames brought to pc.  It is a unique hybrid that has elements of board games and strictly PC RPGs.   It is not a couch party game (at least not yet) -- not sure if it would work or not since it has a stealth element.  Controller support in-game is nice for SteamOS (though you can't  navigate menu yet).  I think it is a better version of Wizwar or Talisman (more stratedy and ways to win) though there is still some luck/badluck that can frustrate or make you jump for joy.\n\nOverall, I have tried many Early Access games and many seem to progress very slow.  I would put Armello at the top of the list for customer support, updates, dev team, ect.  (alongside Brawlhalla); I am thoroughly impressed.

reviewText:
Armello is an incredibly original and refreshing experience.

Combining boardgame strategy with roleplay mechanics in a fairy tale ambiance, the game has this unique aura that won't leave you indifferent.

There are a few different characters, each having its own features and specificities, and four different ways to win the game that will require you to adapt to the unpredictable events happening on the board. Even after hours spent playing, I still haven't unlocked everything and I just can't stop launching new games because this is just too much fun.

You should definitely make a stop by this enchanted kingdom. Not sure you'll manage to leave though.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Love this game to death with a nice community and a lovely game. There are some quirks to it but that's quickly overshadowed by all the fun you have playing the game. For starters:

This is a turned based game that has a lot of cool mechanics which are and are not limited to:

Mana usage - Cast spells on opponents during your turn and on someone elses turn (can't target players that is taking their turn)
Money usage - Funds the perils and trickery cards which turn the battle for Armello in your favor
Perils which are traps
Different character types and abilities for each of the clans united by the King
A generator map that is different everytime you play it.

This game is really fun but the core of the game is how you're suppose to win. There are 4 ways of winning the game.

1. Win by Prestige. Most common winning method by my experience. You pretty much do good deeds and kill enemy heroes and banes. You can also complete the quests.
2. Win by King Kill. Go into the Palace and kill the king to win the game!
3. Win by Spirit Stone. After stepping into the Palace, you can win instantly by exiling the king.
4. Win by Rot. Compete against the King to whoever is the most corrupted. You gain additonal die for having a higher rot score.

There are different ways of playing the game, but why don't you buy it and try it yourself? It's 20 bucks and well worth the amount of money being put into the game.

Do you like fairy tails? And Game of Thrones? And Boardgames? Great.

Are you someone that just tries to ♥♥♥♥ off everyone when you are losing? Yes? Even better.

Armello is then the right game for you. And not just for you, but for everyone that enjoys an excellent strategy-board game in which you can really feel the sweat & heart the developers put in.

I can say for sure, that it is my underdog of the year.

reviewText: This is a real piece of work. I love board game concept mixed with a Game-of-Thronesesque range of tactics. If Game of Thrones were an animated series with animals as the main characters, then this is roughlythe equivalent of the board game version you would have gotten. reviewText:
BASICALLY ITS REDWALL IN VIRTUAL TABLETOP RPG FORM. Both the 8 year old and the 18 year old in me are giddy with joy!
So to start I'll sum up what is generally not well liked by pretty much everyone and get that out of the way. Firstly, nearly everything in this game is in some way randomly generated. I could explain the systems and what I think were the design choices that led to the extreme amount of RNG in this game but it really isn't worth the time. Suffice to say that the one consistent element in the game is the number of tile you can move on a given turn.

There have also been what I see as contradictory complaints about the game being too long to be fun and too short to be playable. I fundamentally disagree with both of these assessments on the grounds that A) I have only had difficulty achieving one play style after less that a days worth of play and B) a game will last you less than an hour to complete when something like irl Dungeons and Dragons will take like three just to get from town to town and a grand strategy game like any of the Civ games can take multiple days to finish on lengthier settings. And to be clear, I mean the game will take less that an hour because the game has what is effectively countdown clock built into the game with the way that the king (the victory condition in this game) works. Basically, the game ends when he dies and he is already on the way out the door by the time the game starts.

Secondly, There is, at this time, not exactly a wealth of content available. THIS DOES NOT MEAN THAT YOU WILL PLAY THE GAME ONCE AND BE DONE WITH IT. What it means is that there is effectively one game mood and one map. What keeps the game fresh, in my opinion, is the very randomness that some people seem to distain. From what I have seen on the forums accessed from within the game, they are still actively working on bring more playable characters into the game and genuinely seem interested in improving the game with time. As for maps and game modes, I haven't seen any developments of note. In my personal opinion, the game is well worth its price as is but that is a very personal evaluation I leave up to you.

If these are concerns for you, you may wish to avoid this game, at least for the time being.

Otherwise, EVERYTHING ABOUT THIS GAME IS AN ABSOLUTE JOY.

The art is lovely in a way that I won't even attempt to describe. It manages to be both whimsical (prob mispelled) and sufficiently, well not exactly bleak but fitting for the sort of dark fantasy game that they were going for.

The RPG elements, which I admit are a tad simplistic, are very rewarding if you take the time to read the in game text, consider you actions through the lens of you character, and put in the smallest effort to care about what your doing. In short, use your imagination for 5 seconds. Its good for you. There is some RPG style progression and a wealth of collectables of extremely high quality (such as animated cards that you unlock for viewing after being played) and trinkets to change the way each kingdoms champions play after you have used them multiple times.

I personally love the gameplay. Note that I say this as someone that plays Dungeons and Dragons semi-regularly and has absolutely no problem waiting for 15 minutes while Sir Mixalot (actual name of friend's character) makes a decision as to what song he is going to play and then roles like thirty dice just to see if it all amounts to anything meaningful. Yes, it is undoubtably slow as a result of there being no way to skip the AI's turns and it is most certainly very random. However, it is not the total cluster that some of the negative reviews might lead you to think. Each character has certains stats at which he or she is better equiped to use. If you pay attention, you might even pick up on the fact that each of the 4 kingdoms is designed to be better at a certain type of victory condition, of which there are 4. And when I say might have noticed, I mean play throught he tutorial up until the point where the game literally tells you which victory each of the AI players are going for and which you should aim for. If that wasn't a big enough clue, maybe just put on your thinking cap an realize that trying to win a game by killing a lion as a rabbit is probably not the best course of action. It's a lot like rock, paper, scissors except this time with fatal" consequences.

Also
date: not that this is the biggest thing to note
recommended: but the music is very pleasent. I'm not talking like Bastion levels of amazing or even Skyrim levels of IS THIS EPIC ENOUGH FOR YOU. It's more subtle and relaxed in a sort of "what if Game of Thrones didn't make you have an minor heart attack everytime you watch" sort of way (note that I do realize that a great deal of GoT is just people talking at each other and not all that eventful).\n\nONE LAST WORD OF CAUTION: I do think that a large part of my personal enjoyment of this particular game comes from the theme and setting. When I was a younger
hoursPlayed: I read a great deal of the "Redwall" series by Brian Jacques that I mentioned at the beginning of this review. It is in no way an understatement to say that these book made me love to read. I can really explain what it was about them as a whole that I responded to but I know that
voteText: by shear virtue of the easy parallels between the books and this game
helpfulPercent: that Armello stirred within me many of the emotions and affections that struck me as a child while reading the collective works of Mr. Jacques. If you
votesHelpful: like me have any fondness for those book I highly recommend giving this game at least a cursory glance before passing it up. If you don't then go read any book from the Redwall series right now
votesTotal: or at the very least keep them in mind if your looking for something to gift to an 8 to 12 year old. I say all of this as an admission of bias. Please do take it into consideration.\n\nSo to sum this whole thing up
votesFunny: if the idea of midieval furry simulator 2015 sounds the least bit interesting to you
commentsCount: give this a chance.\n\nForgive any spelling or grammar error you might find in this thing. I wrote it at 1 in the morning."

reviewText:
Here's my two cents on this game:

- Really beautiful graphics, great gameplay.
- 8 characters to play from, all with unique abilities and differing stats but even the weakest can be the strongest.
- Win in 4 different ways or be like me: Kill king's guards cause they're standing on my quest (._.)
- Sabotage your opponents and laugh like a maniacal mastermind. (Even better when they're so close to winning)
- Then get sabotaged in return (Sucks when you're so close to winning)
- Dice rolls, mhmmm, don't even let me start on that. Unique but still partially dependent on your luck xD (RNG !@!%@!)

Additional stuff:
- I do get this weird rough-ish sort of sound in game and sometimes it gets a little annoying (not that it affects the entire gameplay anyway).
- Game might be still a little buggish (or maybe it's just my PC's issue x.x) but developers are quick to respond xD.

TLDR;
Great game, should try getting it if it's on discount if you feel the price is a bit eheh. Not that type of game which you can play for 5 hours straight, a game or two a day with friends makes it all the better xD. If you're not the board game type of person, might not be entirely worth it to get it at full price but it's a great way to spend time with friends, so do give it a try :D

9/10-ish. Hopefully the developers add a little more content (maybe expand the map and add more winning conditions or allow more players?), but it's still a job well done xD.

reviewText:
Armello is a mostly turn-based strategy game played with up to 4 players. Your ultimate goal is to overthrow the Mad King and restore peace to the land. Or rule over it with an iron paw; this game isn't about what comes after, but the hard-fought journey to it. It is a fresh take in the turn-based genre, where you don't simply go from point A to point B and finish first. You must use this strange land as a tool to build up and achieve victory through combat, magicks, or trickery (usually a combo of all three!). Each player chooses a hero each with their own passive ability and allocation of stat points. Afterwards, you choose a ring, granting an ability based on what clan they hail from. Then an amulet from a shared set that can boost a stat by 1 or make a particular victory condition slightly easier to obtain.

Dice appear in combat and perils (traps that require the dice to match symbols), where you either hit, miss, or defend. Each shield blocks one hit, where misses are 33% likely, hits are 50% likely, and shields are merely 1/6 likely. Attacks are resolved at the same time, so mutual kills can often happen unless you were geared up defensively. I don't feel this is a flaw exactly, just a design that requires player understanding and adjusting accordingly. However, you can guarantee certain dice rolls by burning your cards, matching its symbol on the top-right.

Card decks are used whenever you start your turn and draw new cards up to your Wits stat. You may choose from Items (healing, equipment, movement), Magic (stat buffs, teleportation, peril spells), and Trickery (traps, resource stealing, sabotage). While you are free to pick, your ideal choice lies with your character, position on the board, and time of day. Almost nightfall and you still have some magic? Draw a spell and use it up before you receive more for free. Have a lot of settlements under control? Draw trickery and take advantage of your discount per owned town.

I say it is mostly a turn-based game, in that you can play cards during other player turns. You can equip items to prepare for a potential battle, use buffing magic cards, play perils on the board, even teleport off-turn. While you cannot use a spell directly onto a player currently moving, you can still place traps in their way. Overall, this is the best time to modify or cement the strategy to be used on your next turn, rather than always being bored waiting for the three other players.

The rule of four numbers" is a reoccurring theme in this game. There are four hero clans: Wolf

There are different ways of playing the game, but why don't you buy it and try it yourself? It's 20 bucks and well worth the amount of money being put into the game.

reviewText:
Let me start with some simple pros and cons before giving a more comprehensive review:

Pros:
1)  Easy to pick up and learn with a comprehensive tutorial.

2)  Multiplayer that lets you play with a dedicated group of frieds or random strangers.  (Plus a solid singleplayer experience for when you're antisocial or your friends are away.)

3)  Procedurally generated maps mean every board is different.

4)  With eight different characters and a variety of customization items to select before the game starts you'll quickly find a style of play you love.

5)  Rewards extra customization itmes based on who you play and how.  (Let's face it, we all love customizing things.)

6)  It's pretty to look at, which never hurts.

Cons:
1)  When playing single-player the AI sometimes makes some quirky decisions...  Like walking through a swamp before attacking someone and consequently losing a fight it might have survived.

2)  The Prestige Leader vicotry condition is a little odd in cases of a tie.  Several hours and a dozen games later and I'm still no entirely sure how it picks a leader in the case of a tie...  That being said in this game ties don't last long at all.

The Overview:
Armello is a beautifully rendered boardgame that is easy to pick up and learn but deliciously difficult to master.  You may gear yourself up with a particualr victory in mind (there are four different ways to win afterall) but quickly find that your plan isn't falling into place they way you had hoped.  This is the kind of game that rewards opportunists, flexible thinkers, and clever tacticians.
The entire game is played on a hexagonal board and you spend your turn moving, collecting cards that give you powerful items, spells, or tricks you can use to hamper or kill your enemies, and possibly fighing off the king's guards, banes, or other players through dice rolling.  Fulfilling quests boosts your stats and grant generous rewards so you'll constantly be trying to plot the best route from A to B.  Your final objective is to overcome the corruption in the land represented by the king by either killing him, cleansing him, becoming the new king of corruption (and also killing him) or by becoming the most famous hero in the land and succeeding the king upon his death.  The king draws closer to his demise every sunrise so you'll constantly be racing the clock to amass your power and wrestle victory away from the other players.
Also all the characters are represented by animals, which is kind of neat and gives the whole thing a Redwall meets Game of Thrones kind of feel.  This game is wildly fun, deceptively challenging, and has immense replay value.  All in all this is a fantastic game I would recommend to anyone who loves boardgames or games that reward you for being quick on your feet and flexible in your planning.  Best played with one or two friends once you've mastered the game concepts but as I said, the solo play is strong with this one.  Enjoy!

reviewText:
The artwork is beautiful, the gameplay is easy to learn (but not easy to master by any stretch of the imagination) and the dice mechanic is more fun than just rolling regular numbers.

4 different ways to win: Collect 4 Spirit Stones, kill the King, kill the king while your Rot is higher than his, or have the highest prestige.

8 characters: Two rats (a manipulator and an assassin), two rabbits (a tinker and explorer), two bears (a warrior and a druid) and two wolves (one melee, one ranged) with multiple playstyles depending on which amulets you pick at the start of the game.

The only downside is no chat function other than the preprogrammed phrases. Not going to be either, according to the devs (they don't want to have to moderate, etc). It's also a -little- slow paced, but that's good if you like a relaxing strategy game for a couple of hours a game.

reviewText:
Armello is a very good implementation of an electronic board game.

The game is colorful, and I feel the champions abilities definitely give each character a distinct play style.  Combine that with the items, and no game really plays quite the same.  However, due to the winning conditions, yes the end game will appear on the surface to be the same, but how you got there, and the actual board situation can differ significantly from game to game.

How you build your character and what items you get into play are very important.  Taking items that provide additional dice, will typically give you a better attack, but they leave you vulnerable in defense.  If you take defensive items, you tend to get guaranteed die rolls (shields), but you give up some attack potential to do so.

However, you need to keep an eye on what your opponents are doing.  If they are building defensively, and they have higher base health than you, going defensive is not your best option.  If they are going for a high attack, it might be best for you to rely on subterfuge and obstacles to achieve your aims.

I highly recommend this game, but having a liking for boardgames definitely enhances the enjoyment.

There have been a number of changes to the game since it exited beta status, but what you can see from those channels is largely how Armello looks in its final state. reviewText:
Here's my two cents on this game:

- Really beautiful graphics, great gameplay.
- 8 characters to play from, all with unique abilities and differing stats but even the weakest can be the strongest.
- Win in 4 different ways or be like me: Kill king's guards cause they're standing on my quest (._.)
- Sabotage your opponents and laugh like a maniacal mastermind. (Even better when they're so close to winning)
- Then get sabotaged in return (Sucks when you're so close to winning)
- Dice rolls, mhmmm, don't even let me start on that. Unique but still partially dependent on your luck xD (RNG !@!%@!)

Additional stuff:
- I do get this weird rough-ish sort of sound in game and sometimes it gets a little annoying (not that it affects the entire gameplay anyway).
- Game might be still a little buggish (or maybe it's just my PC's issue x.x) but developers are quick to respond xD.

TLDR;
Great game, should try getting it if it's on discount if you feel the price is a bit eheh. Not that type of game which you can play for 5 hours straight, a game or two a day with friends makes it all the better xD. If you're not the board game type of person, might not be entirely worth it to get it at full price but it's a great way to spend time with friends, so do give it a try :D

9/10-ish. Hopefully the developers add a little more content (maybe expand the map and add more winning conditions or allow more players?), but it's still a job well done xD.

reviewText:
Edit: Originally not recommended, it was borderline. After many plays, the game is in fact a lot of fun to play and the characters add a lot of variety. My gripes with the game still stand though, some crazy RNG, user interface issues, lack of options, easy AI, slow pace with no current way to disable animations.

Here are the selling points from the store page and my breakdown of said features.

◘ Easy to Play but Hard to Master - Armello is an intuitive game, easy to pick up and experience but with deep and emergent strategy. Full release will include a tutorial mode.

Emergent strategy basically means that there is no long term strategy, things change from turn to turn, a new card draw with less than stellar cards means you may have to try and burn them off rather than continuing to your quest marker so maybe you'll get a better draw next time. The card draw is one of my biggest gripes in the game. There are a lot of different cards in the deck, so you can never really plan on what you want to do with your character based on equipment and spell cards, you just have to develop a new plan based on each draw. I wish the game gave you a little more control over the card draw.


◘ Fast & Thoughtful - Adventuring in Armello is fast-paced fun but filled with deadly tactical and politically complex decisions requiring careful forethought and planning.

The pace is simply not fast, you have to wait for your opponents to finish their turn and it takes forever. You can occasionally play some cards off turn, but it's rare. Planning is thrashed by card RNG, if it works against you, your opponents will quickly outpace you in stats and equipment. Poltical descisions are not complex at all and you basically choose between a or b, prestige in the game is relatively easy to get.

◘ Multiple Playable Heroes - Full release will include 8 playable Heroes. Each unique Hero possess a special power, stat line and Ai personality. Also heroes can be customised with Amulet and Signet Ring load-outs to match your play style or counter an opponents strategy.

Fair enough.

Edit: I didn't elaborate, but characters are all very different and require different tactics. My favorite to play at the moment is Amber (dungeon RNG reducer) . Upcoming Bandit Clan DLC will also add to the variety with new characters and different buffs.


◘ Dynamic Sandbox - Armello features a gorgeous dynamic world which procedurally generates a new map each and every game, complete with a dynamic quest system ensuring no two games of Armello are ever the same.

I don't feel like the quest system was very well fleshed out. Pick the stat you want, travel to get it, a random dice roll risk if you want a little extra.
Random map generation does not really help replayability because of the small map size and a small handful of different tiles, I feel a larger map with increased action points and more tile variety would have been more immersive. I feel like I travel the same tiles, and take the same route over and over.

◘ Turn-Based Day & Night Cycle - Armello features a fuzzy turn-based system, cycling between Day and Night phases. The fuzzy turns allow you to still play cards and do certain actions when its not your turn, and when it is you use Action Points to move around the hex board.

I wish there was more to do when it's not your turn, this is less of a problem late game though as players begin to rush the palace.

◘ World Class Music & Audio - By Michael Allen, internationally acclaimed artist Lisa Gerrard, Stephan Schutze and Jacek Tuschewski.

The audio is outstanding.

◘ Animated Cards - Armello will feature over a 120+ beautifully animated in-game Cards, from artists all over the world.

They do look nice. No complaints.

Edit: The game is truly gorgeous to look at, I mentioned it in my ea review, but didn't mention it here,  the all around atmosphere of Armello is near perfection for a game, I don't think there are many games in my library that come close.

◘True Tabletop Feel - We spent months making sure we cherry-picked the best parts of the tabletop experience, like our custom physics-based dice!

There are some things that are not consistent with a tabletop feel.  During a King's decree, the camera locks and I can't even scroll the board. I want to look at my card descriptions while trying to figure out a quest, nope, not happening. The devs have reduced the fog in the game for better visibility, but I just want to zoom out more and see the whole board at once, but the devs are obsessed with the artistic atmosphere and zoom is nerfed.

Multiplayer makes the game a little more fun, as the AI is not great and makes some puzzling decisions, but the pace slows even more and it's agony if you've fallen behind.

For me, Armello could have had some more strategic choices (especially card draw mechanics) and less battling with the RNG.  I do play quite a bit because RNG games have a place in my library. I will also continue to play in the hope of seeing some improvements, but I'm afraid this is the devs final vision (except for some tweaking) and it's not gonna change much.

reviewText:
I was looking for a new game and saw this on the day of its release, bought it as a curiosity.  I never write reviews, ever, but this game deserves it.
Armello has done the impossible, digitalized the tabletop strategy board game while mantaining the feel of rolling dice with your friends.  What's more, the digital platform has allowed for beautiful gameplay, and new and creative stretches to the genre.  It looks great, feels authentic, and tantalizingly hints at a deep and rich mythology that the devs are slowly revealing via updates and dlc.
Some people have complained about the gameplay mechanics, I haven't found them at all random, I mean,  no more than you would want with a game of its type.  The game is incredibly complex but easy to learn, and the devs are always releasing new tweaks, they really listen to feedback, and their patches and updates help, I particulary like the +1 body to all heroes, not to mention the slew of new content that is coming up.
The game is ground breaking. If you ever wanted an easier, more streamlimned way to play Avalon Hill type games without sacrificing the deep strategy, this it it.  Cannot recommend it enough.

reviewText:
I read some reviews before buying this game that were a bit misleading, so mostly I'm writing this to clear up some misconceptions you may have about this game. (I haven't touched multiplayer yet, so I'll be leaving that out)

First off, this game is awesome. Fairly simple, easy to get into, and from what I've seen of the dev's website, continually updated. A single game on the default settings usually take 30-45 minutes to complete. You have the choice of eight different characters to play as and two different maps. You also have the option to equip one ring and one accessory that up different stats from the beginning of a game.

You never know what's going to happen in a game, and you may even set out to win in one way, but end up on a different path later on. The card system adds a very deep layer to the gameplay, especially since you can play cards during other players' turns. Maps do seem small, but the way the map is used with quests and different terrains makes it feel a whole lot bigger.

If you like turn-based games, get this. If you like card games, get this. If you like RPGs, get this. This game has all that and more for the very reasonable price of $20. Just buy it man, it's awesome.

reviewText:
BASICALLY ITS REDWALL IN VIRTUAL TABLETOP RPG FORM. Both the 8 year old and the 18 year old in me are giddy with joy!
So to start I'll sum up what is generally not well liked by pretty much everyone and get that out of the way. Firstly, nearly everything in this game is in some way randomly generated. I could explain the systems and what I think were the design choices that led to the extreme amount of RNG in this game but it really isn't worth the time. Suffice to say that the one consistent element in the game is the number of tile you can move on a given turn.

There have also been what I see as contradictory complaints about the game being too long to be fun and too short to be playable. I fundamentally disagree with both of these assessments on the grounds that A) I have only had difficulty achieving one play style after less that a days worth of play and B) a game will last you less than an hour to complete when something like irl Dungeons and Dragons will take like three just to get from town to town and a grand strategy game like any of the Civ games can take multiple days to finish on lengthier settings. And to be clear, I mean the game will take less that an hour because the game has what is effectively countdown clock built into the game with the way that the king (the victory condition in this game) works. Basically, the game ends when he dies and he is already on the way out the door by the time the game starts.

Secondly, There is, at this time, not exactly a wealth of content available. THIS DOES NOT MEAN THAT YOU WILL PLAY THE GAME ONCE AND BE DONE WITH IT. What it means is that there is effectively one game mood and one map. What keeps the game fresh, in my opinion, is the very randomness that some people seem to distain. From what I have seen on the forums accessed from within the game, they are still actively working on bring more playable characters into the game and genuinely seem interested in improving the game with time. As for maps and game modes, I haven't seen any developments of note. In my personal opinion, the game is well worth its price as is but that is a very personal evaluation I leave up to you.

If these are concerns for you, you may wish to avoid this game, at least for the time being.

Otherwise, EVERYTHING ABOUT THIS GAME IS AN ABSOLUTE JOY.

The art is lovely in a way that I won't even attempt to describe. It manages to be both whimsical (prob mispelled) and sufficiently, well not exactly bleak but fitting for the sort of dark fantasy game that they were going for.

The RPG elements, which I admit are a tad simplistic, are very rewarding if you take the time to read the in game text, consider you actions through the lens of you character, and put in the smallest effort to care about what your doing. In short, use your imagination for 5 seconds. Its good for you. There is some RPG style progression and a wealth of collectables of extremely high quality (such as animated cards that you unlock for viewing after being played) and trinkets to change the way each kingdoms champions play after you have used them multiple times.

I personally love the gameplay. Note that I say this as someone that plays Dungeons and Dragons semi-regularly and has absolutely no problem waiting for 15 minutes while Sir Mixalot (actual name of friend's character) makes a decision as to what song he is going to play and then roles like thirty dice just to see if it all amounts to anything meaningful. Yes, it is undoubtably slow as a result of there being no way to skip the AI's turns and it is most certainly very random. However, it is not the total cluster that some of the negative reviews might lead you to think. Each character has certains stats at which he or she is better equiped to use. If you pay attention, you might even pick up on the fact that each of the 4 kingdoms is designed to be better at a certain type of victory condition, of which there are 4. And when I say might have noticed, I mean play throught he tutorial up until the point where the game literally tells you which victory each of the AI players are going for and which you should aim for. If that wasn't a big enough clue, maybe just put on your thinking cap an realize that trying to win a game by killing a lion as a rabbit is probably not the best course of action. It's a lot like rock, paper, scissors except this time with fatal" consequences.

Also
date: not that this is the biggest thing to note
recommended: but the music is very pleasent. I'm not talking like Bastion levels of amazing or even Skyrim levels of IS THIS EPIC ENOUGH FOR YOU. It's more subtle and relaxed in a sort of "what if Game of Thrones didn't make you have an minor heart attack everytime you watch" sort of way (note that I do realize that a great deal of GoT is just people talking at each other and not all that eventful).\n\nONE LAST WORD OF CAUTION: I do think that a large part of my personal enjoyment of this particular game comes from the theme and setting. When I was a younger
hoursPlayed: I read a great deal of the "Redwall" series by Brian Jacques that I mentioned at the beginning of this review. It is in no way an understatement to say that these book made me love to read. I can really explain what it was about them as a whole that I responded to but I know that
voteText: by shear virtue of the easy parallels between the books and this game
helpfulPercent: that Armello stirred within me many of the emotions and affections that struck me as a child while reading the collective works of Mr. Jacques. If you
votesHelpful: like me have any fondness for those book I highly recommend giving this game at least a cursory glance before passing it up. If you don't then go read any book from the Redwall series right now
votesTotal: or at the very least keep them in mind if your looking for something to gift to an 8 to 12 year old. I say all of this as an admission of bias. Please do take it into consideration.\n\nSo to sum this whole thing up
votesFunny: if the idea of midieval furry simulator 2015 sounds the least bit interesting to you
commentsCount: give this a chance.\n\nForgive any spelling or grammar error you might find in this thing. I wrote it at 1 in the morning."

reviewText:
Armello is an incredibly original and refreshing experience.

Combining boardgame strategy with roleplay mechanics in a fairy tale ambiance, the game has this unique aura that won't leave you indifferent.

There are a few different characters, each having its own features and specificities, and four different ways to win the game that will require you to adapt to the unpredictable events happening on the board. Even after hours spent playing, I still haven't unlocked everything and I just can't stop launching new games because this is just too much fun.

You should definitely make a stop by this enchanted kingdom. Not sure you'll manage to leave though.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Love this game to death with a nice community and a lovely game. There are some quirks to it but that's quickly overshadowed by all the fun you have playing the game. For starters:

This is a turned based game that has a lot of cool mechanics which are and are not limited to:

Mana usage - Cast spells on opponents during your turn and on someone elses turn (can't target players that is taking their turn)
Money usage - Funds the perils and trickery cards which turn the battle for Armello in your favor
Perils which are traps
Different character types and abilities for each of the clans united by the King
A generator map that is different everytime you play it.

This game is really fun but the core of the game is how you're suppose to win. There are 4 ways of winning the game.

1. Win by Prestige. Most common winning method by my experience. You pretty much do good deeds and kill enemy heroes and banes. You can also complete the quests.
2. Win by King Kill. Go into the Palace and kill the king to win the game!
3. Win by Spirit Stone. After stepping into the Palace, you can win instantly by exiling the king.
4. Win by Rot. Compete against the King to whoever is the most corrupted. You gain additonal die for having a higher rot score.

There are different ways of playing the game, but why don't you buy it and try it yourself? It's 20 bucks and well worth the amount of money being put into the game.

reviewText:
Great strategy board game. Sometimes feels a tad slow because theres so much content in the game. Mixes card playing aspects nicely for battle mechanics.

Haven't been able to play online (keep getting bumped) but not sure if mac and pc matchmaking exists, as I've been playing on the go on a macbook, not on my main PC.

Props on the art style, as it's super well done. Character animations for battle scenes can get somewhat repetitive, but it's more about the journey towards being the king and killing everyone/thing in your path. The AI is fairly good, so don't assume you'll always win. It's a slow burn to win, but enjoyable none the less. Multiplayer against friends is probably even more fun.

Worth checking out if you're into strategy/board/card playing games.

reviewText: Armello is better than most boardgames brought to pc.  It is a unique hybrid that has elements of board games and strictly PC RPGs.   It is not a couch party game (at least not yet) -- not sure if it would work or not since it has a stealth element.  Controller support in-game is nice for SteamOS (though you can't  navigate menu yet).  I think it is a better version of Wizwar or Talisman (more stratedy and ways to win) though there is still some luck/badluck that can frustrate or make you jump for joy.\n\nOverall, I have tried many Early Access games and many seem to progress very slow.  I would put Armello at the top of the list for customer support, updates, dev team, ect.  (alongside Brawlhalla); I am thoroughly impressed.

reviewText:
I always feel a bit of secret relief when the results of a Kickstarter project finally makes it into my hands. Kickstarter is both a great tool for people to gain funding for, and put forward ideas for, projects they are passionate about. It’s also a recipe for disaster. Projects often over-promise and under-deliver, much like the last decade for Peter Molyneux. And there’s no guarantee that the people behind the projects have any concept of how to manage a small business, which is essentially what kickstarter is enabling.

Fortunately, the Kickstarter that is Armello did not over-promise and ended up resulting in a great game. League of Geeks, backed by Screen Australia and Film Victoria, have developed a digital board game, and one of the first that I know of that isn’t an adaptation of an actual board game.

What makes Armello a great game is its use of the digital medium. It does things that most other board games couldn’t. There are several different game systems which make this a complex game, but complexity is fine in this medium. When you move into forests at night, you become invisible, something you couldn’t do with a hardcopy game. It also allows the NPCs to be a force of nature in themselves. The king and his guards have their own agenda, the banes that spawn out of the rot also act individually. But the best thing about having a digital board game is that there’s added character and personality in the game. The guard dogs sniff the air as they stand to attention. Some of the cards have animations. Day and night is actually day and night. You have a little advisor which pops up when you need to choose a new quest.

I’m yet to play with other humans, which will definitely provide a stronger challenge than playing with AI (one difficulty setting), and I’m looking forward to it.

For full review, visit: http://icarusreviews.net/2015/10/12/armello/
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I primarily game as a single player, so it made reviewing Armello difficult because a lot of the magic of Armello is found in Multiplayer with the community. Luckily, the community is healthy, supported, and talented. Here's a couple reasons why:

1. Developer Dedication - The LoG crew streams 3 times a week, providing answers to questions, insight to new developments, and generally being a stand-up crew. It's well past launch, and the developers continue to be a positive presence in the community.
2. Player Community - On both the forums and in the streams, you'll find dedicated players willing to answer questions, consider strategies, and talk about the future of the game. Games online maintain a friendly but competitive atmosphere. Because at its core, Armello is a digital boardgame, with all the pros and cons of one.

A number of reviews have brought up the pace, the danger of battles, and the tendency for Prestige victories to be more common. These are all true, but they're part of what make Armello great.

For pacing, you wouldn't rush through a board game, you want to take the time to consider your actions. Plus, you can also play a lot of cards while it isn't your turn. This is where the strategy of Armello really shines.

The battles, I've found the battles are very dangerous because the rewards are significant. Especially when there is a bounty on the player's head, or you're fighting the Prestige leader, or you're clearing a bane from a settlement. All of these can generate +2 relative prestige, which is an enormous boost. With careful maneuvering, you can easily go from underdog to leader, if you roll well.

Finally, yes. I've won a ton more as Prestige Leader than any other. That's what develops the tension. From the very beginning of the game, every player is working toward Prestige victory. That's the long term goal, but sometimes when you are coming up short. That's when you can invoke some of the others such as Spirit or Kingslayer to steal a victory from the Prestige leader. Being flexible and adjusting to changing game conditions is part of the fun of Armello.

There are numerous other critiques players have brought up, which I've considered, and I've now come to terms with. A lot of them are part of what makes Armello great and provides the challenge in the game. I don't think this game is for everyone, it isn't an RPG where you grow stronger and unstoppable. Nor it is a strategy game where consistent good decisions will insulate you from doom. Instead, Armello is a dynamic game full of life and capable of catching you by surprise. And that's why I recommend Armello.

reviewText: Absolutely stunning visual presentation reminiscant of Redwall or Secret of NIMH, and board game mechanics that make the most of the virtual medium makes this game amazing and addictive.\n\nYou are one of several heroes in the Kingdom, taking turns playing cards, saving villages and increasing your resources as you attempt to overthrow a king who has been tainted with corruption. If you're on the fence about this game, get it. You won't regret it.

reviewText: I have a library of about 45 games and have only reviewed one other game.  I am simply not compelled to do so very often but I must say how much I love this game.  The art is fantastic.  The devs are very active and it is just fun.  Sure, it has little issues here and there (would love multiplayer matches to form a bit faster for example) but this is a rare game indeed.  Victory is never guaranteed, you can help other players or stab them in the back.  Become an epic hero in battle or out-wit everyone without swinging your blade.  Take your pick; there are so many ways to win...and lose.  If you are on the fence...dont be.  I will see you in battle.

reviewText: Atmospheric, fast paced, and wonderfully balanced, Armello is a virtual board game of the highest caliber. Fans of  Brian Jacques' 'Redwall' series, David Peterson's 'Mouse Guard' graphic novels, or the 'Mice & Mystics' board game will find Armello's aesthetics a delightful treat. It is a game begging for additional player characters (perhaps as DLC) as well as different maps, but one can hope such additions are already in the works. Two rabbit thumbs up!

reviewText:
A fast-paced, beautiful and entertaining tabletop with some of the most charismatic characters ever seen in a pick-up-and-play game? Sign me up!

In Armello, you take turns with your opponents in a closed 10-rounds match that will decide the future of a kingdom in ruins. There are different gameplay strategies that you can adopt, the rules are easy to master (though it does have some meta with the whole item system) and soon you will be holding grudges against one or other character, just like in a good board game.

Since this is a board game presented in a digital medium, it does make use of great graphics and sound to improve the experience. Everything in Armello is animated (even the CARDS), the SFX are good and the music is calm and fitting. Also, if you like talking animals (or furries, admit it) you will probably love the characters in the game. Their animations and style are strikingly good, and on top of that each one has their own perks, adding more replay value.

All in all, it's easy to see that the game was developed by a team who loves what they do. Great attention to detail, polished UI, and just enough content to justify the time and money spent on it. Only criticism I have is not even related to the game itself: I find it hard to find other players for multiplayer matches.

One of my favorite casual games in a while, and certainly one I would recommend to anyone who enjoys tabletop games.

The game play is like a nice mix of the Lord of The Rings story with Studio Ghibli art stylings and themes with a D&D twist thrown in with it's relative form based gameplay (just everybody makes thier own story). All in all, a great game.

reviewText:
Armello is a mostly turn-based strategy game played with up to 4 players. Your ultimate goal is to overthrow the Mad King and restore peace to the land. Or rule over it with an iron paw; this game isn't about what comes after, but the hard-fought journey to it. It is a fresh take in the turn-based genre, where you don't simply go from point A to point B and finish first. You must use this strange land as a tool to build up and achieve victory through combat, magicks, or trickery (usually a combo of all three!). Each player chooses a hero each with their own passive ability and allocation of stat points. Afterwards, you choose a ring, granting an ability based on what clan they hail from. Then an amulet from a shared set that can boost a stat by 1 or make a particular victory condition slightly easier to obtain.

Dice appear in combat and perils (traps that require the dice to match symbols), where you either hit, miss, or defend. Each shield blocks one hit, where misses are 33% likely, hits are 50% likely, and shields are merely 1/6 likely. Attacks are resolved at the same time, so mutual kills can often happen unless you were geared up defensively. I don't feel this is a flaw exactly, just a design that requires player understanding and adjusting accordingly. However, you can guarantee certain dice rolls by burning your cards, matching its symbol on the top-right.

Card decks are used whenever you start your turn and draw new cards up to your Wits stat. You may choose from Items (healing, equipment, movement), Magic (stat buffs, teleportation, peril spells), and Trickery (traps, resource stealing, sabotage). While you are free to pick, your ideal choice lies with your character, position on the board, and time of day. Almost nightfall and you still have some magic? Draw a spell and use it up before you receive more for free. Have a lot of settlements under control? Draw trickery and take advantage of your discount per owned town.

I say it is mostly a turn-based game, in that you can play cards during other player turns. You can equip items to prepare for a potential battle, use buffing magic cards, play perils on the board, even teleport off-turn. While you cannot use a spell directly onto a player currently moving, you can still place traps in their way. Overall, this is the best time to modify or cement the strategy to be used on your next turn, rather than always being bored waiting for the three other players.
