reviewText:
I primarily game as a single player, so it made reviewing Armello difficult because a lot of the magic of Armello is found in Multiplayer with the community. Luckily, the community is healthy, supported, and talented. Here's a couple reasons why:

1. Developer Dedication - The LoG crew streams 3 times a week, providing answers to questions, insight to new developments, and generally being a stand-up crew. It's well past launch, and the developers continue to be a positive presence in the community.
2. Player Community - On both the forums and in the streams, you'll find dedicated players willing to answer questions, consider strategies, and talk about the future of the game. Games online maintain a friendly but competitive atmosphere. Because at its core, Armello is a digital boardgame, with all the pros and cons of one.

A number of reviews have brought up the pace, the danger of battles, and the tendency for Prestige victories to be more common. These are all true, but they're part of what make Armello great.

For pacing, you wouldn't rush through a board game, you want to take the time to consider your actions. Plus, you can also play a lot of cards while it isn't your turn. This is where the strategy of Armello really shines.

The battles, I've found the battles are very dangerous because the rewards are significant. Especially when there is a bounty on the player's head, or you're fighting the Prestige leader, or you're clearing a bane from a settlement. All of these can generate +2 relative prestige, which is an enormous boost. With careful maneuvering, you can easily go from underdog to leader, if you roll well.

Finally, yes. I've won a ton more as Prestige Leader than any other. That's what develops the tension. From the very beginning of the game, every player is working toward Prestige victory. That's the long term goal, but sometimes when you are coming up short. That's when you can invoke some of the others such as Spirit or Kingslayer to steal a victory from the Prestige leader. Being flexible and adjusting to changing game conditions is part of the fun of Armello.

There are numerous other critiques players have brought up, which I've considered, and I've now come to terms with. A lot of them are part of what makes Armello great and provides the challenge in the game. I don't think this game is for everyone, it isn't an RPG where you grow stronger and unstoppable. Nor it is a strategy game where consistent good decisions will insulate you from doom. Instead, Armello is a dynamic game full of life and capable of catching you by surprise. And that's why I recommend Armello.

reviewText: This is the first time ive ever felt strongly enough about a game to actually write a review. This game is awesome! The graphics are stunning, the storytelling is compelling, the gameplay is simple but effective, and it has just the right level of difficulty to keep you coming back for more. reviewText:
I read a lot of Red Wall when I was a kid because I wasn't really too interested in Harry Potter or all that nonsense. Uh. Not sure how that's -exactly- relevant? But it is. Armello's been an amazing experience that I'm trying to currently push on my friends. To note: This -is- basically an videogame boardgame, but it's super fun, and the animation is smooth. The tactics are varied and interesting, and there's a lot of room for risky play. Anyways, I'm probably more coherent when I hate a game. It's hard to praise a game as much as I have, so I'll get to the cons:
-There's only one game board.
-There's a pretty small character selection.

That's uh, about it. That and turns can take a little long, but that's okay when you're doing singleplayer anyways, because you can just turn on quickturns. I'd really love it if the developer considered DLC addons for maps and characters. I would definitely buy both. I'd be happy to support a developer that's made a wonderful game like this, anyways.

reviewText:
RNG will always be a cruel, unforgiving force.
I absolutely adore this game's atmosphere and visuals, and games are short, tense and enjoyable. Even still, I've lost count of how many times I've let out some sort of gargled raspy noise as I failed -another- skill check.
70% chance to win? Nah, son. You failed. Meanwhile your opponents are winning every roll they ever make.

Still, I really enjoy the games I get out of this. My last victory was so nail-bitingly close I don't think I have fingernails anymore.

reviewText:
I always feel a bit of secret relief when the results of a Kickstarter project finally makes it into my hands. Kickstarter is both a great tool for people to gain funding for, and put forward ideas for, projects they are passionate about. It’s also a recipe for disaster. Projects often over-promise and under-deliver, much like the last decade for Peter Molyneux. And there’s no guarantee that the people behind the projects have any concept of how to manage a small business, which is essentially what kickstarter is enabling.

Fortunately, the Kickstarter that is Armello did not over-promise and ended up resulting in a great game. League of Geeks, backed by Screen Australia and Film Victoria, have developed a digital board game, and one of the first that I know of that isn’t an adaptation of an actual board game.

What makes Armello a great game is its use of the digital medium. It does things that most other board games couldn’t. There are several different game systems which make this a complex game, but complexity is fine in this medium. When you move into forests at night, you become invisible, something you couldn’t do with a hardcopy game. It also allows the NPCs to be a force of nature in themselves. The king and his guards have their own agenda, the banes that spawn out of the rot also act individually. But the best thing about having a digital board game is that there’s added character and personality in the game. The guard dogs sniff the air as they stand to attention. Some of the cards have animations. Day and night is actually day and night. You have a little advisor which pops up when you need to choose a new quest.

I’m yet to play with other humans, which will definitely provide a stronger challenge than playing with AI (one difficulty setting), and I’m looking forward to it.

For full review, visit: http://icarusreviews.net/2015/10/12/armello/

reviewText:
Armello is a very good implementation of an electronic board game.

The game is colorful, and I feel the champions abilities definitely give each character a distinct play style.  Combine that with the items, and no game really plays quite the same.  However, due to the winning conditions, yes the end game will appear on the surface to be the same, but how you got there, and the actual board situation can differ significantly from game to game.

How you build your character and what items you get into play are very important.  Taking items that provide additional dice, will typically give you a better attack, but they leave you vulnerable in defense.  If you take defensive items, you tend to get guaranteed die rolls (shields), but you give up some attack potential to do so.

However, you need to keep an eye on what your opponents are doing.  If they are building defensively, and they have higher base health than you, going defensive is not your best option.  If they are going for a high attack, it might be best for you to rely on subterfuge and obstacles to achieve your aims.

I highly recommend this game, but having a liking for boardgames definitely enhances the enjoyment.

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Armello brings the charm of board games into the digital world, and does it better than a simple port might.

A lot of digital board games simple replicate a board game with a screen and buttons. This can be fun, but one thing that sets Armello apart is that they actually take advantage of the medium and do things that would actually be impossible in a real-life board game, but yet they never take away from that dice-rolling, peice-moving wistfulness that comes from playing a good board game. The game looks and sounds fantastic, with battle animations and background music, all while rolling dice and drawing cards. It's a very nice balance of a board game and a video game, without sacrificing the charm of either one.

As for the game itself, you pick a anthropomorphic animal hero, then move around the board to try and overthrow the kind before one of your three opponents do. There's combat, and spells, and stragedy, and many options for how to win. Not a whole lot to say here, except that if you like turn-based, board game combat with some stragety and thinking but also some luck, you'll like this game.

To anyone who likes board games and video games, this is an excellent example of how to properly merge the two genres.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've enjoyed this game thoroughly.

Having followed it since it's infancy on Kickstarter, I can't help but revel at how much it's progressed from the beta stages to the current gaming incarnation.

The storyline is rich and full of character (and characters). And while it seems simple; there is masterful amount of strategy to be had in something that feels so fluid.

This truly is more than a simple turn based strategy. It's a game that has depth. And while every 20 round game feels as it will be too short to truly experience anything; I find myself drawn not only into the game world but to the storylines behind each avatar's play style.

To this effect I woud recommend this game and I forsee expansion packs in the future.

reviewText:
Interesting table-top styled strategy game. The gameplay is largely dice and card-draw based, meaning there is a lot of RNG. Where the game shines is in how strategy emerges in how you manage the RNG through burning cards, building your character, and understanding what your opponents are doing. As such, while there is still a good deal of RNG, good players are the ones who know how to control and bias the randomness in their favor.

There are 4 ways to win the game, but not each approach is on equal footing. The Prestige and Combat victories are by far the easiest, while the Spirit Stone victory trails a little behind. The Corruption victory is very difficult, and in many ways seems redundant to the Combat approach, which is far easier. That being said, the game is in continuing development, and I'm anticipating that as new heroes and cards are added to the game (in free updates and DLCs) that the depth and balance between different strategic approaches will be improved.

TL; DR --- Do you like table-top games? Do you like turn-based strategy? Do you like games that have multiple ways to acheive victory? Do you have a brain for understanding RNG and managing it toward your favor? If you answered YES" to all of these
date: buy this game. You wont regret it."

reviewText:
Armello is not only the best boardgame I've ever played, it's also run by the best community!!!

I highly recommend you join the discord which is on the armello reddit, the players there will teach you so much and help you learn about the complexities and nuances of the decisions you make. They will celebrate your successes and comfort you on your failures, all whilst teaching you. Moreover, this is a boardgame at heart. Playing it with stranger to whom you can't talk is not the way it was designed to be played.

I beseech you to try this game, put the time in to learn its strategies and allow yourself to be swept away in the wonderful and blissful land of Armello.

NOTE: I'm aware this game is not for everyone. It requires a lot of patience at first, and does involve a large amount of RNG.

reviewText:
Okay, I wrote a full-length review only to see it fail to post and I copied something else which removed my entry from clipboard to fml...

Anyway, this game is not quite what I was expecting. It's also made from an Aussie studio which is awesome!

This game is great. The art is nice, graphics are pretty. The audio (sound and music) are superb. The gameplay is fun, deep yet intuitive with different tactics/strats. It has high replayability and great for online play. You can also customise the rules online/offline to play however you like.

Now the negatives. The game lacks some content, it's not an expensive game, it's actually quite cheap but for $20USD I'd like more than 1 level or at least some content for us solo players like a short campaign with a basic storyline. More characters and amulets/rings would be nice too, or at least more of the former. I'd also like a better matchmaking system with more detail and selections like choosing a public lobby. The prestige victory is also like the only worthy strat in most cases, this isn't a big deal as maybe it's supposed to be that way but the Rot victory is so hard to get, I got it on my 2nd day, but with AI, on PS4 only 0.8% of all players achieve a Rot victory and about 5.5% on Steam. The game does rely on skill and thoughtful strategies to win, however it's quite RNG dependent too, moreso than Hearthstone...but that's a bad example...I'd say slightly more than Chaos Reborn or at least on par.

It sounds like there's more negatives, and there probably are more negatives, but they're quite small specific aspects. Don't worry, it wasn't a tough decision between a Yes/No for my recommendation. It was an easy Yes." Don't buy it though if you don't like a little RNG

reviewText:
An amazing production all around.

The art direction is beautiful, filled with animations and visually pleasing graphics.
The soundtrack is very atmospheric and blends seamlessly with the games' many soundeffects.
And the story, though tragic is equally powerful and immersive as both the visuals and the music.

The gameplay itself is rewarding in every sense of the word, with things like microrewards just for participating in games, and a myriad of other ways to keep hope lit during a particularly unlucky streak. There's incredible potential for variety in every match, and no game is the other alike. In this game the pen and the sword are equally matched, and with the 4 alternate ways of achieving victory they ensure that every turn can twist the game in a new direction.

At first it may feel a bit slow, because each turn takes a fair bit of time. But since there's little restrictions with what cards can be played on other people's turns, you quickly learn how to not only speed that wait up, but keep yourself busy during it.

As with any game boasting this much variety between every match, luck can of course also become an obstacle. But in those scenarios you learn how to deal around it. Either by seeking an alternate path or just bide your time until another presents itself. Many games have been turned around completely by attentive underdogs who knew how to play their cards right.

The multiplayer has also lived up to expectations. Swift game lobbies and amusing phrases exhanged between players doing their best to add more surprises to the game helps renewing gameplay even further. Once you feel confident enough to try it out I can wholeheartedly recommend it, with random players or friends.

I can tell that a lot of effort was put into this game, and it took me completely by surprise just how well thought through it is in just about every single aspect.

I sincerely recommend this game to pretty much anyone, either as a fun way to pass some time or a challenge for those who enjoy competition with other players. I'd give this game a 9/10.

reviewText: Armello is a digital board game that mixes strategy and luck, where you play as a hero and go for one of several victory options in order to become the new king of Armello. It is a fun and cunning game, where anything can happen at any time and where no one is ever counted out. Up until the last turn, you can easily pull off a victory despite having virtually nothing going for you -- but only if you can deal with your opponents accordingly! The game feels a bit like a mixture between a lot of Mario Party, a good dose of Civilization, and a touch of Skyrim. My only gripe is that turns aren't simultaneous, making it so that you watch your opponents play more than you play yourself.

Terrible game.
Have you ever played Mario Party or Monopoly with a group of friends or family?
Imagine that horror and multiply that by cancer.
I get burned to death when i'm just about to finish a quest.

I never complete a quest unless I have over 70% chance to complete it.
Overall.
Pretty good game. I recommend it. 9/10 for lack of Foxes for me.

reviewText:
# 53      Armello

A board game set in a fantastical world  where animals are the dominant species, and a sickness called the rot ravages your King.  Adding cards, perils and board stylings of Catan, this board style game is actually a pretty slick joy.  Its a bit faster paced than Talisman, and way more polished.  One game ran me about an hour to play on single player, which is pretty fair for this type pf game.  The visuals are beautiful, smooth and well drawn, easy on the eyes.  And the sounds and music are very easy on the ears.

At first glance the mechanics seem daunting, with a steep learning curve.  Not that way at all.  The tutorial is set up into 4 chapters, highlighting 4 of the 8 or so clans.  Each one adding a few new mechanics, until finally you learn about how to win the game.  Like i said, smooth.  Developers seem pretty active, having a twitch stream after each new update, highlighting the new features.

I was a little peeved at the price, but after sitting down with it for a few hours, 20 bucks is actually pretty fair.

8/10 might buy a copy for the spouse

reviewText: A fun digital board game experience.  The characters are memorable and the art style is endearing.  The mechanics are fun and not too hard to learn, but difficult to master, with lots of variety in play-style depending on which heroes you enjoy.  Most importantly the devs are active and have been adding new cards, characters, and items at a reasonable pace since release.  I have seen a lot of people complain about having trouble finding multiplayer matches, but I haven't had any issues finding people to play with during afternoon through peak hours US, especially with the new Dice Hunt rewards.

reviewText:
“There is a savage beast in every man, and when you hand that man a sword or spear and send him forth to war, the beast stirs.”
― George R.R. Martin, A Storm of Swords

This beautifully created world of beasts and other furry creatures has stollen my heart. It’s a well thought out casual, yet challenging game of strategy, luck and gentle humor. That is, when you enter the game with an understanding of what you’re about to embark on in this quest of art and mind.

When stresses of life and the insanity of other games I enjoy tend to wear me thin, this is the game I always run back to with my arms wide open. The visuals are soothing. The gameplay is perfect for someone that just wants to relax after a long stressful day of getting scolded from their bosses or hearing the screaming of impatient children. Grab a glass of your beverage of choice, make those nachos you have been craving all week and sit down and enjoy the bliss and relaxation as you laugh along with others when you are riddled with bad luck or good fortune.

The series of set phrases that you will have in this game, used to communicate with others in multiplayer, bring a special roleplaying aspect that makes it very hard to get angry. (That is, unless you’re just angry by trait) Having a sense of humor will take you a long way; here in this game and in life.

I encourage everyone to pick this game up for themselves, friends or their kids (Great for all ages because the chat between everyone is talentedly limited) and have a great adventure of mind and visuals. Armello is one of the best relaxed yet, challenging turn-based strategy board like games I’ve come across. And, oh! I am so glad I did.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nLet be known the review is still for the Early Access release of Armello (who knows what 6 months will change!) - but so far I'm really enjoying it. From the music at character selection to the card animations, there's a lot of aesthetic pleasers in this game. Each game has ran about 40-60 minutes for me so far (single player) and it was a bit of a curve to get familiar with everything (like most board games, though). I really do enjoy almost everything about the game so far. I feel like so far it's been fairly difficult to win, unless by means of prestige. If I find myself behind in prestige about half-way through the game, I almost know that there's no way to catch up and kind of already consider myself having failed which kind of burns my gameplay morale - but besides that! This is an amazing game so far and I can't wait to see what comes out in the full release in 6 months. So excited!

reviewText: An amazing blend of tabletop dice rolling with real-time strategy from a top-down view, Armello represents a culmination of unique replayability with difficult-to-earn achievements and great community involvement from the developers. reviewText: Armello reminds me of board / card games like Settlers of Catan or Dominion, except it's a little bit more complicated.  I've wondered whether it would be possible to play as a physical boardgame, but I think it is too complex.  On the computer it's fantastic.  The pacing is great, there are a lot of possible victory conditions and different strategies to pursue.\n\nLove the game.  Art and setting is fantastic.  That said, like a board game, buy this if you have friends to play with.  Single player is fun, but the AI isn't that great, and I think it would get old quickly.

reviewText: Wonderful multiplayer experience for fans of tabletop gaming of all varieties. Hexagon style board and movement with resource management simialr to catan with the developemnt and progression focused on character characfer instead of a settlement. Nice reward system that seems to give you an additional different bonus to select pregame each time you utilize a different playstyle/character , which continually opens up more options for you. Gorgeous artwork that was clearly held in high importance during development. Matches move at a decent pace, giving you limited, but not entirely absent, actions to perform during other players turns. Length of each match is nice, most taking under an hour, giving you enough time to figure out a playstyle or character and moving on to another. The music is pleasant and fits mood nicely, but does not stand out in any particular way. Combat is simple, using a unique D6 system that is supplemented by combat and spell items and based off various symbols as opposed to numbers. Could benefit from an initiative system, as of now both characters engaged in combat simply get their full attack turn with no real importance to order unless they are outright slaughtered, going nearly negative their full health pool.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

League of Geeks' flagship game shows a great deal of promise as it goes out to early access. Armello is a video game which bases itself in board game principals where four heroes, a wolf, rat, rabbit and bear, compete for their clans to secure the throne.

The goal is to gain more prestige points than your opponents by the time the king dies of his illness, or to smite him yourself. The game has three methods of doing this, and takes familiar elements and mixes them in ways that work extremely well. The fact that the characters are anthropomorphic is icing on the cake of a solid game.

Full Review at Flayrah: https://www.flayrah.com/5976/armello-promising-furry-fantasy-game-early-access-release

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Short yet fun Board Game for the computer.  That's currently the best way to describe this game right now.  I've played a few times, won a few games, lost a few (even against the a.i. which was a fun suprise, usually the a.i. in games arnt challenging enough).  However the game lacks the long term strategy aspect that most games like it thrive off of and prestige victory seems to be the most viable option for a game lasting only about 20 turns/10 days. the upside to this is it gives you a game where you can sit down and play a game in 40 minutes without worrying about saving.

The game is ideal for playing with your friends and for those days where you need something to do for the next 30-45min.
Is it worth the price?  So far for me...  $25/6.3hrs of play=$3.96/hr  for me that is worth it as I know that price will drop as I play more.

Overall rating- 7.1/10  -  The game has alot to offer at an early stage.  But a game speed option should be added to fit the needs and wants of the average strategy gamer because lets face it, failing all of my quests at 40-60% is just pure bad luck and there's no way to bounce back from wasting 15 turns on failed quests in a 20 turn game.  But thats just how the dice roll sometimes.

Yes for anything 7.0 and up thats what i always say.  What's the point if i only enjoyed %50 of the game

reviewText: Having followed Armello from the Kickstarter campaign, I can say wholeheartedly that the final product is something that the crew at League of Geeks should be incredibly proud of. Armello is a unique and fantastically executed blend of RPG, tabletop game, card game, and turn-based-strategy. The world and characters are brought to life by the sublime art and sound team, and Armello is brimming with character. Gameplay is easy to pick up, but has enough nuances and options to keep players hooked and learning more and more each match. Matches tend to take an hour to complete roughly, but in Single Player the autosave function guarantees you can drop out and back into the action at any time. If you're even remotely curious or interested in this game, I'd certainly recommend you purchase it!
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Beautiful and engaging pc boardgame experience. Best played with friends (since the AI lacks that edge and ability to cooperate which makes the game that much more entertaining).

Armello was originally prototyped as a physical game, and that feel carries through into the digital version, from the dice physics to the card decks, without requiring the mental chore to keep track of all the math / board counters / other variables that would bog things down in real life.

Each space on the board has different terrain and variables -- towns give gold when claimed, forests give stealth in the cover of night, druid circles heal anyone who enters, and dungeons have the option of offering treasures or waking monsters. Players are given quests to travel across the kingdom and commit deeds of heroism that strengthen them for their eventual confrontation with the mad king at the center of the board. Equipment cards affect the number and types of dice you have to roll when facing tests and combats, and there are various spells, items, and traps that can be played to  terrain and/or players that can help or hinder them. Combat and perils are challenged with dice rolls -- you gain dice by equipping items and using spells to tip the odds in your favor.

There are currently 8 different characters (with more planned), each with different skills to complement different playstyles, from magic-using tank to sneaky hit-and-run thief, to item-hoarding situational card-swapper. The flow of each game requires players to be able to adjust their strategies for victory or be left at the mercy of more ambitious opponents. Either challenge the king directly or work to sabotage the plans of others and grab a win through trickery and amassing personal prestige. Literally stack your dice with clever use of your cards and abilities, and make a grab for Armello's throne before someone else does.

If you are a fan of tabletop and card games, then Armello is definitely worth a try. :)

Cons: No auto-reconnect if a player acidentally disconnects, no ingame chat (voicechat improves the boardgame experience feel, imo)

reviewText:
Armello's is a digital board game whose theme is a cocktail of Dark
Souls and Game of Thrones, all of it presented with a gorgeous art
style. Although not especially deep at the moment, it's fun and has
great potential for future patches.

---

Pros:
* Art - The art style in this game is absolutely beautiful. The cards
are lovely with their subtle animations and the 2D character art lends
the heroes a lot of personality. Sound effects and music are
appropriate and lovely. I'm looking forward to the DLC at least as
much for new art and cinematics as I am for new mechanical content.
* Fun and Balance - Hard to quantify rigorously, but the game feels
fun - it rewards being thoughtful without demanding that every action
is supremely calculated. Characters feel pretty well balanced given
the recent release, although not perfectly so. Mechanics like
corruption and the special abilities of followers mean that a single
card can be applied in different, interesting ways.

Cons:
* Arbitrary - Serious board game fans should realize that Armello has
a fair amount of luck involved: Drawing the right cards is important
and the outcome of almost all conflicts is dice based (although you
may burn cards to reduce the factor of luck here). However the real
element of luck is in the placement of random events, quests, and
perils around the map. You may lose a game due to an unlucky
positioning of an early quest or win one because of a timely spirit
stone spawn. To win, the rewards from the 'risky' option of quests are
very important, but you'll often have about a 40%-60% chance to fail
these, taking an expensive penalty instead. This is particularly
noticeable when two players are both close to victory and the
determination may hinge on one being a single turn ahead or having a
lucky/unlucky teleport. It's all fine for a video game, but players
expecting a more rigorous experience like mageknight or agricola may
be frustrated.
* UX Issues - The game permits you to play effects during an
opponent's turn, but doesn't offer a good way to pause or an interrupt
system like Magic's. The result is an imperfect blend of real-time and
turn-based feels that is jarring at times.  I also experienced are some
minor issues in the game such as UI elements disappearing or the sound
failing during certain effects. None of it threatened stability, however.

---

As for a sense of how the game plays, you spend your turns travelling around the map, preparing yourself through items and quest rewards to face the King, while trying to prevent the other players from doing the same. Usually there are several objectives you could pursue at once (is it worth taking an extra turn to reach my quest if I explore a dungeon first? What about one less turn if I take damage by going through a swamp?) to keep the mind sufficiently tickled. The game has a stronger emphasis on inter-player conflict than board games like Dominion so many of these decisions may involve whether to spend resources pulling yourself up or pushing someone else down.

Time factors into all of this. There are a very limited number of turns before the King dies. This introduces conflict between the players pursuing different victory conditions: As the King grows physically weaker over time, a player planning the regicide victory may wish to wait till late to face an easier battle. But if they wait too long and the King dies 'naturally' from his advancing corruption, the current prestige leader will win a diplomatic victory as heir.

Overall if you want a beautiful, clever game and don't mind a bit of bad luck, you'll probably like Armello. If nothing else, your eyes will thank you.

reviewText:
Part Settlers of Catan (modular board, simple board game mechanics, a heavy influence of dice-luck, euro victory-point scheme) and part Talisman (move around a board full of perils, equipment and spell cards, simple rpg-type quests) but with eyeball-kissing artwork and nice audio (although I don't know how long I can stand to listen to the soundtrack before it's going to end up muted).

There are some poor design choices that can certainly be corrected down the line without massive changes to the game and those include the worthless map zoom function, the too-tiny flags the indicate settlement ownership, an inability to fast-forward through AI turns, as well as general player info that is not easily visible at a glance. The UI desperately needs a button that gives a player a quick comparison of hero stats and standings (for all players).

I need to play more games to see if there is a runaway prestige issue. Prestige serves as both a potential victory condition AND a means of enacting temporary rules that benefit some players and punish others. A prestige leader is not only in a winning position but can continue to enact edicts that keep the other players down. This may be a positive design choice that prevents too much wildly swinging, bash-the-leader gameplay but I need to see more games before I can judge.

Recommended with the caveat that the buyer realizes that they are buying a digital board game" (essentially) and I would have felt a lot more comfortable paying $15 (or less) as it currently feels like a very well-made ipad game.

reviewText: A very well executed board game, made to be a beautiful video game. The visual presentation draws you in and the mechanics compels you to stay and explorer more of it.\nThe only weakness I feel is worth mentioning, is that if you try and stringently pursue a certain victory condition, the game will slap your hand and throw a myriad of random events at you, which might screw up your plan. The trick then is to be able to revise your plans immediately and go for a new victory condition, if that one seems more plausible than your old one. Also, sadly, a lot of online games I've playe so far are marred by people disconnecting. But that's a problem with the player base. The game is very enjoyable in single player as well, which is a rare quality in a virtual board game.

reviewText:
I like it

+ A mix of Talisman and Catan
+ Art style is great
+ Simple rules
+ Games will end in a set period of time
+ Fun with friends

Downsides

- Game is cpu heavy. Don't be decieved because it's a board game". If you have an old computer that struggles to run Civilization 5 then you will run into the same problems
- Turns feel really long.
- Feels incomplete. I feel that it's missing some features that it should have like the options to fine tune graphics or gameplay features. I'm sure these features will come in time.
- No hot seat gaming.

Now some people complain about the RNG. I don't think it's a problem because it actually averages out. For example
date:
if you have a character with 6 dice rolls. You have a 1/2 chance of getting 1 point of attack per roll. That means on average you should only get about 3 attack rolls. You might get more or less but point is you are very unlikely to score all 6 dice rolls as attacks. If you take this in mind rather than hoping to getting "double sixes" then it will be a much more pleasant experiance.

It's a board game so expect to lose some games because you were not lucky enough.

Overall I'd definitly buy it if you enjoy board games and can get 3-4 friend to play with."

reviewText: Having followed Armello from the Kickstarter campaign, I can say wholeheartedly that the final product is something that the crew at League of Geeks should be incredibly proud of. Armello is a unique and fantastically executed blend of RPG, tabletop game, card game, and turn-based-strategy. The world and characters are brought to life by the sublime art and sound team, and Armello is brimming with character. Gameplay is easy to pick up, but has enough nuances and options to keep players hooked and learning more and more each match. Matches tend to take an hour to complete roughly, but in Single Player the autosave function guarantees you can drop out and back into the action at any time. If you're even remotely curious or interested in this game, I'd certainly recommend you purchase it!

reviewText:
Part Settlers of Catan (modular board, simple board game mechanics, a heavy influence of dice-luck, euro victory-point scheme) and part Talisman (move around a board full of perils, equipment and spell cards, simple rpg-type quests) but with eyeball-kissing artwork and nice audio (although I don't know how long I can stand to listen to the soundtrack before it's going to end up muted).

There are some poor design choices that can certainly be corrected down the line without massive changes to the game and those include the worthless map zoom function, the too-tiny flags the indicate settlement ownership, an inability to fast-forward through AI turns, as well as general player info that is not easily visible at a glance. The UI desperately needs a button that gives a player a quick comparison of hero stats and standings (for all players).

I need to play more games to see if there is a runaway prestige issue. Prestige serves as both a potential victory condition AND a means of enacting temporary rules that benefit some players and punish others. A prestige leader is not only in a winning position but can continue to enact edicts that keep the other players down. This may be a positive design choice that prevents too much wildly swinging, bash-the-leader gameplay but I need to see more games before I can judge.

Recommended with the caveat that the buyer realizes that they are buying a digital board game" (essentially) and I would have felt a lot more comfortable paying $15 (or less) as it currently feels like a very well-made ipad game.

"

reviewText:
Armello's is a digital board game whose theme is a cocktail of Dark
Souls and Game of Thrones, all of it presented with a gorgeous art
style. Although not especially deep at the moment, it's fun and has
great potential for future patches.

---

Pros:
* Art - The art style in this game is absolutely beautiful. The cards
are lovely with their subtle animations and the 2D character art lends
the heroes a lot of personality. Sound effects and music are
appropriate and lovely. I'm looking forward to the DLC at least as
much for new art and cinematics as I am for new mechanical content.
* Fun and Balance - Hard to quantify rigorously, but the game feels
fun - it rewards being thoughtful without demanding that every action
is supremely calculated. Characters feel pretty well balanced given
the recent release, although not perfectly so. Mechanics like
corruption and the special abilities of followers mean that a single
card can be applied in different, interesting ways.

Cons:
* Arbitrary - Serious board game fans should realize that Armello has
a fair amount of luck involved: Drawing the right cards is important
and the outcome of almost all conflicts is dice based (although you
may burn cards to reduce the factor of luck here). However the real
element of luck is in the placement of random events, quests, and
perils around the map. You may lose a game due to an unlucky
positioning of an early quest or win one because of a timely spirit
stone spawn. To win, the rewards from the 'risky' option of quests are
very important, but you'll often have about a 40%-60% chance to fail
these, taking an expensive penalty instead. This is particularly
noticeable when two players are both close to victory and the
determination may hinge on one being a single turn ahead or having a
lucky/unlucky teleport. It's all fine for a video game, but players
expecting a more rigorous experience like mageknight or agricola may
be frustrated.
* UX Issues - The game permits you to play effects during an
opponent's turn, but doesn't offer a good way to pause or an interrupt
system like Magic's. The result is an imperfect blend of real-time and
turn-based feels that is jarring at times.  I also experienced are some
minor issues in the game such as UI elements disappearing or the sound
failing during certain effects. None of it threatened stability, however.

---

As for a sense of how the game plays, you spend your turns travelling around the map, preparing yourself through items and quest rewards to face the King, while trying to prevent the other players from doing the same. Usually there are several objectives you could pursue at once (is it worth taking an extra turn to reach my quest if I explore a dungeon first? What about one less turn if I take damage by going through a swamp?) to keep the mind sufficiently tickled. The game has a stronger emphasis on inter-player conflict than board games like Dominion so many of these decisions may involve whether to spend resources pulling yourself up or pushing someone else down.

Time factors into all of this. There are a very limited number of turns before the King dies. This introduces conflict between the players pursuing different victory conditions: As the King grows physically weaker over time, a player planning the regicide victory may wish to wait till late to face an easier battle. But if they wait too long and the King dies 'naturally' from his advancing corruption, the current prestige leader will win a diplomatic victory as heir.

Overall if you want a beautiful, clever game and don't mind a bit of bad luck, you'll probably like Armello. If nothing else, your eyes will thank you.

reviewText:
A very fun board game. The art is great, the characters are very well animated, and the weapons are very original.
In short, take turns with the three other heros and pick 1 of the 4 different ways to win the game. The game play does not take that long. Normally by dawn 8 or 9 the game, (this being the longest). If you can kill the king sooner, then it will be even quicker. If you are going for a prestige victory then you are keeping the other heros away from the king. Which again, turn 8 or 9 depending on events. Time wise I'd say the game takes 40 - 60 minutes. Either way, time flies with this game. Really happy with this game!

Up to this point I have played strictly solo, maybe I'll try the multiplayer in the future.

reviewText:
Armello is a beutifull, well thought out game. It's a little like dungeons and dragon's, where the randomness factor comes into play during combat and cave exploration. Anyway, the world itself is gorgeous. at the start of the game you can go through a tutorial (which  highly recommend you do) and it will run you through the main characters, and their passive's and perks, e,g, river, from wolf clan, she carries a bow and arrow with her, if YOU attack anything, she will fire her bow and deal 1 damage before attacking, making her an excellent asassin. The end goal of the game depends on how you play, and play as/with. You can win either by, killing the king, and not duying during the combat, waiting for the king to die and (if you were well renound throughout the kingdom) take his place automatically, or you can bring 4 spirit stones to him, cleansing him of his corrupt ways. Thats just the main point's of the game.

As soon as i understood how the game mechanics worked, i  was immedietly captured by it.

Now this game is good, and kept me busy for a couple of rounds in a row, but after a while, you have to walk away, now thats not a bad thing, EVERY TIME, its a new quest,journey,story and experience, you can and probably will come back to it over and over again, the fact that you can come so close to winning and to lose it all in  an instant, is just great, for once it feels good to NEARLY win, still getting xp for that clan and for your self, it's just great.

anyway,ill leave it here, yes without a doubt, recommend this game, no faults with it, it's in good committed hands ( i think) and i hope more branches of this game. love it.

reviewText:
Here are my main two gripes with the game:

1. Excessive reliance on RNG. RNG itself isn't bad, but when its an overwhelming factor that takes more importance than strategizing or good tactics, it just feels like you're playing a more complicated version of Monopoly in the end. There's thankfully some strategizing in how you choose to play certain characters and highlight their strengths, but it still feels somewhat limiting as their seems to be one dominant playstyle for a character. There's also a pretty strong snowballing effect, so when you're consistently dying / not hitting your quests due to random luck, you just feel sort of screwed.

2. Lack of chat. The developers have chosen not to implement chat due to concern regarding 'safe spaces'. I don't particularly understand the concept of playing multiplayer without being able to chat with each others (and no, pre-set voice commands don't count as chat), let alone playing a board game / table top game without being able to communicate. The entire fun in a board game is communication. Furthermore, Armello games take roughly 1-2 hours to complete and you'll be waiting 5~ minutes for other players to finish their turns at sometimes. Not having chat to kill the time while waiting is a pretty awful decision. You can get around this by playing with others and there is an online community, but if you're looking for a quick game you might end up waiting for a while.


Conceptually, the game is interesting, but I think the gameplay could use some tuning to be less luck-oriented and more skill-oriented, while the chat thing is just absolutely silly.

reviewText: Armello is the best virtual board game I have played to date. It does a great job of feeling like a board game while taking advantage of a lot of things that are only possible in virtual space (ie hidden things that only certain players can see). There are several very different play styles for different win conditions and with each patch, gameplay gets more and more dynamic. This is one of the few games that has lived up to its initial hype (and it's not even done yet as I write this!). A must-have game for any board-game enthusiast and an excellent game regardless.\nWatch gameplay here: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLL5JEFvVpx9pi5wJBFo_WUegKuWro60Q2

reviewText: A turn-based digital board game set in a disney's Robin Hood like world where anphropomorphic animals rule the land. Whether playing single player or multiplayer; the game consists of 4 heroes vying for the future of the throne. The game is easy to learn but difficult to master. The board is randomly generated (except starting points and the palace) with each terrain having a different effect on the game and your hero. Settlements generate gold, mountains require double the movement, swamps cost health to traverse, forests provide stealth at night, stone circles heal the uncorrupted and dungeons can help or hinder you. Time is limited by the king's decaying health and turns alternate between dawn and dusk each providing different benefits.\n\nNot finished, work in progress.

Yes there's a few niggles graphically (The -massive- DoF effect when zooming out is somewhat irksome, and sometimes clouds literally block my vision when zoomed in) but besides that, the presentation is great, the art style inspiring, and to be frank it reminds me a lot of Redwall. Which is a good thing.\n\nIt's basically Talisman, except your movement isn't restricted by dice and the world is drop dead beautiful, and there's more than one way to win. The overall 'rules' are relatively simple and easy to grasp, but there's enough tactical depth to keep things interesting.

reviewText: A turn-based digital board game set in a disney's Robin Hood like world where anphropomorphic animals rule the land. Whether playing single player or multiplayer; the game consists of 4 heroes vying for the future of the throne. The game is easy to learn but difficult to master. The board is randomly generated (except starting points and the palace) with each terrain having a different effect on the game and your hero. Settlements generate gold, mountains require double the movement, swamps cost health to traverse, forests provide stealth at night, stone circles heal the uncorrupted and dungeons can help or hinder you. Time is limited by the king's decaying health and turns alternate between dawn and dusk each providing different benefits.\n\nNot finished, work in progress.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Updated Aug. 7th, 2015 Review Additions:

Over the past few months, I can honestly say this game has made leaps and bounds from where I hopped on. The community continues to grow, the game continues to get better, and I can only imagine what amazing things are in store from its actual release and onward.

LoG and the rest of the Armello community are some of the best people I've gotten to know, and every dime spent on this project was well used. I can say with a surety that this game is well worth your money, and that this game is ten-times as good as it was in its Early EA.

If you're still unsure about whether or not this game will interest you, I suggest keeping an eye on LoG's twitch channel, and watching the weekly community vs devs games (they're a hoot!).

~~~
Edited Original Review:


So, even after my first match with AI, I can wholeheartedly recommend this game. The TLC that LoG constantly states they've given this game is quite evident, even from the main menu and first few turns. Literally everything in this game works together to create quite a triumphant and easily enjoyed experience that does not disappoint. The art work, fabulous. The music, fantastic. The gameplay, classic, yet new.

Performance:
I have helped LoG (and continue to help them) squash as many bugs as possible, and I can honestly say that they are rather fast and efficient at getting rid of game bugs. Thankfully this game runs rather well on my lower-mid level laptop. Not to mention that it has a rather low space footprint for a game of this kind.

Aesthetics:
This game is very pleasing to look at and to listen to. If you don't believe me, you obviously haven't watched the trailers. The trailers alone send shivers down the spine, and leave a considerable amount of chilling goosebumps upon one's person. I sincerely hope that the OST will at some point be available, because it would be an easy buy, even if you don't play the game, for the music, too, plays an integral part in sweeping you away to the magical land that is Armello.

Gameplay:
Armello is designed to play a lot like a table-top RPG/Card/Board game. Each of the 4 base characters have initial stats and a unique ability, and receive bonuses based on a ring and amulet of the player's choosing. The characters play a large part in how the outcome of the game can be achieved by catering to different playstyles, making the character choice a rather important one - though, not necessarily game-defining. While one can achieve different types of victories with the same character, some conditions are easier met by certain characters.

Each turn can easily be a game changer, as players are constantly in a close struggle to gain prestige, gold, magic, or treasure all necessary things to taking the throne, the ultimate objective of the match. There is seldom a point in the game where one can relax, because someone else is almost always on your heels in terms of strength, or physical/magical gains.

Experience:
This game is rather easy to jump into and enjoy, however, it is highly recommended to look into the game guide here on Steam. Even with its current, early mechanics, this game is easily replayable. Each match and turn is able to bring quite a different experience, and only gets better in a game against other humans. The characters and other pre-match choices can make a large difference based on who's playing who, so the strategizing happens from the get-go.

I chose to buy in because this game interested me, and I know that being an Indie Dev is far from easy, and every dollar counts. However, I do again, sincerely hope that this first project doesn't leave a bad taste in the gaming community's mouth because of a mistake made in their infancy (the KickStarter incident, which as since been cleared up!).

Pseudo TL;DR -

This game is a rather specific purchase...If this is a game you're looking for, I can personally recommend it.

For those of you sitting on the fence: Trust me, this game is well worth it, and the community is truthfully one of a kind.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Originally posted at: http://caffeinecrew.com/2015/06/10/loading-not-yet-ready-armello/

The King of the land lets out a mighty roar and decrees that this morning all of the land’s Heroes must pay taxes worth of 2 gold. I cringe and hand over my money—I braved the depths of the local dungeon and potential face-off with a Bane to obtain it. There are but a few days left of the King’s life, and I’m incredibly close to obtaining the means to cure him and save the land from devastation. I am now forced to decide between trying to cure him (which may be impossible in the allotted remaining time), or attempt another approach.

This is but one playthrough of League Of Geeks’s first title, Armello—a high fantasy digital board game. Currently in Early Access, Armello sports a unique design centered around 4 players (Human or AI controlled) attempting to either overturn the beleaguered King, or to save him against a mysterious plague known as The Rot. Armello also maintains a somewhat procedural design, in which map tiles are randomly placed each game in order to create unique playthroughs each time. It’s with this design in mind that it makes sense the Armello game board is so small, but at the same time it often feels a bit too cramped.

Armello’s 54 tiled design makes for fast paced sessions, coupled with the ability to move up to 3 spaces per turn (or 2 if you intend to cross a mountain), accessing a lot of the board’s missions and special objectives seems quite easy. Or so I initially thought. Attempting any of Armello’s 3 possible game endings means staying heavily focused on a series of gameplay elements at all times and more often than not (unless you get insanely lucky), you will find yourself abandoning your current ending goal for the most common: Prestige (more on that later). But at the same time you will likely be bumping into one of the other 3 Heroes, the King’s Guard, or the terrifying Banes. Sometimes this can get in the way of gameplay and feels somewhat oppressive, albeit understandable.

Personally I would love to see larger board sizes incorporated into later builds of Armello so I can further customize the experience for longer and more in-depth sessions. This, however, leads into Armello’s fairly short session time thanks to each playthrough lasting a maximum of 18 rounds (9 Day/9Night turns). Not having an option for more turns really puts the squeeze on the game’s potential win outcomes. Rounds are managed by the King’s health, which drops by 1 after every Night turn passes (1 day/1 night). Day turns are the safer of the two as Banes deal far less damage and appear less frequently, while night-time makes them stronger, and occasionally spawn from dungeons. Some Heroes, such as Thane, gain benefits at night like an extra attack die.

Armello uses Gold and Magic Points as currency for using their myriad card selection ranging from equippable combat effects, to direct player sabotage. You can also take your cards and burn them during dice rolls to guarantee specific dice outcomes; this removes a number of dice equal to the number of cards burned, but can potentially guarantee winning or overcoming a trap.

Armello’s other form of “currency” is Prestige, a form of positive notoriety that is earned from killing Banes, other Heroes, finishing Quests, or from cards. The player with the most Prestige gets to pick the King’s daily decree each Day Turn, and will win should the King die (end of turn 18) via a Prestige Win. This type of win is the most common from the games I played, and is the easiest to obtain. After 3 times of getting a Prestige win I found the mechanic a bit unbalanced and boring. The other possible ways to win are: Killing the King and surviving, and curing the King via Spirit Stones. Both options require intense player building with the latter needing a focus on good timing and Quest management.

All of this in mind, Armello sports some of the most amazing art and music I’ve seen in an Early Access product. The character models, the animations, and even the cards themselves are all beautifully crafted to bring the game to life. It has this undeniable charm that pervades every aspect of the game, from the Heroes both majestic and shifty, to the Banes—unearthly Rot creatures—who maintain an air of danger and threat. There are a few minor hitches such as the King’s Declaration graphic staying on-screen for far too long and obstructing any action taking place during that event. The music as well is moody and ethereal, creating a mystical atmosphere throughout each playthrough. However, when browsing cards on the Main Menu there are no sound effects when clicking on cards.

It’s still very soon in Early Access, but Armello is definitely one of the more tightly designed digital board games I’ve played as of late, and its future developments could prove quite interesting. I suggest keeping your eye on it if you’re on the fence. If you really enjoy digital board games, though, grab this and run with it along the development process.

This game is one of the best games i've come across in a long time (If you like things in the vien of D&D meets Fire Emblem with furries)


Artisticaly it's the most beautiful game i've seen in the last 2 years. Gameplay wise? As i said above if you like the sound of that then you are in for one hell of a fun time.

But let me go into a bit more detail. Everything (for the most part) in Armello is decided by Dice and Cards. Cards -Spells-Equipment-Trickey-followers- will allow you to either lay traps and challenges for your foes (trickery cards) Buff your rolls in combat and trickeries (Equipment and Followers) Or just cause a ruckus and make people not have a very good day (Spells).


If anything listed above interests you, then this just might be the game for you.

reviewText:
Tl;dr: Gorgeous graphics, garbage gameplay

OK, I have played this game 4 times through now (5 if you include the tutorial). I enjoyed the tutorial. The graphics are lovely. There is a potentially deep, intelligent, strategic game under here. So here's why I feel like I wasted my money:

1.) The AI is terrible. I won" my first game vs. the AI because they killed the king while I was prestige leader. There is absolutely no reason for them to do this - it was a move which ensured a victory for me which I could not have secured for myself for many turns.

2.) A game will last somewhere between 25-40 turns as a guess
date: but is generally decided within the first 3-4. It is very
recommended: very easy to get into a position where either A.) one player is so far ahead their victory is certain
hoursPlayed:
but won't happen for another 3/4 of the game B.) you can't win because you lost a few early battles to the RNG and now can't hope to get back on your feet.

3.) The battles are a snooze-fest and you are forced to watch *every single one*. I don't mean every one you are involved in - I mean battles between two characters who aren't even opponents of yours (essentially NPCs) on the other side of the map which have 0 bearing on your strategy etc. Battles you do not care about. Battles that last around a minute and consist of randomly thrown dice.

4.) There is some small element of strategy involved in dice throwing -you can trade your cards to lock dice into position - but god knows why you'd want to when a dice roll can and will randomly reroll itself giving you extra victory points/defence/etc if it lands on the "right" side. Why would you trade the possibility of this potentially infinite loop for anything else?

5.) I think the game is supposed to be primarily multiplayer - but the same problems of it being essentially a dice rolling sim persist. What's more the "chat" system is restricted to a handful of clickable speech buttons which don't actually even say the thing that's on them ("oops" becomes "well
voteText: that could have gone better" etc.). Also see the game being won/lost in a few turns yet lasting so much longer than that it's literally painful.\n\nI played for less than 5 hours I know
helpfulPercent: and I would say at least 2 of those were me giving it extra play time so i could be sure I was being fair. I do not understand the overwhelmingly positive reviews of this game. If it was £3-£5 or still in early access I would give it a break but as it stands this is a real waste of your time and money.\n\nFinally: everyone who disagrees with this review

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're a fan of board games and RPGs, this is a must try, especially mage knight the board game, if you ever played that one, then this game has a lot of elements from it, but obviously simplified for everyone to get into.

Everything from looks to art is great, except a minor thing which is the animations in battle seem a bit wonky/awkward, but that's just a preference.

Now I understand they decided to limit a lot of deep elements of the genre to attract more people, but I do believe a few things need to be considered for the final release:

1) A leveling system: Be it in game for the characters, they gain exp for killing enemies/heroes and when they level up they get to pick some character specific skills which they can use once per round etc.  Account level up to show progress of some sort and rewards such as skins or whatever, rather than just earning rings and whatnot.

2) A better variety of enemies more than just a crow/ the option to be able to attack kings guards without the need for the kings orders to allow it.

3) Introduce elements such as Fire shield or Ice attack which count as 2 swords and needs 2 blocks to block 1 ice attack and such, this might be a little too complex for the general public though.

4) More maps, hopefully this is already being thought of/implemented.

5) Like someone has suggested, even though the game has 4 routes to take to win the game, everyone ends up going for the prestige route because its the easiest and more beneficial way, they need to somehow balance to improve variety.

6) Different game modes, cooperation between 4 players to fight against the map and conquer castles or such and the trickery spells etc could be used by the enemy minions, another one would be a two on two sort of match with the same elements.

7) Allow us to buy recruits at cities or settlements with coins or magic depending on their type, seeing as leaving it to RNG doesn't really have a fun feeling to it.


Overall this game is great and I'm quite excited to see it in its final form, but for now I think I'll give it a  rest until it's finished. Great job guys, unique experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played Armello for about 5 hours now almost exclusively in multiplayer and I've had a lot of fun with it so far. The gameplay is very good and well structured, although it does require some more balancing. It's much much easier to win by prestige amount than any other way. As soon as that's balanced a little more, this game is a pearl among rocks I would recommend to everyone.

Technically I've only had issues with the game not registering my graphics card correctly and thereby forcing me to play in lowest quality, but as it's on an Early Access state, that's more than understandable at this point.

I've had great experiences with this so far and can't wait to see what's in store for the final version. Keep up the good work!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've always been a board game fan, and had both high expectations and trepidation walking into Armello. Would the RPG element be complete enough? Would the game be deep enough in a one hour play through? Would it be exciting enough to get me to play it over and over?  More importantly, would I ever choose to play Armello when I could otherwise play Settlers of Catan or Dominion on my kitchen table?

The answer is YES, to all of these questions.

The RPG element is too downplayed to really be called RPG". It is more "inspired by" RPG. The closest thing I can think of to it is Munchkin—the RPG parody. Yes
date: you go around and get treasures and equip weapons
recommended: but the real reason for doing this is to get a strategic advantage

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As someone who rarely purchases games, I am very pleased that I decided to invest in Armello.

The whole game oozes charm and elegance with lovely graphics and a flowing soundtrack that fits perfectly with the mood of the moment. It features some old ideas but executes them so that they feel new and original.

The game can be played straight from the box but, as the player gets more involved, the various strategies and mechanics become clearer. Do you strive for strength in close combat or opt for tiptoeing around the world, searching for spirit stones, and using long-range tactics to shatter your opponents?

I love the way this game has been designed. It has the power to immerse and captivate you with plenty of variation and scope for future expansion. Each of the heroes provide a different approach to winning the game and can be further defined by completing quests and obtaining a wide range of useful objects like armour, spells and follower companions. The element of luck and random outcomes makes every game different and entertaining.

If you enjoy employing your brain, I think you'll really like Armello!

reviewText: I didn't want to like this game. It looked a little too cutsie, almost like a dolled up girl's version settlers of Cataan. But I did, and I do and I will.\n\nIf you have room in your library for a relaxing 30-45 minute strategy turned based multiplayer boardgame style game. GET THIS ONE.

reviewText:
Armello is a great game for anyone who enjoys elements of the RPG and Strategy genres. It's essentially a turn based board game which supports up to four players at once, with players attempting to win the game in one of the four ways to win. Each player selects a character and each character has different starting stats and a unique ability. Each player will begin the game and select a quest out of a few different alternatives. The quest will boost a stat and give a chance to win gear. Gear is great in this game and I've seen most games come down to gear loadouts and, of course, dice rolls. Oh yes, a public service announcement: anyone who doesn't like dice mechanics should probably bypass this title as it is ALL dice!

There is also the rot game mechanic. Rot is a stat that is basically like evil corruption. I mention this separately, just in case there are any players, like me, that like to take the left hand path and play evil. Armello indeed has the low road and it takes the form of rot. Get to a higher level of rot than the King (the villain) and you will get a huge bonus. Plus, I have rarely seen other players use that route, increasing its novelty with multiplayer.

Now here are some things I dislike about Armello. I think that there are some balancing issues, especially for Corrupt characters (ie. very rare corruption cards) and a complete lack of aesthetic customization to characters. I'd love to take my evil bear priest and trick her out.

Again, if you like strategy, board games or RPG's, pick up this title. Armello is one of my new favorites and with multiplayer matches only lasting just above an hour or so, I'm not sinking a whole afternoon into it.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
In short: This is a charming game. It's fun, it's replayable, and it's nice to look at.

But if you like reading longer reviews -

Armello is a turn-based strategy roleplay game, built much like one would build a board game. In fact, I would go as far as to call this a, 'Virtual Boardgame'. The gameplay is exactly what you'd expect from that: Rolling dice, moving tiles, drawing cards, and collecting stuff, until you can claim victory, or the timer runs out. Gameplay is a bit repetitive, but you certainly don't play Monopoly because of the ways you can innovate. There are several ways to aquire victory; some of which are somewhat hard, and there are playstyles that show through that. It's very hard to secure a 'Rot' victory, but fairly easy to accumulate prestige, and simply wait the timer out.

I really like the art style, and I am a big fan of the 'furry' theme. Don't worry, non-furs, there's no Yiffing here. It's visually appealing, and the music matches what's going on on the board very well, as well as helping to really immerse you in the game. Though, I wouldn't exactly say that the soundtrack alone is worth half the game's pricetag, (at a whopping $9.99 at the time of this review) it definitely helps my score. It's very moving, and flowing, and keeps a light-hearted tone until the grim of battle finds you for the first time.

Overall, I have to give the game a 8/10, marred only by the steep pricetag, and a lack of a campaign.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
For all the people who hate Early Access, Armello is a game that proves it can be used well.  The devs were remarkably on-point with updates for content, AI, and game play issues.  I am just floored by the experience of watching this game grow.

As for the game itself? It has a small community right now, but even the single player creates amazing scenarios and so many moments of nail biting tension that you will love and hate and get to experience every time you play. It is probably one of the best uses of a digital platform for a board game design I've ever seen, up there and perhaps beating Civilization.  It feels like a board game that simplifies what would be an immense amount of complexity and a game box the size of a Cathode Ray Tube TV into background programming.

The negatives are there, of course. The graphics can suffer at high res, the mouse sensitivity has cost me a few games (mostly from a card not burning in time, or being played to the wrong hero) and the Rot victory is incredibly difficult to get if you don't base your entire game around it, but it is so, so satisfying when it works that I cannot truly fault it for that.  The first two issues are likely because of the game being also developed for mobile, and the last feels a bit more like the game designers discouraging you from being totally evil the entire game.

All in all, I recommend this game very much so to all the folks looking for a game that's fun, gorgeous, and will leave you sweating until the king's crown has fallen down.

reviewText:
Nice game.

I like it.  A very good product of a designed based on hybridizing board/dice/card games with RPG / 4x-esque games.  It might be a bit too oversimplified, but deeper strategies do exist.

My favorite part about the game (and the part in which I think it does the best) is its job of developing and presenting the theme.  The artwork, the lore, the presentation of the entire story (which is unforutnatly a bit short) was very well done.  The win conditions are all very fitting, from slaying the king in direct combat to submitt oneself to the corrupting Rot, it all goes with the lore very nicely.  At the end of each game you can pretty much imagine a tale written about what happened in the past 1 or 2 hour of gameplay, as the mechanic of the game trasnlates into a story smoothly.

Now the gameplay in itself is not bad at all.  People say it is too luck dependent, but really it's just a factor you stratgize around.  The actual range of risk analysis isn't so big.  Sure, rollin 4 dice might sometime beat someone who is rolling 6, but that should be in your consideration of margin of risk and possiblity.  Engagment with dice differentiation of 4 or more is rarely unexpected.  Furthermore, the overall health of all the character is relatively low in comparsion too all the things that can kill you.  It's more often than not that both combatants just die from fighting than one guy winning purely due to chance.  The only thing that is bit too chancy is quests and spirit stones.  Although they normally don't change the outcome too much, it's a weird mechanic of odds with a payoff that doens't really makes much sense.

In other words, the game has set a very good premise on this hybrid genre.  It has a good base, a great art form, phenomonial theme and lore.  All it needs is to expand on the mechanics, extend compaign story, rework the chance mechanics a little.  I hope they can pack a lot of more good content in a DLC or something, because otheriwse there would be little incentive to keep working on the same game.

8/10 for novelty.  10/10 if you are big on thematic and artistic elements.

reviewText:
Remember the boardgames that would consume hours as a kid (or admittedly as an adult for me as well)?
This is one of those games.
Great graphics, challenging gameplay and definite replayability, you really should be putting your money here.
Armello features:
Different paths to victory
Gorgeously animated cards
Back story
Monsters
Heroes
Villains
Treachery

Do yourself a favour, and pick this up.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Its sad I cant share my actual Armello stories. Some of them have been pretty good.

Pick one of 8 heroes, each from one of four clans. Wolf, Bear, Rat, or Rabbit. Chose the ring and amulet that will give them special, clan specific, bonuses. On top of the heroes unique ability. Then begin the quest to become King or Queen of Armello. The king will succumb to the Rot a little after a week. Depending on certain choices made before day 9. Or the king defeats a few would be heroes.

Chose cards based on three types. Trickery, that may require gold, or prestiege. Magic, wich requires the magic resource to use. Or Items, requiring gold. Each type may also cause corruption. Corrupted weapons, magic, and trickery will cause the user to contract Rot. Becoming corrupted has its own benefits and drawbacks. And is one of the four ways to claim the throne. You could also win by being prestige leader. By combat. Or by spirit stone, and banish the king. Its never clear how you will win each game. Or who will ultimately become the next ruler of Armello.

Positives:
+ Nice artstyle
+ Neat game and dice mechanics
+ 4 different ways to win
+ No two games play exactly alike
+ Immersive music
+ Procedurally generated maps, no two maps are exactly the same
+ Interesting and animated cards
+ Addicting, reminds me of hearthstone in a way
+ Can still use cards, even if it isnt your turn

+/- Luck plays a big part in some games, epic underdog wins happen.

Negatives
- Only 8 characters currently, the amount of heroes feels small
- Maps only have one size & cannot be changed, currently
- Games are short, only four-ish quests can be done before the king dies
- No animation skips, you have to watch the AI's turns.
- No team game modes. A Clan Vs. Clan would be fun, like the Rabbit Clan versus the Rat Clan.

After playing for a few hours, I dont mind losing, the adventure, challenges, choices, chances, and rewards in each playthrough keep me hooked. Each game tells a story it feels like. And the music and art can get pretty immersive.

And Im used to playing bloody metal shooters like Killing Floor2. Another good game, if you are wondering.

Armello is great,

Buy It/10

Ever played Mage Knight?

NO.

Because it is a boardgame. Most of you dweeble heads have never seen a board game.

This is a boardgame.

Yes it is different. More simplified and not even on the same league as Mage Knight. But as far as complexity, strategy, and that over all boardgame feel... this.. this is the best I have seen so far.

Bravo Armello. Bravo indeed!

Now get you things together and make a physical copy.

reviewText:
Its sad I cant share my actual Armello stories. Some of them have been pretty good.

Pick one of 8 heroes, each from one of four clans. Wolf, Bear, Rat, or Rabbit. Chose the ring and amulet that will give them special, clan specific, bonuses. On top of the heroes unique ability. Then begin the quest to become King or Queen of Armello. The king will succumb to the Rot a little after a week. Depending on certain choices made before day 9. Or the king defeats a few would be heroes.

Chose cards based on three types. Trickery, that may require gold, or prestiege. Magic, wich requires the magic resource to use. Or Items, requiring gold. Each type may also cause corruption. Corrupted weapons, magic, and trickery will cause the user to contract Rot. Becoming corrupted has its own benefits and drawbacks. And is one of the four ways to claim the throne. You could also win by being prestige leader. By combat. Or by spirit stone, and banish the king. Its never clear how you will win each game. Or who will ultimately become the next ruler of Armello.

Positives:
+ Nice artstyle
+ Neat game and dice mechanics
+ 4 different ways to win
+ No two games play exactly alike
+ Immersive music
+ Procedurally generated maps, no two maps are exactly the same
+ Interesting and animated cards
+ Addicting, reminds me of hearthstone in a way
+ Can still use cards, even if it isnt your turn

+/- Luck plays a big part in some games, epic underdog wins happen.

Negatives
- Only 8 characters currently, the amount of heroes feels small
- Maps only have one size & cannot be changed, currently
- Games are short, only four-ish quests can be done before the king dies
- No animation skips, you have to watch the AI's turns.
- No team game modes. A Clan Vs. Clan would be fun, like the Rabbit Clan versus the Rat Clan.

After playing for a few hours, I dont mind losing, the adventure, challenges, choices, chances, and rewards in each playthrough keep me hooked. Each game tells a story it feels like. And the music and art can get pretty immersive.

And Im used to playing bloody metal shooters like Killing Floor2. Another good game, if you are wondering.

Armello is great,

Buy It/10

reviewText:
Being an avid board game and video game player I was excited to try out Armello.

The first thing you will discover when playing the game is that the designers put a lot of work into creating the game. The artwork is fantastic and the game does a great job building an interesting environment.

While Armello does take some time to adjust to, the gameplay is quite interesting and provides for plenty of opportunities for strategy. With four different paths to victory no two games will ever be the same. Armello does a great job combining elements of RPGs, card games, and other tabletop mechanics.

While my playtime is currently kind of low, Armello is not the type of game where I would play multiple games in a row but it is the type of game that I plan on playing every so often.

If the concept behind the game interests you and you like board games in addition to video games, I think you will really enjoy Armello.

Note: I received a free review copy of Armello. Other than the review copy I received no other compensation for this review and receiving the review copy had no impact on the content of this review.
