reviewText:
Early Access Review

As someone who rarely purchases games, I am very pleased that I decided to invest in Armello.

The whole game oozes charm and elegance with lovely graphics and a flowing soundtrack that fits perfectly with the mood of the moment. It features some old ideas but executes them so that they feel new and original.

The game can be played straight from the box but, as the player gets more involved, the various strategies and mechanics become clearer. Do you strive for strength in close combat or opt for tiptoeing around the world, searching for spirit stones, and using long-range tactics to shatter your opponents?

I love the way this game has been designed. It has the power to immerse and captivate you with plenty of variation and scope for future expansion. Each of the heroes provide a different approach to winning the game and can be further defined by completing quests and obtaining a wide range of useful objects like armour, spells and follower companions. The element of luck and random outcomes makes every game different and entertaining.

If you enjoy employing your brain, I think you'll really like Armello!

reviewText:
At first glance, the game is all I want. Fantasy, boardgame, nice graphic, etc. However, the truth is the game can't really go far after I try it out.
1. Lack of game content. Only one game mode except tutorial. With the mechanism and all the set-ups they should be able to come up with more.
2. Poor multiplayer experience. No communication at all. That is killing a boardgame!
3. Not balanced. The winning conditions and the characters are not well balanced.
4. Extremly random. Luck decides everything.
5. Tends to snowball. A 50%-chance bad start may totally destroy you whole game, not leaving you any chance if others not stupid.
If the game is like a $10 small product I would like it much better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are already plenty of reviews stating what this game is, so I'll skip that part. The real question is, is it enjoyable, and the answer is a resounding yes. Is it worth 25 USD? Well...

Being early access there are still a few kinks I feel the game needs to work out, but the developers are constantly tweaking the game to make it as fair for all players and strategies as possible. New characters can currently be previewed in game and on the forums, so the current four are certainly not the end all, and more content and game modes are still being worked on. Multiplayer is operating, though it's currently easier to schedule a time with friends than wait for a public match. Single player is still a hoot though, and will keep you busy for hours as you try and achieve the different win conditions for in-game rewards that can be used in multiplayer matches. Artwork and design is also stunningly beautiful. For what's there, 25 may seem a little steep, but for what's promised, 25 is well worth it.

reviewText:
Want more players in multiplayer? Multiplayer is regional block by Steam. To change region, go to

Steam -> Settings -> Download -> Download Region

Europe has a big fan base, my favourite region is UK London. I notice that multiplayer's strategy changes base on region.

This is a tabletop games, takes 10-20 hours to unlock all rings and amulets. Then the only thing left to do is multiplayer. You don't have to put much time into this game to be powerful, don't have to worry that you can't catch up with others after leaving the game once a while. Just play with people whenever you want. You need skills and luck to win, neither devotion nor pay to win.

Move three cells each turn, draw a number of cards base on wit. Cards can be equipments, useable items, spells, traps, etc. Finish quests to gain more stats and rewards. Three ways to kill king, or win with prestige. Every character has their own special ability. Each clan has their unique rings. As a result, strategy is diverse. You can speed up AI in option, and push . button, to speed up AI further, too. In multiplayer, people uses strategies that you never see with AI. I learned a lot in multiplayer.

For those who complains about randomness. I have played so many turn-based strategy games, a few notable are heroes series, Xcom series, talisman, Elder Sign, Hard West, King’s Bounty, etc. I tend to play on highest difficulty and get boring because it is too easy. In Armello, I win 70-80% against AI because of randomness and I enjoy it. I won’t play this game if I know how to win 100% every time.

Multiplayer is where the real challenge begins. Where you feel anxious and tense, the intense pleasure, a kind of addiction. The stimulation is too good...You don’t want to go back to single player anymore.

Conclusion: A Hidden gem. Must play.

reviewText:
You play one charakter with unique abilites like a first strike or getting more money from villages etc. From then on you try to win the game by either killing the king, curing him or let him die by himself and be choosen as the next king by reputation.
Which way you choose depends on your playstyle but also on your cards which you draw at the start of your round. By completing personal quests you get items, gold and other usefull stuff to beat all other players. But beware of them trying to interrupt you.

It is pretty much RNG at many times - too much for many guys. But it is a board game with dices - so there have to be RNG. However it's much more about how you take adventage of your luck and make your way to victory not too obvious. I really enjoy this game.

It's pure fun and beautiful.

reviewText:
While a beautiful game with some interesting game mechanics, overall I found the experience weighted against me so heavily as to be unfun.  Every choice and strategy I tried to implement was meaningless because the dice never came up my way, and while I appreciate the desire to force the player to change their strategy due to circumstances it became very tedious when it happened all the time.

This was all from the singleplayer experience, I didn't try multiplayer.  I can't imagine anything would have gone differently though.

Perhaps a decent game for a luckier person, but if you're the sort who rolls poorly this game is just going to be a lesson in frustration.
